I'm a 5-year-old girl. Does she have any past medical conditions or take any medications? No, I don't have any past medical conditions or take any medications. Does she show similar behaviors at home? Yes, I ignore my parents just like at school. Is there any family history of behavioral or psychiatric conditions? I don't know about my family's medical history.
input: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of difficulty at school. She does not listen to her teachers or complete assignments as requested. She does not play or interact with her peers. The girl also ignores her parents. Throughout the visit, she draws circles repeatedly and avoids eye contact. Physical and neurological examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Does she have difficulty sitting still or seem excessively active?

instruction: I passed out during a soccer game, and I've been feeling short of breath for the last 3 months and chest pain when I do strenuous activities for the past week. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 26-year-old male. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? No, I haven't mentioned any medical conditions or medications. Do you have a family history of heart disease? Yes, my brother had a sudden death a couple of years ago. Do you experience any palpitations? No, I haven't mentioned experiencing palpitations.
input: A 26-year-old male professional soccer player is brought to the emergency department due to an episode of syncope during a game. He has felt increasing shortness of breath during the past 3 months. During the past week, he has been feeling chest pain upon exertion. He also tells the doctor that his brother had a sudden death a couple of years ago. His heart rate is 98/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur immediately after S1; it is best heard on the apex, and it radiates to the axilla. There is also an early diastolic murmur heard in early diastole, which is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope. When the Valsalva maneuver is performed, the murmur becomes louder. An ECG and an echocardiogram are performed, which confirm the diagnosis.
output: Do you have any chest tightness at rest?

instruction: I've been experiencing heartburn and diarrhea for the last 2 months. How old are you? I am 31 years old. Are you male or female? I am a male.
input: A 31-year-old Caucasian male presents to his physician's complaining of heartburn and diarrhea for 2 months. He reports a history of tumors of the parathyroid and pituitary glands. Laboratory results show a serum gastrin level of 1600 pg/mL (normal 0-200 pg/mL) and an increased basal acid output to maximal acid output ratio (BAO/MAO). The findings on endoscopy are shown in Figure A along with multiple gastric ulcerations. Stomach pH is measured to be 1.1.
output: Have you been taking any medications?

instruction: I've been looking pale and feeling really tired lately. How old are you? I am 5 years old.
input: A 5-year-old girl presents for a routine checkup. The patient’s parents say she has been looking pale and tired lately. Her family history is unremarkable. Upon physical examination, several bruises are seen, as well as petechial bleeding on her limbs. A complete blood count shows leukocytosis with severe anemia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows 35% blasts. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows hepatosplenomegaly and a chest radiograph reveals a mediastinal mass.
output: Are you male or female?

instruction: I've been having severe lower abdominal pain for several hours, fevers, feeling generally unwell, and nausea for the last 2 days. What is your age and sex? I am 23 years old and female. Have you missed a period or think you might be pregnant? My last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago, and a urine test showed that I'm not pregnant. Have you noticed any abnormal vaginal discharge? Yes, there is a yellow-white purulent discharge. Have you had any new or multiple sexual partners recently? Yes, I've had 3 sexual partners in the past month. Have you been diagnosed with any sexually transmitted infections before? No, my past medical history is insignificant. Do you have any pain during sexual intercourse? The exam showed that my cervix is inflamed with motion tenderness, which suggests it might be painful.
input: A 23-year-old gravida 1-para-1 (G1P1) presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started several hours ago. She has had fevers, malaise, and nausea for the last 2 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her past medical history is insignificant. She has had 3 sexual partners in the past 1 month and uses oral contraception. The vital signs include temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Uterine and adnexal tenderness is also elicited. A urine test is negative for pregnancy. On speculum examination, the cervix is inflamed with motion tenderness and a yellow-white purulent discharge.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)

instruction: I've been having painful joints, and my right wrist and left ankle and knee feel stiff and sore. How old are you? I am 19 years old.
input:
A 19-year-old university student presents to the student clinic with painful joints. He states that over the past week his right wrist has become increasingly stiff. This morning he noticed pain and stiffness in his left ankle and left knee. The patient has celiac disease and takes a daily multivitamin. He says he is sexually active with multiple male and female partners. He smokes marijuana but denies intravenous drug abuse. He recently traveled to Uganda to volunteer at a clinic that specialized in treating patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). He also went on an extended hiking trip last week in New Hampshire. Physical exam reveals swelling of the right wrist and a warm, swollen, erythematous left knee. The left Achilles tendon is tender to palpation. There are also multiple vesicopustular lesions on the dorsum of the right hand. No penile discharge is appreciated. Arthrocentesis of the left knee is performed. Synovial fluid results are shown below:

Synovial fluid:
Appearance: Cloudy
Leukocyte count: 40,000/mm^3 with neutrophil predominance

Gram stain is negative. A synovial fluid culture is pending.
output: Are you male or female?

instruction: I currently have nausea and a headache, and I've vomited twice in the last half hour. What is your age and sex? I am a 27-year-old woman. Have you experienced similar headaches before? No, I have no history of serious illnesses and I take no medications. Have you noticed any visual changes? No, I haven't noticed any changes in my vision. Did your headache start suddenly? Yes, the headache started after I hit my head on the sidewalk. Did you lose consciousness when you hit your head? Yes, I was unconscious for a couple of minutes after the accident. Are you experiencing any confusion or memory loss? I'm oriented to person, place, and time. Are you experiencing any weakness or numbness in any part of your body? The case vignette does not mention any weakness or numbness. Are you experiencing any dizziness or balance problems? The case vignette does not mention dizziness or balance problems. Are you experiencing any seizures? Yes, I started having a seizure during the physical examination.
input: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While performing the remainder of the physical examination the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Epidural Hematoma

instruction: I've been having progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months and occasionally, I have a dry cough. Can you please tell me your age and gender? I'm a 60-year-old man. Do you have any history of hypertension, diabetes, or heart disease? No, I don't have a history of those conditions. Have you ever smoked or currently smoke? Yes, I've smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Are you experiencing any chest pain? No, I'm not experiencing any chest pain. Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or ankles? No, I haven't noticed any swelling in my legs or ankles. Have you experienced any unintentional weight loss? No, I have not experienced any unintentional weight loss.
input: A previously healthy 60-year-old man comes to his physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. He does not experience shortness of breath at rest. He also occasionally has a dry cough. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He drinks a beer daily and occasionally more on weekends. He does not use illicit drugs. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lbs); BMI is 19.7 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I've been having several episodes of dizziness over the past month where it feels like I'm spinning. What is your age and sex? I'm a 64-year-old woman. Are you experiencing any hearing loss or ringing in your ears during the dizziness? No, I'm not experiencing any hearing loss or ringing in my ears. Have you been experiencing any nausea or vomiting during these episodes? No, I have no nausea.
input: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month. The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes she feels as though she is spinning. Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position. They also sometimes happen when she suddenly turns her head to look at something. She has no nausea. Last month, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead.
output: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been getting in trouble for being disruptive during class, like not listening to my teacher and refusing to do what I'm asked. How old are you? I am 9 years old. Are you male or female? I am a boy. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions? No, I haven't been diagnosed with any medical conditions. Do any family members have behavioral or mental health issues? The information about my family's health wasn't provided. Have these behaviors been present for more than six months? The information provided doesn't specify how long these behaviors have been present. Do you have difficulty paying attention or staying focused on tasks? The information provided doesn't specifically mention if I have difficulty paying attention or staying focused on tasks.
input: A parent-teacher conference is called to discuss the behavior of a 9 year-old boy. According to the boy's teacher, he has become progressively more disruptive during class. When asked to help clean up or read out-loud, he replies with "You're not the boss of me." or "You can't make me." He refuses to participate in gym class, but will play the same games during recess. He gets along with and is well-liked by his peers. His mother reports that her son can "sometimes be difficult," but he is helpful around the house and is very good playing with his 7-year-old sister.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Oppositional Defiant Disorder

instruction: I came in with a fever and a headache that started yesterday, but now I'm also experiencing blurry vision, chills, nausea, and vomiting. What is your age and gender? I am a 47-year-old woman.
input: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a fever and a headache. Her symptoms started yesterday and have rapidly progressed. Initially, she was experiencing just a fever and a headache which she was treating with acetaminophen. It rapidly progressed to blurry vision, chills, nausea, and vomiting. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension and she is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and oral contraceptive pills. Her temperature is 104°F (40.0°C), blood pressure is 157/93 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Upon further inspection, the patient also demonstrates exophthalmos in the affected eye. The patient's extraocular movements are notably decreased in the affected eye with reduced vertical and horizontal gaze. The patient also demonstrates decreased sensation near the affected eye in the distribution of V1 and V2. While the patient is in the department waiting for a CT scan, she becomes lethargic and acutely altered.
output: Do you have any past medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been having more painful bumps on my chest and I've also been feeling fevers, chills, and my joints, especially around my chest, hurt. What is your age? I'm 16 years old. What is your sex? I am male. Do you have any existing medical conditions? Yes, I have severe nodulocystic acne.
input: A 16-year-old male with past medical history of severe nodulocystic acne presents to the emergency room with increasing painful cysts on the trunk after recently starting oral isotretinoin in the past 3 weeks. Patient endorses fevers, chills, joint pain particularly along the chest. Examination reveals multiple inflammatory papules and large cystic nodules wih hemorrhagic crust on the chest, shoulders, and back. The sternum is tender to palpation.
output: Are you taking any medications?

instruction: I've been hitting my head on the wall a lot, I'm not talking as much as I used to, and I don't answer when people call my name. How old is the patient and what is their sex? I'm a 3-year-old boy. Has he had any recent illnesses or injuries? No, I haven't had any recent illnesses or injuries. Is he currently taking any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications. Does he engage in repetitive behaviors or have restricted interests? Yes, I keep banging my head on the wall and I'm not interested in my toys anymore. Does he have any family history of developmental or behavioral disorders? I don't know about that.
input: A mother brings her 3-year-old son to the doctor because she is worried that he might be harming himself by constantly banging his head on the wall. He has been exhibiting this behavior for a few months. She is also worried because he has started to speak less than he used to and does not respond when his name is called. He seems aloof during playtime with other children and seems to have lost interest in most of his toys.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Autism Spectrum Disorder

instruction: I've been seeing some light-colored spots on my legs that started appearing a year ago. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 50-year-old male. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have high blood pressure.
input: A 50-year-old African American male with past medical history of hypertension and hypertension presents for evaluation of light spots on his legs that he initially noticed one year ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy, but he is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. He has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.
output: Are the spots itchy or do they cause any other symptoms?

instruction: I've been having chronic pelvic pain, particularly during sex, and I recently started having yellowish vaginal discharge. How old are you? I am 21 years old. Have you noticed any unusual odor with the discharge? No, there hasn't been any unusual odor with the discharge. Are you sexually active? Yes, I am sexually active. Have you experienced any pain or burning when you urinate? No, I haven't had any pain or burning when I urinate. Have you had any new sexual partners recently? Yes, I have had new sexual partners recently. Have you experienced any itching or irritation in your genital area? No, I haven't experienced any itching or irritation in my genital area.
input: A 21-year-old woman presents to the women’s clinic with chronic pelvic pain, especially during sexual intercourse. She also reports new onset yellowish vaginal discharge. She has no significant past medical history. She does not take contraceptive pills as she has had a copper intrauterine device placed. She smokes 2–3 cigarettes every day. She drinks beer on weekends. She admits to being sexually active with over 10 partners since the age of 14. Her blood pressure is 118/66 mm Hg, the heart rate is 68/min, the respiratory rate is 12/min and the temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). On physical examination she appears uncomfortable but alert and oriented. Her heart and lung examinations are within normal limits. Bimanual exam reveals a tender adnexa and uterus with cervical motion tenderness. Whiff test is negative and vaginal pH is greater than 4.5.
output: Do you have any fever or chills?

instruction: I've been having pain in my hands for the last 6 months, and it's worse when I wake up, but the pain stays all day even though I take ibuprofen.
input: A 34-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a 6-month history of pain in her hands. The pain is worse in the morning but is present throughout the day despite her use of ibuprofen. Additionally, her left 4th finger recently began to swell and is particularly painful. She has also begun to notice changes in her nails, which have become brittle. Prior to the onset of symptoms, she made multiple visits to the clinic with complaints of pain in her lower back and ankles that was eventually well controlled with ibuprofen. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pressure is 138/88 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 18/min. Inspection of the hands demonstrates the physical examination findings present in Figure A. Additionally, a rash on the right elbow is identified and pictured in Figure B. The distal interphalangeal joints of the left hand are tender to palpation, as is the second distal interphalangeal joint of the right hand. The Achilles tendons are tender bilaterally, and ultrasonography is consistent with mild Achilles tendonitis bilaterally. Testing for HLA-B27 is positive.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having severe, all-over belly pain that gets worse after I eat, and I've been feeling nauseous and sometimes there's blood in my diarrhea. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 57-year-old man. Are you currently taking any medications or have any past medical conditions? I have high blood pressure, which I take medication for.
input: A 57-year-old man presents with 2 days of severe, generalized, abdominal pain that is worse after meals. He is also nauseated and reports occasional diarrhea mixed with blood. Apart from essential hypertension, his medical history is unremarkable. His vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure of 145/92 mm Hg, and an irregularly irregular pulse of 105/min. Physical examination is only notable for mild periumbilical tenderness.
output: How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?

instruction: I'm experiencing pain in both my knees and severe pain over my right groin. My right leg also feels a bit shorter, is bent, turned inward, and I can't open it outward. What is your age? I'm 25 years old. Are you male or female? I am a female. Have your symptoms started recently? Yes, they started after being in a car accident.
input: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been having trouble focusing at work and I'm really tired all the time, even though I wake up early and can't get back to sleep. How old are you? I'm 34 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am male. Are you currently taking any medications? The case vignette doesn't mention me taking any medications. Have you experienced any significant changes in your mood or feelings recently? Yes, my wife has noticed I'm speaking more slowly than usual and I'm not as interested in dance classes we used to enjoy together. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I've been experiencing these issues for about 2 months. Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently? My appetite has decreased recently.
input: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of difficulty concentrating at work. He is worried he may lose his job due to poor performance. He feels constantly tired but attributes his fatigue to waking up early most mornings and being unable to fall back asleep. His wife has noticed that he has been speaking more slowly than usual and his appetite has decreased. He used to enjoy dance classes with her but has not been as interested in this recently. He is a veteran who returned from a deployment to Afghanistan 2 years ago.
output: Have you noticed any changes in your weight recently?

instruction: I have a painful rash with small red spots that turned yellow and pus-filled on my right index finger. What is your age and gender? I'm a 21-year-old male.
input: A 21-year-old male presents for evaluation of a painful rash on his right index finger. He reports a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. He denies any trauma or topical products applied to the area. He has a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base.
output: Have you recently injured your finger?

instruction: I've been having sharp, central chest pain for several days that doesn't seem to change when I move around, but it gets worse when I lie down and feels a bit better when I sit up. What is your age and sex? I am a 31-year-old man.
input: An otherwise healthy 31-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a several-day history of sharp, central chest pain, which is constant and unrelated to exertion. The pain gets worse on lying down and decreases with sitting forward. He has smoked 10–15 cigarettes daily for the past 7 years. His blood pressure is 120/50 mm Hg, the pulse is 92/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F). On physical examination, a scratching sound is heard at end-expiration with the patient leaning forward. ECG is shown in the image. Serum troponin is mildly elevated.
output: Do you have any other symptoms, such as fever or shortness of breath?

instruction: I've been having worsening abdominal pain over the last few hours and I'm feeling nauseous.
input:
A 72-year-old man presents to the ED complaining of worsening abdominal pain over the last few hours. He also reports nausea, but denies fever, vomiting, or changes in the appearance of his bowel movements. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and peptic ulcer disease. Due to his recurrent bleeding peptic ulcers, he does not take warfarin. His surgical history is significant for an appendectomy as a child. His medications include metformin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and omeprazole. He has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. His temperature is 37.6 C (99.7 F), blood pressure is 146/80 mm Hg, pulse is 115/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. On physical exam, he is in acute distress due to the pain. Pulmonary auscultation reveals scattered wheezes and decreased air entry. His heart rate is irregularly irregular, with no murmurs, rubs or gallops. Abdominal exam is significant for decreased bowel sounds and diffuse tenderness. Initial laboratory evaluation is as follows:
Na 138 mEq/L, Cl 101 mEq/L, HCO3 12 mEq/L, BUN 21 mg/dL, Cr 0.9 mg/dL, glucose 190 mg/dL, amylase 240 U/L (normal < 65 U/L).
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: My baby's eyes and skin have been turning yellow for the past 2 weeks. How old is your baby? She is 4 weeks old.
input:
A 4-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowing of her eyes and skin for 2 weeks. The mother has noticed that the girl's stools have become pale over the past week. She was breastfed since birth but her parents switched her to formula feeds recently after reading on the internet that breastfeeding could be the cause of her current symptoms. The patient was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 50th percentile for length and at the 60th percentile for weight. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum studies show:
Bilirubin
Total 15 mg/dL
Direct 12.3 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 2007 U/L
AST 53 U/L
ALT 45 U/L
γ-glutamyl transferase 154 U/L
Blood group A positive
output: Is your baby breastfed or formula-fed?

instruction: I've been having an aggressive cough with lots of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum. Can you tell me your age and sex? I am a 51-year-old woman. Are you experiencing any fever or chills? No, I don't have a fever or chills. Have you smoked or been exposed to secondhand smoke? No, I'm a non-smoker. Have you had this cough for more than three weeks? Yes, I've had this cough for about 11 years.
input: A 51-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of an aggressive cough with copious amounts of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum. She says she has had this cough for about 11 years with exacerbations similar to her presentation today. She also reports that her cough is worse in the morning. She was evaluated multiple times in the past because of recurrent bouts of bronchitis that have required treatment with antibiotics. She is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). Chest auscultation reveals crackles and wheezing over the right middle lobe and the rest of her physical examinations are normal. The chest X-ray shows irregular opacities in the right middle lobe and diffuse airway thickening.
output: Do you experience shortness of breath or wheezing?

instruction: I've been experiencing discharge from my left nipple for the past 3 months, and the amount seems to be increasing. What is your age? I am 52 years old. What is your sex? I am a woman. Is the nipple discharge bloody? No, the discharge looks gray-greenish. Do you have any pain or tenderness in your breasts? No, I don't have any pain or tenderness. Do you have any breast lumps? Yes, there is a firm mass under the inverted nipple in my left breast.
input: A 52-year-old woman visits your office complaining about discharge from her left nipple for the past 3 months. The discharge looks like gray greenish and its amount is progressively increasing. She appears to be anxious and extremely uncomfortable with this situation as it is embarrassing for her when it occurs outdoors. Past medical history is insignificant. Her family history is negative for breast and ovarian disorders. She tries to stay active by running for 30 minutes every day on a treadmill, staying away from smoking, and by eating a balanced diet. She drinks alcohol occasionally. During physical examination you find a firm, stable mass under an inverted nipple in her left breast; while on the right breast, dilated subareolar ducts can be noted. There is no lymphadenopathy and remaining of the physical exam is normal. A mammogram is performed which reveals tubular calcifications.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Mammary duct ectasia

instruction: I'm experiencing severe pain in my right leg, along with tingling and weakness. What is your age and sex? I'm a 58-year-old man. Do you have any chronic illnesses or take any medications? Yes, I have type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure. Have you noticed any swelling or redness in your leg? There's no redness, but my right leg is pale and cold.
input: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe right leg pain accompanied by tingling and weakness. His condition started suddenly 3 hours ago when he was watching a movie. His medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has been smoking 20–30 cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. His vital signs include a blood pressure of 149/85 mm Hg, a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), and an irregular pulse of 96/min. On physical examination, his right popliteal and posterior tibial pulses are absent. His right leg is pale and cold.
output: Did the pain start suddenly?

instruction: I've been feeling very tired and noticeably pale for the past two days. What is your age and sex? I'm a 2-year-old boy. Have you experienced any bruising or bleeding? No, I haven't noticed any bruising or bleeding lately. Have you had any recent illnesses or infections? Yes, about a week ago, I had belly pain, throwing up, and bloody poop, but that has gotten better. Have you noticed any swelling or changes in your urine? I haven't noticed any swelling, but I can't speak about changes in my urine. Have you been taking any medications recently? My parents have been giving me oral rehydration solution.
input:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of pallor and increasing lethargy for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a 6-week roadtrip in Mexico because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him oral rehydration solution. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 45,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec
Serum
Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 2.5 mg/dL
Direct 0.1 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L
A blood smear shows schistocytes.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome

instruction: I suddenly passed out while playing baseball and needed CPR to wake up again. What is your age and sex? I'm a 23-year-old man. Have you experienced chest pain or palpitations before? No, I haven't had any chest pain or palpitations before. Do you have any family history of heart disease or sudden death? My case doesn't mention any family history of heart disease or sudden death.
input: A 23-year-old man presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury. Consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs. An S4 is present.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I have painless, black, really swollen bumps on my left hand. What is your age and sex? I am a 50-year-old man. Do you have any other medical conditions? I do not have any medical conditions that I am aware of. Have the bumps changed in size or appearance recently? No, they haven't changed in size or appearance recently.
input: A 50-year-old farmer presents to a physician with painless, black, severely swollen pustules on the left hand. Examination reveals extensive swelling around the wound. Microscopy reveals gram-positive bacilli with a bamboo stick appearance. Culture shows large, gray, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular borders.
output: Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your hand?

instruction: I've been getting more confused and having difficulty walking for the past 4 months. How old are you and what is your gender? I am a 77-year-old woman. Do you have any past medical history or take any medications? Yes, I have high cholesterol and high blood pressure, and I take lisinopril and atorvastatin.
input: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the physician for gradually increasing confusion and difficulty walking for the past 4 months. Her daughter is concerned because she has been forgetful and seems to be walking more slowly. She has been distracted during her weekly bridge games and her usual television shows. She has also had increasingly frequent episodes of urinary incontinence and now wears an adult diaper daily. She has hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 139/83 mmHg. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. She has a broad-based gait and takes short steps. Sensation is intact and muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Laboratory studies are within normal limits.
output: Have you experienced any urinary incontinence?

instruction: I have a burning and aching pain along the bottom of my foot, and sometimes it feels numb. What is your age and sex? I am a 35-year-old male. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? The pain has been getting worse recently. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions or are you taking any medications? I've had surgical repair of my Achilles tendon, ACL, and medial meniscus, but I am currently not taking any medications. Have you been diagnosed with diabetes? No, I have not mentioned being diagnosed with diabetes. Have you been drinking alcohol regularly? I haven't mentioned anything about drinking alcohol.
input: A 35-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with pain along the bottom of his foot. The patient is a long-time runner but states that the pain has been getting worse recently. He states that when running and at rest he has a burning and aching pain along the bottom of his foot that sometimes turns to numbness. Taking time off from training does not improve his symptoms. The patient has a past medical history of surgical repair of his Achilles tendon, ACL, and medial meniscus. He is currently not taking any medications. The patient lives with his wife and they both practice a vegan lifestyle. On physical exam the patient states that he is currently not experiencing any pain in his foot but rather is experiencing numbness/tingling along the plantar surface of his foot. Strength is 5/5 and reflexes are 2+ in the lower extremities.
output: Do you have any family history of neurological disorders?

instruction: I have multiple sores on my left forearm and neck that started as red spots and then became enlarged, ulcerated, and got crusty over the past five weeks.
input: A 52-year-old man presents with a 5-week history of multiple cutaneous ulcers on his left forearm and neck, which he first noticed after returning from a 2-month stay in rural Peru. He does not recall any trauma or arthropod bites. The lesions began as non-pruritic erythematous papules that became enlarged, ulcerated, and crusted. There is no history of fever or abdominal pain. He has been sexually active with a single partner since their marriage at 24 years of age. The physical examination reveals erythematous, crusted plaques with central ulceration and a raised border. There is no fluctuance, drainage, or sporotrichoid spread. A punch biopsy was performed, which revealed an ulcerated lesion with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate. Amastigotes within dermal macrophages are seen on Giemsa staining.
output: Can you please tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having pain in my armpit for about a year and it often gets worse. What is your age and sex? I am a 23-year-old woman. Have you noticed any lumps or bumps in your armpit? Yes, there's something unusual there.
input: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with pain in her axilla. She has had this pain chronically for the past year with frequent exacerbations. The patient has a past medical history of polycystic ovarian syndrome and smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily. Her temperature is 97.0°F (36.1°C), blood pressure is 137/98 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A.
output: Have the lumps been discharging any fluid or pus?

instruction: I have been having multiple episodes where I stare and make faces without realizing it, and I can't respond to my family when this happens. Can you tell me your age and gender? I'm a 9-year-old girl. How often do these episodes occur? They have been happening for the past 3 weeks. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions or are you taking any medications? No, I haven't been diagnosed with any conditions or taking any medications. Have any of your family members experienced similar episodes? Not that I know of. How long does each episode last? They last for several minutes.
input: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of multiple episodes of staring and facial grimacing that have occurred over the past 3 weeks. There are no precipitating factors for these episodes and they last for several minutes. She does not respond to her family members during these episodes. One week ago, her brother witnessed an episode in which she woke up while sleeping, stared, and made hand gestures. She does not remember any of these episodes but does recall having a vague muddy taste in her mouth prior to the onset of these symptoms. After the episode, she feels lethargic and is confused. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities.
output: Do you feel confused or tired after an episode?

instruction: I have painless, black, really swollen bumps on my left hand. What is your age and sex? I am a 50-year-old man. Do you have any other medical conditions? I do not have any medical conditions that I am aware of. Have the bumps changed in size or appearance recently? No, they haven't changed in size or appearance recently. Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your hand? No, I haven't had any recent injuries or trauma to my hand. Do you have any fever or other systemic symptoms? No, I don't have a fever or any other symptoms. Have you noticed any changes in the bumps over time? The bumps have turned black and are severely swollen but they haven't changed much otherwise. Have you been exposed to animals or animal products recently? As a farmer, I am regularly exposed to animals and animal products.
input: A 50-year-old farmer presents to a physician with painless, black, severely swollen pustules on the left hand. Examination reveals extensive swelling around the wound. Microscopy reveals gram-positive bacilli with a bamboo stick appearance. Culture shows large, gray, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular borders.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Cutaneous Anthrax

instruction: My skin is really saggy, especially on my cheeks, neck, underarms, and thighs. What is your age and gender? I'm a 6-year-old boy. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? I have a medical condition where my aortic root is dilated. Do any family members have similar skin or heart conditions? My mom said that other family members might have skin like mine. Do you have any joint hypermobility or frequent joint dislocations? I haven't mentioned anything about joint problems or dislocations.
input: A 6-year-old male with past medical history of aortic root dilation presents for evaluation of loose skin that was noticed at birth but has progressively worsened. Family members have noticed the patient's skin is saggy but thought it may be related to overeating. The patient's mother reports other family members may have similar skin. Physical examination reveals loose, sagging skin of the cheeks, neck, axilla, thighs. A punch biopsy demonstrates loss of elastic fibers. Arm span width to body height ratio is within normal limits.
output: Have you had any hernias or digestive problems?

instruction: I've been feeling weak and from time to time there's a burning pain in my neck, shoulders, and arms. What is your age and gender? I am a 23-year-old woman. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I've been experiencing these symptoms for about 8 months. Do you experience numbness or tingling in your limbs? I haven't felt temperature or pain in my arms, but I can feel vibrations and know where my body is positioned. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions or are you taking any medications? No, I haven't mentioned any diagnoses or medications.
input: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of weakness and intermittent burning pain in her neck, shoulders, and arms. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 1 year ago. Examination of the upper extremities shows absent reflexes, muscle weakness, and fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent; vibration and proprioception are preserved. The pupils are equal and reactive to light.
output: Do you have any family history of neurological disorders?

instruction: I've got some small, painless bumps on my tummy that don't itch. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 2-year-old girl. Have the bumps been increasing in number or size? The question about whether the bumps have been increasing in number or size isn't something I can answer based on the information given. Do you have any other symptoms besides the bumps? No, I don't have any other symptoms. Have you noticed any changes in the size or number of the bumps? There's no mention of any changes in the size or number of the bumps. When did the bumps first appear? The exact time the bumps appeared hasn't been specified. Do you have any past medical history or is she taking any medications? I've been previously healthy and am not on any medications. Does anyone in the family have similar skin bumps? Yes, one child at my daycare had similar bumps last week.
input: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox one month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several skin-colored, nontender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Molluscum contagiosum

instruction: I've been having abdominal pain and discomfort for the past 3 days. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 25-year-old woman. Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements? Yes, I've had alternating diarrhea and constipation.
input: A 25-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and discomfort for the past 3 days. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) a couple of years ago, managed until recently with imipramine, psyllium, and loperamide. 5 days ago, because she had developed alternating diarrhea and constipation, bloating, and abdominal pain on her medication, she was started on alosetron. Her current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), the heart rate is 115/min, the blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 22/min. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive on auscultation. A fecal occult blood test is positive and laboratory tests show her white cell count to be 15,800/µL.
output: Do you have any history of similar abdominal pain before?

instruction: I have a recurring rash on my back that tends to come back mostly during the summer.
input: A 65-year-old man presents with a recurring rash on his back. He has had the rash several times before, most often during the summer, and it was treated successfully with an antifungal shampoo prescribed by a prior dermatologist. The rash is not itchy or painful. He has a history of depression and hypertension. On physical examination, hyperpigmented macules coalescing into patches with very fine white scale are found. The lesions are scattered primarily on his upper chest and upper back.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having intermittent pain on the sides of my lower back for about 5 months. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 31-year-old woman. Have you noticed any changes in your urination, such as pain or blood? I have had five urinary tract infections over the past 2 years. Have you noticed any blood in your urine? No, I haven't noticed any blood in my urine. Have you experienced any fever or chills? No, I haven't experienced any fever or chills. Do you feel any pain that spreads to your abdomen or groin? No, the pain does not spread to my abdomen or groin. Are you taking any medications? You have not provided me any information about taking medications, so I can't say if I am. Have you experienced any weight loss or fatigue? No, I haven't experienced any weight loss or fatigue. Have you ever had kidney stones? You didn't give me any information about having kidney stones, so I can't say if I have. Do you have any family history of kidney disease? You haven't given me any details about my family history, so I don't know if I have a family history of kidney disease.
input: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of intermittent flank pain. Over the past 2 years, she has had five urinary tract infections. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral, nontender upper abdominal masses. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 29 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.4 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple parenchymal anechoic masses.
output: Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your back?

instruction: I've lost my appetite, I'm not gaining weight properly, and have lost about 15 pounds in the last three months. How old are you? I am 16 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am a girl. Have you had any other symptoms? I haven't had my menstrual period in 3 months. Are you intentionally restricting your food intake? Yes, I am keeping track of my daily calorie intake in a diary and trying to lose more weight.
input: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned about her lack of appetite and poor weight gain. She has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. The patient states that she should try to lose more weight because she does not want to be overweight anymore. She maintains a diary of her daily calorie intake. Menarche was at the age of 13 years, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. She is on the high school track team. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She is at 50th percentile for height and below the 5th percentile for weight and BMI. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination shows fine hair over the trunk and extremities.
output: Are you afraid of gaining weight or becoming fat?

instruction: I've been feeling really tired, I've lost some weight, and I've got these multiple painless bumps on my neck and underarms. What is your age and sex? I am a 29-year-old man.
input: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and multiple painless swellings on his neck and axilla. He reports that his swellings become painful after he drinks alcohol. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy specimen shows giant binucleate cells.
output: Have you experienced any fevers or night sweats?

instruction: I've been losing a lot of hair for the past 2 months, with clumps falling out when I shower and on my pillow. What is your age and gender? I'm a 20-year-old man. Have other family members experienced similar hair loss? No, they haven't.
input: A 20-year-old man presents with 2 months of hair loss. He says that approximately 8 months ago, he was involved in a motor vehicle accident which resulted in several fractures and a difficult recovery. He has noticed clumps of hair coming out in the shower and on his pillow. He denies scalp itch. He denies any recent infections or genital sores.
output: Have you started any new medications recently?

instruction: I feel weak and don't want to walk. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 3-year-old boy. Have you had any recent illnesses or infections? No, I haven't been sick recently.
input: A 3-year-old boy presents to the office with his mother. She states that her son seems weak and unwilling to walk. He only learned how to walk recently after a very notable delay. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all verbal and social milestones but he has a great deal of trouble with gross and fine motor skills. Past medical history is noncontributory. He takes a multivitamin every day. The mother states that some boys on her side of the family have had similar symptoms and worries that her son might have the same condition. Today, the boy’s vital signs include: blood pressure 110/65 mm Hg, heart rate 90/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the boy appears well developed and pleasant. He sits and listens and follows direction. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. He struggles to get up to a standing position after sitting on the floor. A genetic study is performed that reveals a significant deletion in the gene that codes for dystrophin.
output: Have you had any recent injuries or falls?

instruction: I've been feeling really tired and generally unwell. What is your age and sex? I am a 71-year-old man.
input: A 71-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with non-specific complaints of fatigue and malaise. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, non-seminomatous testicular cancer, and hypercholesterolemia. He currently smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day, drinks a glass of wine per day, and he currently denies any illicit drug use. His vital signs include: temperature, 36.7°C (98.0°F); blood pressure, 126/74 mm Hg; heart rate, 87/min; and respiratory rate, 17/min. On examination, his physician notices cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally, as well as splenomegaly. The patient comments that he has lost 18.1 kg (40 lb) over the past 6 months without a change in diet or exercise, which he was initially not concerned about. The physician orders a complete blood count and adds on flow cytometry.
output: Have you experienced any weight loss, fever, or night sweats?

instruction: I've been experiencing lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 34-year-old man. Do you experience morning stiffness that lasts longer than 30 minutes? Yes, the pain and stiffness are worse in the morning. Have you had any eye problems, such as redness or pain? I haven't mentioned any eye problems.
input: A 34-year-old man presents to his physician with a complaint of lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. He describes the pain as being worse in the morning and then gradually improving with activity throughout the day. On physical exam, he has decreased anterior flexion of the lumbar spine. A radiograph of his lumbar spine is obtained and is shown in Figure A.
output: Do you have any pain or swelling in other joints?

instruction: I've got a rash all over my body, even on the palms of my hands and the bottoms of my feet, and I've had a really high fever for the past 5 days that isn't getting better with fever medicine. What is your age and gender? I am a 5-year-old girl. Do you have any red or swollen eyes? I haven't mentioned anything about my eyes being red or swollen. Do you have any swollen lymph nodes? Yes, my neck feels swollen but it's not easy to feel the exact lumps. Have you noticed any changes in your mouth, like red or swollen lips? My throat looks really red, but I haven't said anything about my lips.
input:
A 5-year-old girl presents with a rash and a persistent fever of 41.0°C (105.8°F), not relieved by Tylenol. The patient’s mother says that her symptoms started 5 days ago and have not improved. The rash started on her trunk and now is present everywhere including the palms and soles. Her birth history is normal. Her pulse is 120/min and respiratory rate is 22/min. On physical examination, the patient is agitated and ill-appearing. There is significant swelling of the distal upper and lower extremities bilaterally. The pharynx is hyperemic (see image). Generalized edema with non-palpable cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Muscle tone is normal. Remainder of exam is unremarkable. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Laboratory test
Hb 9 g/dL
RBC 3.3/mm3
Neutrophilic leukocytosis 28,000/mm3
Normal platelet count 200,000/mm3
Serum ɣ-GT increased
Hyperbilirubinemia 2.98 mg/dL
AST and ALT are normal, but there is markedly increased serum CRP.
output: Have you noticed any redness or swelling in your hands or feet?

instruction: I have a rash that started on my face a few weeks ago and spread to my whole body, including my palms and soles. What is your age and sex? I am a 2-month-old male.
input: A 2-month-old male with past medical history of delayed neurological development, deafness presents for evaluation of rash and history of suspected multiple fractures evaluated in the emergency room. Mother notes the rash started a few weeks ago on the face and then spread throughout the body onto the palms and soles. Physical examination reveals multiple thin scaly dark pink macules coalescing into patches on the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles. The patient does not move the right hand during the encounter.
output: Does your baby have a fever?

instruction: I've been having pain and stiffness in my fingers and knees for the past year. What is your age and sex? I'm a 59-year-old woman. Do you experience morning stiffness? If yes, how long does it last? Yes, the stiffness lasts for about 10 minutes after I wake up.
input: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of pain and stiffness in her fingers and knees. The stiffness lasts for about 10 minutes after she wakes up in the morning. She also reports that her knee pain is worse in the evening. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her only medication is acetaminophen. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers of both hands.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Osteoarthritis

instruction: I've been having painful sores in my mouth for the past 4 days. How old are you? I am 16 years old. Are you male or female? I am a boy.
input: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in his mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year at high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of his oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Do you have a fever or any other symptoms?

instruction: I've been waking up early in the morning feeling really pale and weak, with a high fever and I feel like I'm going to throw up really badly. What is the patient's age and sex? I'm a 5-year-old boy. Have these symptoms been persistent or do they come and go? They come and go; I've had five of these times where I get sick over the last 10 months. Has there been any rash or swelling during these episodes? No, there hasn't been any rash or swelling. How long does each episode last? Each time, it lasts for about a day. Does the child have any known medical conditions? No, I don't have any medical conditions.
input: A 5-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his mother, who relates a primary complaint of a recent history of five independent episodes of vomiting over the last 10 months, most recently 3 weeks ago. Each time, he has awoken early in the morning appearing pale, feverish, lethargic, and complaining of severe nausea. This is followed by 8-12 episodes of non-bilious vomiting over the next 24 hours. Between these episodes he returns to normal activity. He has no significant past medical history and takes no other medications. Review of systems is negative for changes in vision, gait disturbance, or blood in his stool. His family history is significant only for migraine headaches. Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. Initial complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and abdominal radiograph were unremarkable.
output: Does anyone in the family have similar symptoms?

instruction: I have a rash, my belly hurts sometimes, and my legs and arms are swollen. I also have pain in my knees and hands but I didn't get hurt. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 6-year-old girl. Do you have a fever? No, I don't have a fever.
input: A 6-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician with a rash and intermittent abdominal pain and swelling of her legs and arms. She has also begun to complain of pain in her knees and hands with no history of trauma. Her temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 100/80 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A as well as symmetric swelling in the joints of the upper extremities. Her abdomen is currently nontender and not painful. Laboratory studies are pending, and the results of a urinalysis are notable only for positive blood and protein in the urine.
output: Do you have any blood in your urine?

instruction: I'm experiencing pain in both my knees and severe pain over my right groin. My right leg also feels a bit shorter, is bent, turned inward, and I can't open it outward.
input: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: What is your age?

instruction: I've been having a high fever and trouble walking because of my sore leg for the past week. How old is the patient and what is their sex? I'm a 4-year-old boy. Has the child had any recent injuries to the leg? No, I haven't had any injuries to my leg. Does the leg show any swelling or redness? Yes, there is some swelling and redness around my right ankle. Has the child had any recent infections? I take an antibiotic every day and had to get extra vaccinations as a baby, but nothing recent has been mentioned. Does the child have any chronic medical conditions? I have something wrong with my blood.
input: A young Mediterranean teen brings her 4-year-old little brother to the Emergency Room because of a high temperature. Their parents are on their way to the hospital, but, in the meantime, she provides some of the history. She explains that he has been running a fever and limping for the past week. This morning, she had trouble awakening him, and she noticed some swelling and redness around his right ankle. In terms of his past medical history, she knows he has something wrong with his blood. He had to receive extra vaccinations as an infant, and he takes an antibiotic everyday. On exam in the ED, his temperature is 102.4 deg F (39.1 deg C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 123/min, and respirations are 22/min. He is lethargic, and his exam is noteworthy for erythema and edema in an area surrounding his distal shin.
output: Do you have any other symptoms like fatigue or bruising?

instruction: I'm breathing really fast, and my heart is beating quickly too. What is the patient's age? I'm a newborn baby.
input: A newborn born at 33 weeks of gestation has a respiratory rate of 70/min and a heart rate of 148/min 2 hours after birth. He is grunting and has intercostal and subcostal retractions. He has peripheral cyanosis as well. An immediate chest radiograph is taken which shows a fine reticular granulation with ground glass appearance on both lungs.
output: Is the patient male or female?

instruction: I've been experiencing chronic diarrhea almost every day for the past four months, lower abdominal discomfort and cramping that gets better after I have a bowel movement. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 31-year-old woman. Have you experienced any weight loss recently? No, I haven't noticed any change in my weight recently. Have you noticed any blood or mucus in your stool? There's mucus in my stool, but no blood. Are you currently taking any medications or supplements? The case vignette does not mention any medications or supplements that I am taking. Have you experienced any joint pain or skin rashes? No, I have not experienced any joint pain or skin rashes.
input:
A 31-year-old woman visits the clinic with chronic diarrhea on most days for the past four months. She also complains of lower abdominal discomfort and cramping, which is relieved by episodes of diarrhea. She denies any recent change in her weight. Bowel movements are preceded by a sensation of urgency, associated with mucus discharge, and followed by a feeling of incomplete evacuation. The patient went camping several months earlier, and another member of her camping party fell ill recently. Her temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 122/98 mm Hg. Her physical examination is unremarkable. A routine stool examination is within normal limits and blood test results show:
Hb%   13 gm/dL
Total count (WBC):   11,000/mm3
Differential count:    
  Neutrophils: 70%
  Lymphocytes: 25%
  Monocytes: 5%
ESR:   10 mm/hr
output: Do you have any family history of gastrointestinal disorders?

instruction: I've been having hip pain that my usual painkillers don't help with anymore. What is your age and sex? I am a 60-year-old man. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any regular medications? Yes, I have osteoarthritis in my hip and I've been taking high doses of painkillers for the pain. Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or changes in your urine? No, I haven't noticed any swelling or changes in my urine. Do you have any family history of kidney or urinary diseases? I'm sorry, but I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history. Do you have a history of high blood pressure? No, my blood pressure today was 110/70 mm Hg, which is within normal limits. Have you been experiencing this hip pain for a long time? Yes, I've been diagnosed with hip problems due to osteoarthritis for the past 5 years. Are you currently taking any over-the-counter pain medications? Yes, I have been taking high doses of painkillers for my hip pain. What type of painkillers are you taking? I'm sorry, but I didn't mention the specific type of painkillers I'm taking.
input:
А 60-уеаr-old Ніѕраnіс mаn рrеѕеntѕ to thе offісе for а rеgulаr hеаlth сhесkuр. Не hаѕ bееn wаіtіng for his hір rерlасеmеnt ѕurgеrу for osteoarthritis, whісh he was diagnosed for the past 5 уеаrѕ. Не admits to having taken high doses of painkillers for hip pain management, but now they don’t provide any pain relief. Ніѕ vіtаl ѕigns include: blood рrеѕѕurе 110/70 mm Нg, рulѕе 78/mіn, tеmреrаturе 36.7°C (98.1°F), and rеѕріrаtorу rаtе 10/mіn. Оn physical ехаmіnаtіon, thеrе іѕ а lіmіtеd rаngе of motіon of hіѕ rіght hір.
The laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 12 g/dL
Red blood cell 5.1 million cells/µL
Hematocrit 45%
Total leukocyte count 6,500 cells/µL
Neutrophils 71%
Lymphocyte 14%
Monocytes 4%
Eosinophil 11%
Basophils 0%
Platelets 240,000 cells/µL
Urinalysis shows:
pH 6.2
Color light yellow
RBC 7–8/ HPF
WBC 10-12 /HPF
Protein 1+
Cast none
Glucose absent
Crystal none
Ketone absent
Nitrite negative
24-hr urine protein excretion 0.9 g
Urine for culture No growth noted after 48 hours of inoculation at 37.0°C (98.6°F)
output: Have you had any back or flank pain?

instruction: I've been feeling fatigued for several months, but other than that, I have no complaints. How old are you and what is your gender? I am a 60-year-old man. Do you have any prior medical conditions? No, I don't have any history of serious illness. Have you experienced any weight loss or loss of appetite? No, I haven't experienced any weight loss or loss of appetite. Do you have any bone or joint pain? I take acetaminophen for knee pain, but no other bone or joint pain.
input:
A 60-year-old man presents to the physician for a follow-up examination. During the previous visit, splenomegaly was detected on the abdominal exam, which has been confirmed by abdominal ultrasound. He has no complaints other than fatigue for several months. There is no history of serious illness. His only medication is acetaminophen for knee pain. The temperature is 36.7℃ (98.1℉), pulse is 68, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, the spleen size on percussion is 16 cm (6.2 in). Otherwise, the physical examination shows no abnormalities. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 10 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 80,000/mm3
Platelet count 450,000/mm3
The peripheral blood smear shows a predominance of neutrophils and the presence of band cells, myelocytes, promyelocytes, and blasts (< 5%). The cytogenetic study shows t(9;22).
output: Do you have any family history of cancer or blood disorders?

instruction: I've got a red rash with small raised spots and some pus-filled bumps on my skin, mostly on my trunk and arms and legs, but not on the palms of my hands or the bottoms of my feet.
input: A 4-day-old newborn is presented to the physician because of a generalized rash for the past day. He was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. The vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 152/min, and respirations 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: How old are you?

instruction: I've got multiple spots on my face that I have had since I was a teenager, but I've noticed there seem to be more of them now. What is your age? I'm 65 years old. Are you male or female? I am male. Have you noticed any changes in the spots' size, shape, or color? They haven't really changed in size, shape, or color; there are just more of them now. Have you had significant sun exposure or frequent sunburns? I haven't been asked about my sun exposure or history of sunburns, so I'm not sure how to answer that. Have any of your family members have similar spots? Yes, there is a history in my family of having multiple renal cysts and episodes of lungs collapsing without an apparent cause.
input: A 65-year-old male presents to dermatology clinic for evaluation of multiple spots on the face present since adolescence but increasing in number. His past medical history is remarkable for multiple pulmonary cysts, spontaneous pneumothorax and renal cell carcinoma. He reports a positive family history of multiple renal cysts and recurrent pneumothorax. Physical examination reveals multiple light hypopigmented to skin colored dome shaped papules on the face and pedunculated hyperpigmented papules on the neck and axilla.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Birt-Hogg-Dubé Syndrome

instruction: I have a rash on my face and also some faint rash on my upper arms. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 7-year-old girl. Is the rash itchy? No, the rash isn't itchy. How long have you had the rash? The rash started three days ago.
input: A 7-year-old female presents for evaluation of facial rash that began three days ago. The patient's mother reports four days before the rash began, the patient had some fevers and thigh muscle aches. Mother notes many other children at the school have had a similar rash. On examination, on the bilateral cheeks are bright pink red lacy reticulated erythematous patches with sparing of the perioral and mesolabial fold with similar faint patches on the bilateral upper arms. No lesions are appreciated in oral mucosa. Patient is up to date with vaccinations.
output: Have you started using any new skincare products or medications?

instruction: I've been having severe lower back pain and feeling really tired for the past 3 months. What is your age and gender? I'm a 72-year-old man. Are you currently taking any medications or have any past medical conditions? I take ibuprofen for pain relief and I have no history of a serious illness. Have you experienced any weight loss or night sweats? No, I haven't experienced weight loss or night sweats. Have you noticed any changes in your urination? No, I haven't noticed any changes in my urination. Have you had any bone fractures or additional bone pain? No, I haven't had any bone fractures or additional bone pain.
input:
A 72-year-old man presents to the physician with severe lower back pain and fatigue for 3 months. The pain increases with activity. He has no history of a serious illness. He takes ibuprofen for pain relief. He does not smoke. The blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg, the pulse is 86/min, the respirations are 16/min, and the temperature is 36.7℃ (98.1℉). The conjunctivae are pale. Palpation over the 1st lumbar vertebra shows tenderness. The heart, lung, and abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. No lymphadenopathy is palpated. The results of the laboratory studies show:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 5,500/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 350,000/mm3
Serum
Calcium 11.5 mg/dL
Albumin 3.8 g/dL
Urea nitrogen 54 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL
Lumbosacral computed tomography (CT) scan shows a low-density lesion in the 1st lumbar vertebra and several similar lesions in the pelvic bones.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Multiple Myeloma

instruction: I have a painful sore on my right breast that has been growing bigger for the last 2 months, and there is also some fluid coming out of the nipple on that side.
input: A 34-year-old Ethiopian woman who recently moved to the United States presents for evaluation to a surgical outpatient clinic with painful ulceration in her right breast for the last 2 months. She is worried because the ulcer is increasing in size. On further questioning, she says that she also has a discharge from her right nipple. She had her 2nd child 4 months ago and was breastfeeding the baby until the pain started getting worse in the past few weeks, and is now unbearable. According to her health records from Africa, her physician prescribed antimicrobials multiple times with a diagnosis of mastitis, but she did not improve significantly. Her mother and aunt died of breast cancer at 60 and 58 years of age, respectively. On examination, the right breast is enlarged and firm, with thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and an ulcer measuring 3 × 3 cm. White-Gray nipple discharge is present. The breast is tender with axillary and cervical adenopathy. Mammography is ordered, which shows a mass with a large area of calcifications, parenchymal distortion, and extensive soft tissue and trabecular thickening in the affected breast. The patient subsequently undergoes core-needle and full-thickness skin punch biopsies. The pathology report states a clear dermal lymphatic invasion by tumor cells.
output: What is your age?

instruction: I have a cut on my scalp that isn't healing. What is your age and sex? I am a 69-year-old male.
input:
A 69-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for a general checkup. The patient works as a farmer and gardens in his spare time. The patient has a past medical history of poorly managed diabetes mellitus type II, and irritable bowel syndrome. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, insulin, fiber supplements, and a multivitamin. On physical exam you note an obese gentleman. Inspection of the patient's scalp reveals the finding in Figure A. The patient is sent home and instructed to keep a blood glucose journal and to return with it in three months.

Three months later, the patient returns with his glucose journal. In addition, he complains of a cut on his scalp that is not seeming to heal. The patient's glucose journal reveals an average blood glucose of 175 mg/dL. On inspection of the patient's scalp, you note the finding in Figure B.
output: How long has the cut been present without healing?

instruction: I have severe abdominal pain and cramping, and it's been hurting for the past 3 hours. What is your age and sex? I'm a 51-year-old man. Is the pain localized to one area or widespread? The pain starts in my abdomen but it also radiates to my back. Do you have any nausea or vomiting? Yes, I've vomited multiple times.
input:
A 51-year-old homeless man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and cramping for the past 3 hours. He endorses radiation to his back. He adds that he vomited multiple times. He admits having been hospitalized repeatedly for alcohol intoxication and abdominal pain. His temperature is 103.8° F (39.8° C), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. He refuses a physical examination due to severe pain. Blood work reveals the following:
Serum:    
  Albumin: 3.2 gm/dL
  Alkaline phosphatase: 150 U/L
  Alanine aminotransferase: 76 U/L
  Aspartate aminotransferase: 155 U/L
  Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase: 202 U/L
  Lipase: 800 U/L
output: Have you consumed any alcohol recently?

instruction: I've been experiencing shortness of breath, especially when I do any physical activity. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 60-year-old man. Do you have any history of heart or lung disease? No, I don't have any history of heart or lung disease. Do you smoke or have you ever smoked? The case vignette does not provide information about my smoking history.
input: A 60-year-old man presents to the office for shortness of breath. The shortness of breath started a year ago and is exacerbated by physical activity. He has been working in the glass manufacturing industry for 20 years. His vital signs include: heart rate 72/min, respiratory rate 30/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. On physical exam, there are diminished respiratory sounds on both sides. On the chest radiograph, interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate is found on both sides, and there is also an eggshell calcification of multiple adenopathies.
output: Are you taking any medications currently?

instruction: I've been feeling really restless and agitated, and I can't seem to sit still for more than a few minutes. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 25-year-old woman. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I was diagnosed with schizophrenia two weeks ago and started taking fluphenazine. Have you noticed any muscle stiffness or tremors? No, my main issue has been feeling restless and unable to stay put.
input: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because she has appeared increasingly agitated over the last week. She feels restless, has not been able to sleep well, and has been pacing around her house continuously in an attempt to relieve her symptoms. Two weeks ago, she was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treatment with fluphenazine was initiated. Today, physical examination is interrupted multiple times because she is unable to sit or stand still for more than a couple minutes.
output: Does moving around help relieve your feelings of restlessness?
