He had a negative cardiac workup in the ED and he was discharged with a 24-hour Holter monitor which was also negative. He has no history of any medical or psychiatric illnesses. The patient reports that since his initial ED visit, he has had several episodes of unprovoked palpitations associated with feelings of dread and lightheadedness though he cannot identify a particular trigger. Recently, he has begun sitting towards the back of the lecture halls so that he can “quickly escape and not make a scene” in case he gets an episode in class.
output: Have you experienced any recent stressful events?

instruction: I feel extremely sleepy and I can't respond to people talking to me. What is your age? I am 22 years old. Are you male or female? I am male. Have your symptoms been sudden or gradual? My symptoms have been sudden. Have you experienced any seizures or headaches? I haven't mentioned having any seizures or headaches. Are you taking any medications? I was given diphenhydramine and haloperidol at the hospital. Do you have any past medical history? I was treated once before for using multiple substances. Have you used any substances recently? I can't say for sure if I've used substances recently. Are you having a fever? Yes, I have a high fever of 104°F (40°C). Are you experiencing muscle stiffness or rigidity? Yes, my muscles are very rigid and I can't move my extremities freely.
input: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, he is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome

instruction: I've been feeling generally unwell, I have pain when I urinate, my vision is blurry, and I have a painful, itchy rash that started on my chest and face and spread to my hands and feet. Can you please tell me your age and gender? I am a 56-year-old woman. Have you experienced any joint pain or swelling? No, I haven't experienced any joint pain or swelling.
input: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. The rash began on her chest and face and spread to her limbs, palms, and soles. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions?

instruction: I've noticed some changes in my vision, like it's not as sharp as it used to be. How old are you? I'm 59 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am a male. Is your vision impairment in one eye or both eyes? It's in both eyes. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have high blood pressure, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis, and I'm taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen for my conditions.
input: A 59-year-old man presents to his ophthalmologist for an annual eye exam. The patient reports feeling well and has noticed some changes in his visual acuity. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis. He is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen. Family history is significant for glaucoma in his mother and father. His intraocular pressure is 17 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. The patient undergoes a slit-lamp examination and the findings are shown in Figure A.
output: When did you first notice the changes in your vision?

instruction: I've got some small, painless bumps on my tummy that don't itch. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 2-year-old girl. Have the bumps been increasing in number or size? The question about whether the bumps have been increasing in number or size isn't something I can answer based on the information given. Do you have any other symptoms besides the bumps? No, I don't have any other symptoms. Have you noticed any changes in the size or number of the bumps? There's no mention of any changes in the size or number of the bumps. When did the bumps first appear? The exact time the bumps appeared hasn't been specified. Do you have any past medical history or is she taking any medications? I've been previously healthy and am not on any medications.
input: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox one month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several skin-colored, nontender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Does anyone in the family have similar skin bumps?

instruction: I've got a painful, scaly skin rash that's itchy and burns, and also I've been experiencing some intermittent vomiting and diarrhea. What is your age and sex? I am a 42-year-old man. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions or are you taking any medications? No, I haven't been diagnosed with any conditions and I'm not taking any medications.
input: A man, aged 42 years, presents with a 6-month history of a painful, scaly skin rash. The eruption is symmetrically distributed over photosensitive areas, affecting his face, neck, upper back, forearms, and hands. The dorsal surfaces of his hands and forearms exhibit a dusky brown coloration over rough and cracked skin. He complains of itching and burning and reports intermittent vomiting and diarrhea. He admits to heavy alcohol intake for the last 2 decades and denies taking any medications. Neuropsychiatric evaluation reveals short-term memory loss, speech problems, and poor concentration.
output: Do your symptoms affect any specific part of your body?

instruction: I noticed a lump in my right groin area while I was bathing three days ago.
input: A previously healthy 64-year-old man comes to the physician 3 days after noticing a lump in his right groin while he was bathing. He has no history of trauma to the region. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension treated with atorvastatin and labetalol. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 4-cm (1.6-in), nontender, pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill at the right midinguinal point. On auscultation, a harsh continuous murmur is heard over the mass. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: How old are you and what is your sex?

instruction: I have a painful rash with small red spots that turned yellow and pus-filled on my right index finger. What is your age and gender? I'm a 21-year-old male. Have you recently injured your finger? No, I haven't injured my finger. Have you noticed any fever or feeling unwell? No, I haven't felt feverish or unwell. Have you recently been exposed to any chemicals or irritants? No, I haven't used any topical products or been exposed to any chemicals on the area. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? I have a history of cold sores on my lips.
input: A 21-year-old male presents for evaluation of a painful rash on his right index finger. He reports a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. He denies any trauma or topical products applied to the area. He has a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base.
output: Do you have any blisters or fluid-filled lesions?

instruction: I've noticed that my baby gets bruises easily and there are tiny red spots on his arms that don't go away when I press on them. How old is your baby and what is their sex? My baby is 1 week old, but I didn't mention the sex. What is the sex of your baby? The case vignette does not specify the sex of my baby.
input: A 1-week old child is brought into your office for a normal check-up when you notice bruising on his arm. The mother states the child was born at home and had a "natural birth". She also states that the child is eating and having yellow seedy stools 4-8 times per day. She took lamotrigine for her seizures, but she had regular check-ups and was told everything was normal. She does state that she has noticed that the child bruises easily. On exam, the vitals are normal, but the child has pin-point spots on his arms where he was held by the mother that do not disappear with pressure (Figure A). His PT and aPTT are elevated, but the bleeding time is normal.
output: Has your baby had any previous illnesses or is currently taking any medications?

instruction: I have this red, worm-like rash on the bottom of my left foot that has been slowly spreading. What is your age and sex? I'm a 21-year-old male. Have you noticed any itching or discomfort? Yes, it's been quite itchy.
input: A 21-year-old male presents to the urgent care clinic after returning from the beach seven days ago. About three days ago, he noticed a red worm like rash on the bottom of his left foot that has been progressively moving. He reports walking barefoot on the beach. Examination reveals a serpiginous red-yellow plaque extending from left plantar forefoot to the medial aspect of dorsal foot.
output: Have you recently walked barefoot in sandy or moist areas?

instruction: I've noticed some changes in my vision, like it's not as sharp as it used to be. How old are you? I'm 59 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am a male. Is your vision impairment in one eye or both eyes? It's in both eyes.
input: A 59-year-old man presents to his ophthalmologist for an annual eye exam. The patient reports feeling well and has noticed some changes in his visual acuity. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis. He is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen. Family history is significant for glaucoma in his mother and father. His intraocular pressure is 17 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. The patient undergoes a slit-lamp examination and the findings are shown in Figure A.
output: Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I have been having difficulty breathing and my skin is pale, especially my arms and legs. How old is the patient and what is their sex? I'm a newborn baby boy. Is the baby breathing rapidly or with any unusual sounds? Yes, I'm breathing fast and making a grunting noise. Was the baby born prematurely? Yes, I was born at 30 weeks.
input: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 1780-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 30 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.8C (98.2F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 64/min, and blood pressure is 61/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Examination shows pale extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Supplemental oxygen is administered. Ten minutes later, his pulse is 148/min and respirations are 66/min. Pulse oximetry on 60% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 90%.
output: Has the baby received any respiratory support or oxygen therapy?

instruction: I've been having an aggressive cough with lots of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum.
input: A 51-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of an aggressive cough with copious amounts of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum. She says she has had this cough for about 11 years with exacerbations similar to her presentation today. She also reports that her cough is worse in the morning. She was evaluated multiple times in the past because of recurrent bouts of bronchitis that have required treatment with antibiotics. She is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). Chest auscultation reveals crackles and wheezing over the right middle lobe and the rest of her physical examinations are normal. The chest X-ray shows irregular opacities in the right middle lobe and diffuse airway thickening.
output: Can you tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I feel extremely sleepy and I can't respond to people talking to me. What is your age? I am 22 years old.
input: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, he is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry.
output: Are you male or female?

instruction: I've been having headaches, feeling generally unwell, and a sharp pain on the right side of my head for four days. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 42-year-old man. Do you have any skin rashes or changes? Yes, I developed a rash over the area where I have the pain, on my right forehead. Do you have any blisters or vesicles on the rash? No, there are no blisters, just red, thin, raised patches. Have you experienced any numbness or tingling in the affected area? No, I haven't felt any numbness or tingling. Have you started taking any new medications recently? No, I haven't started any new medications.
input: A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history.
output: Have you any chronic medical conditions?

instruction: I've got some growths on my left arm that have been getting bigger over the past three months. What is your age and sex? I'm a 76-year-old woman. Do the growths itch or cause any pain? No, they don't itch or hurt at all. Are the growths pigmented or discolored? Yes, they're purple-blue.
input: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of lesions on her left arm. She first noticed them 3 months ago and they have grown larger since that time. She has not had any pain or pruritus in the area. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with mastectomy and radiation therapy 27 years ago. Since that time, she has had lymphedema of the left arm. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the left arm. There are four coalescing, firm, purple-blue nodules on the left lateral axillary region and swelling of the surrounding skin.
output: Have you been diagnosed with any other health conditions?

instruction: Oh, I'm not the one with symptoms; I delivered a baby girl who is having eye problems the doctors call chorioretinitis. How old is your baby? My baby is just newly born. Has there been any infection during the pregnancy? I didn't have much prenatal care or antenatal screening, so I'm not sure about any infections. Does your baby have any other symptoms? Yes, the doctors found that her head is larger than normal, and they also mentioned some issues in her brain with certain areas having abnormal spots and swelling after they did a special brain scan. Did the mother have any exposure to cats during pregnancy? Yes, I have multiple cats in my household.
input: A 26-year-old woman with poor prenatal care and minimal antenatal screening presents to the emergency department in labor. Shortly thereafter, she delivers a baby girl who subsequently demonstrates symptoms of chorioretinitis on examination. A series of postpartum screening questions is significant only for the presence of multiple cats in the mother’s household. The clinical team orders an enhanced MRI examination of the infant’s brain which reveals hydrocephalus, multiple punctate intracranial calcifications, and 2 sub-cortical ring-enhancing lesions.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Congenital Toxoplasmosis

instruction: I'm feeling confused, and this morning I had abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and I've vomited three times. Can you tell me your age and sex? I am a 44-year-old woman.
input:
A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion starting this morning. Her husband states that she initially complained of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fatigue after eating. She has vomited 3 times and progressively became more confused. Her past medical history is notable for morbid obesity, diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, a sleeve gastrectomy 1 month ago, and depression with multiple suicide attempts. Her temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 104/54 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Her physical exam is notable for generalized confusion. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 3.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 22 mg/dL
Glucose: 41 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
C-peptide level: normal
output: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I am not experiencing any symptoms today; I feel healthy. What is your age? I am an 18-month-old toddler. Are you male or female? I am a boy. Have you had any previous illnesses or taken any medications? No, I have not had any previous illnesses or taken any medications. Do any family members have a history of cancer or blood disorders? The case vignette doesn't provide any information on my family's medical history.
input:
An 18-month-old toddler is brought to a pediatric hematologist by his father. The boy was referred to this office for prolonged neutropenia. He has had several blood tests with an isolated low neutrophil count while hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet count is normal. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. Today his complete blood count (CBC) with differential shows:
Hemoglobin: 15.5 g/dL
Platelets: 300,000 mm3
Neutrophils: 20%
Bands: 2%
Lymphocytes: 40%
Monocytes: 15%
Today, he has a heart rate of 90/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, blood pressure of 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the child appears healthy and is within expected growth parameters for his age and sex. A bone marrow biopsy shows normal bone marrow with 95% cellularity and trilineage maturation. Flow cytometry is normal with no abnormal markers noted.
output: Have any recent blood tests been performed?

instruction: I've been having memory problems and trouble taking care of myself. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 65-year-old man.
input: A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a change in his behavior over the past few months. Initially, the patient was noted to be behaving inappropriately including using foul language and grabbing people unexpectedly. This has progressed to a worsening of his memory and trouble caring for himself. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 162/103 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an elderly man who laughs inappropriately at times and who is a poor historian. When he is engaged in conversation, he exhibits word finding difficulty and is rather inattentive.
output: How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?

instruction: I've lost my appetite, I'm not gaining weight properly, and have lost about 15 pounds in the last three months. How old are you? I am 16 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am a girl. Have you had any other symptoms? I haven't had my menstrual period in 3 months.
input: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned about her lack of appetite and poor weight gain. She has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. The patient states that she should try to lose more weight because she does not want to be overweight anymore. She maintains a diary of her daily calorie intake. Menarche was at the age of 13 years, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. She is on the high school track team. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She is at 50th percentile for height and below the 5th percentile for weight and BMI. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination shows fine hair over the trunk and extremities.
output: Are you intentionally restricting your food intake?

instruction: I've been experiencing increasing shortness of breath for the last 8 months and a dry cough for the last 6 months. How old are you? I am 75 years old. What is your sex? I am a man. Do you smoke or have you ever smoked? No, I have never smoked in my life. Do you have any other medical conditions? Yes, I have high blood pressure. Are you taking any medications? Yes, I'm taking lisinopril for my high blood pressure. When did you start taking lisinopril? I'm sorry, but I don't have that information.
input: A 75-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for increasing shortness of breath for the last 8 months. He also complains of a dry cough for the last 6 months. Initially, his shortness of breath occurs with exertion, but now he feels it at rest as well. He has no other complaints. He has a sedentary lifestyle and had a hip replacement surgery recently. The past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is taking lisinopril. The patient is a lifetime non-smoker. The blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, pulse rate is 85/min, and the temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F). Physical examination reveals fine inspiratory crackles and digital clubbing. A chest X-ray reveals peripheral reticular opacities associated with traction bronchiectasis predominantly at the lung bases. The pulmonary function test results reveal a decreased FEV1, a decreased FVC, and a preserved FEV1/FVC ratio. High-resolution CT scan of the chest is shown.
output: Are you short of breath when lying down?

instruction: I've been getting short of breath with moderate exertion and I have a slight cough that sometimes brings up a little bit of phlegm.
input: A 79-year-old man presents to the office due to shortness of breath with moderate exertion and a slightly productive cough. He has a medical history of 25 years of heavy smoking. His vitals include: heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 27/min, and blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg. The physical exam shows increased resonance to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and crackles at the lung base. Chest radiography shows signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. Spirometry shows a forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%, a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%.
output: How old are you and what is your sex?

instruction: I've been losing a lot of hair for the past 2 months, with clumps falling out when I shower and on my pillow.
input: A 20-year-old man presents with 2 months of hair loss. He says that approximately 8 months ago, he was involved in a motor vehicle accident which resulted in several fractures and a difficult recovery. He has noticed clumps of hair coming out in the shower and on his pillow. He denies scalp itch. He denies any recent infections or genital sores.
output: What is your age and gender?

instruction: I have been experiencing increasing pain and swelling in my right foot for the past 2 weeks. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 26-year-old woman.
input: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling in her right foot for the past 2 weeks. Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with her joints. The pain has not allowed her to continue training for an upcoming marathon. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is a model and has to regularly wear stilettos for fashion shows. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your foot?

instruction: I've had a fever and sore throat for 2 days, and this morning I started getting a rash on my face and neck that's spreading to my body. What is the age and sex of the patient? I am a 6-year-old girl. Are you taking any medications or have any past medical conditions? No, I'm not taking any medications and I don't have any past medical conditions. Have you noticed if the rash is itchy? No, I haven't mentioned it being itchy.
input: A 6-year-old girl is brought to a clinic with complaints of fever and sore throat for 2 days. This morning, she developed a rash on her face and neck which is progressing towards the trunk. The teachers in her school report that none of her classmates has similar symptoms. She has a normal birth history. On physical examination, the child looks healthy. The heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. An oropharyngeal examination reveals circumoral pallor with a red tongue, as shown in the photograph below. The chest and cardiac examinations are within normal limits. No hepatosplenomegaly is noted.
output: Does the rash feel rough or like sandpaper?

instruction: I currently have no complaints. How old are you? I am 55 years old. Do you have any family history of cancer? There is no mention of a family history of cancer in my case. Are you male or female? I am a male. Have you had any previous illnesses? I have high cholesterol and high blood pressure. Are you currently taking any medications? Yes, I'm taking rosuvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and aspirin. Have you had any recent blood tests? Yes, my last blood tests showed some abnormal results. Have you noticed any changes in your weight or appetite recently? There are no changes in weight or appetite mentioned in my case. Have you experienced any fatigue or weakness recently? There's no mention of fatigue or weakness in my case. Have which blood tests were abnormal? My white blood cells are high, my red blood cell count and hemoglobin levels are low.
input:
A 55-year-old man presents for a routine check-up. He currently has no complaints, and his last physical and laboratory studies were unremarkable. His past medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia, well managed with rosuvastatin, and hypertension, well managed with hydrochlorothiazide. His current medications also include aspirin. The patient is afebrile and his vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals some generalized lymphadenopathy. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
WBC 38,000/mm3
RBC 4.20 x 106/mm3
Hematocrit 27.3%
Hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL
Platelet count 355,000/mm3
A peripheral blood smear and differential shows 92% small normocytic lymphocytes.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

instruction: I have had light spots on my back for about a year. What is your age and sex? I am a 15-year-old man. Have the spots changed in size or color over time? The spots have slowly grown and new ones have appeared near the first ones.
input: A 15-year-old Black man presents with a 1-year history of light spots on his back. The rash has grown slowly, with several new lesions appearing near the first one. It is not itchy or painful. He has not tried any treatments for this condition. He has no relevant medical history and none of his family members have similar skin findings. On examination, there are several well-demarcated depigmented macules and patches on his lateral back.
output: Do the spots have any scales or flaking?

instruction: I've been feeling persistently sad and have had difficulty concentrating for the past 6 weeks, and I'm also having trouble sleeping. How old are you? I'm 38 years old. What is your sex? I am a man. Have you experienced any recent significant life changes or stressors? Yes, my girlfriend broke up with me 4 years ago, and I've been feeling down most of the time since then.
input: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating for the past 6 weeks. During this period, he has also had difficulty sleeping. He adds that he has been “feeling down” most of the time since his girlfriend broke up with him 4 years ago. Since then, he has only had a few periods of time when he did not feel that way, but none of these lasted for more than a month. He reports having no problems with appetite, weight, or energy. He does not use illicit drugs or alcohol. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I've been experiencing progressive hearing loss in both of my ears over the past year. How old are you? I am 78 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am a male. Have you noticed any ringing in your ears? No, I haven't experienced any ringing in my ears. **Are you currently taking any medications?** Yes, I take enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin.
input: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. He has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports to hear the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead.
output: Do you experience any dizziness or balance issues?

instruction: I've been having painful joints, and my right wrist and left ankle and knee feel stiff and sore. How old are you? I am 19 years old. Are you male or female? I am a male university student. Have you had any recent infections or sexually transmitted diseases? I haven't mentioned any recent infections or diseases, but I am sexually active with multiple partners. Do you have any symptoms like burning during urination? No, I don't have any burning during urination.
input:
A 19-year-old university student presents to the student clinic with painful joints. He states that over the past week his right wrist has become increasingly stiff. This morning he noticed pain and stiffness in his left ankle and left knee. The patient has celiac disease and takes a daily multivitamin. He says he is sexually active with multiple male and female partners. He smokes marijuana but denies intravenous drug abuse. He recently traveled to Uganda to volunteer at a clinic that specialized in treating patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). He also went on an extended hiking trip last week in New Hampshire. Physical exam reveals swelling of the right wrist and a warm, swollen, erythematous left knee. The left Achilles tendon is tender to palpation. There are also multiple vesicopustular lesions on the dorsum of the right hand. No penile discharge is appreciated. Arthrocentesis of the left knee is performed. Synovial fluid results are shown below:

Synovial fluid:
Appearance: Cloudy
Leukocyte count: 40,000/mm^3 with neutrophil predominance

Gram stain is negative. A synovial fluid culture is pending.
output: Have you experienced any eye redness or pain?

instruction: I have a rash on my face and also some faint rash on my upper arms. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 7-year-old girl. Is the rash itchy? No, the rash isn't itchy. How long have you had the rash? The rash started three days ago. Have you started using any new skincare products or medications? No, I haven't started using any new skincare products or medications.
input: A 7-year-old female presents for evaluation of facial rash that began three days ago. The patient's mother reports four days before the rash began, the patient had some fevers and thigh muscle aches. Mother notes many other children at the school have had a similar rash. On examination, on the bilateral cheeks are bright pink red lacy reticulated erythematous patches with sparing of the perioral and mesolabial fold with similar faint patches on the bilateral upper arms. No lesions are appreciated in oral mucosa. Patient is up to date with vaccinations.
output: Do you have any other symptoms, such as fever or sore throat?

instruction: I've had a fever and sore throat for 2 days, and this morning I started getting a rash on my face and neck that's spreading to my body. What is the age and sex of the patient? I am a 6-year-old girl. Are you taking any medications or have any past medical conditions? No, I'm not taking any medications and I don't have any past medical conditions.
input: A 6-year-old girl is brought to a clinic with complaints of fever and sore throat for 2 days. This morning, she developed a rash on her face and neck which is progressing towards the trunk. The teachers in her school report that none of her classmates has similar symptoms. She has a normal birth history. On physical examination, the child looks healthy. The heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. An oropharyngeal examination reveals circumoral pallor with a red tongue, as shown in the photograph below. The chest and cardiac examinations are within normal limits. No hepatosplenomegaly is noted.
output: Have you noticed if the rash is itchy?

instruction: I have a growing red patch on my right shoulder that started as a small red bump three days ago, and I've been feeling sick with on-and-off low fevers. What is your age and sex? I am a 12-year-old girl. Have you had any recent cuts or injuries to your shoulder? No, I haven't had any recent cuts or injuries to my shoulder. Is the red patch swollen or painful? The red patch is not painful or causing any symptoms. Have you been exposed to tick bites or spent time in wooded areas recently? I went camping about 11 days ago but I don't remember any insect bites.
input: A 12-year-old girl presents to the pediatric dermatologist with an expanding, but otherwise asymptomatic erythematous patch on her right shoulder, which she first noticed 3 days ago. The girl states the rash started as a small red bump but has gradually progressed to its current size. No similar lesions were observed elsewhere by her or her mother. She has felt ill and her mother has detected intermittent low-grade fevers. During the skin examination, a target-like erythematous patch, approximately 7 cm in diameter, was noted on the left shoulder (as shown in the image). Another notable finding was axillary lymphadenopathy. On further questioning it was revealed that the patient went camping with her grandfather approximately 11 days ago; however, she does not recall any insect bites or exposure to animals. The family has a pet cat living in their household.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Lyme disease

instruction: I'm having trouble breathing and I can see my chest pulling in between my ribs and below them when I breathe.
input: Five weeks after delivery, a 1350-g (3-lb 0-oz) male newborn has respiratory distress. He was born at 26 weeks' gestation. He required intubation and mechanical ventilation for a month following delivery and has been on noninvasive pressure ventilation for 5 days. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 148/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 60/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 40% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions. Scattered crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis.
output: How old is the patient and are they male or female?

instruction: I've been having severe, unbearable headaches and pain in both of my eyes. What is your age and sex? I am a 32-year-old woman.
input: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to severe, intractable headaches, and bilateral ocular pain. Her symptoms began approximately 2 weeks prior to presentation and have progressively worsened. She initially had right-sided headaches that were sharp, interfered with sleep, and were unresponsive to pain medications. The headache was around her right eye and cheek, and she noticed diplopia with right lateral gaze. Her symptoms were accompanied by fatigue, fever, and edema around the right eye. Approximately 2 days after these symptoms, she developed swelling around the left eye. Medical history is significant for a recent rhinosinusitis infection. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 133/72 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. On physical exam, there is ptosis, proptosis, chemosis, and periorbital swelling of both eyes. There is hyperesthesia in the bilateral ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. Fundoscopic exam demonstrates bilateral papilledema. There is mydriasis and eye muscle weakness in all directions.
output: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been feeling dizzy and like the floor is moving under me for the past 2 days. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 33-year-old man. Have you noticed any hearing loss or ringing in your ears? No, I haven't noticed any hearing loss or ringing in my ears.
input: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness. He states he has experienced a sustained sense of disequilibrium for the past 2 days. He feels that the floor is unstable/moving. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not have any other medical diagnoses. The patient is currently taking vitamin C as multiple family members are currently ill and he does not want to get sick. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a horizontal nystagmus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver does not provoke symptoms and examination of the patient’s cranial nerves is unremarkable.
output: Did the dizziness start suddenly or gradually?

instruction: I have really bad breath that's been going on for a long time, and lately I've been having trouble swallowing food. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 73-year-old man. Have you unintentionally lost weight recently? The case vignette does not provide that information.
input: A 73-year-old man presents with complaints of long standing halitosis. He has recently been having progressive difficulty with swallowing. In the last several weeks, he has also noticed a small amount of regurgitated food on his pillow in the morning. You obtain the radiographic study depicted in Figure A.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Zenker's diverticulum

instruction: I have a painless black spot growing on my left hand and arm, and I've been experiencing new shortness of breath.
input: A 14-year-old male with no pertinent past medical history presents with a painless growing black spot on his left hand and arm. States he thinks it may have occured after working with farm animals including pigs, sheep, and cattle on his parents farm. Parents states it began as a yellow pus spot that slowly enlargened and popped with yellow fluid exiting. Review of symptoms remarkable for new shortness of breath and otherwise negative. Examination revealed an edematous pink-brown violaceous plaques with central necrotic escharsand surrounding erythema on the left hand and arm. Punch biopsy is performed and demonstrates gram positive spore-forming rods.
output: Can you tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I'm not currently experiencing any symptoms; I'm here for a regular prenatal care visit. What is your age? I am 38 years old. Have you had any previous pregnancies? Yes, I have been pregnant three times before. Have you had any complications in your previous pregnancies? My other children were born before 37 weeks' gestation.
input: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal care visit. She used fertility enhancing treatment for her current pregnancy. Her other children were born before 37 weeks' gestation. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 28.4 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender, and no contractions are felt. Ultrasonography shows a cervical length of 22 mm and a fetal heart rate of 140/min.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I have a painless skin bump on my neck that has gotten darker over the last three months and sometimes it itches, and I've noticed a similar one on my lower back. What is your age and sex? I am a 68-year-old man. Have you had any personal or family history of skin cancer? I haven't mentioned anything about my personal or family history of skin cancer. Are you taking any medications or have other medical conditions? I haven't mentioned taking any medications or having other medical conditions. Does the bumps have irregular borders or multiple colors? The description provided doesn't specify anything about irregular borders or multiple colors. Have the bumps changed in size since they appeared? The bumps haven't changed in size since they appeared; just the color has become darker.
input: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless skin lesion on his neck. The lesion has gradually become darker in color. Sometimes it is itchy. He also noticed one similar lesion on his lower back. He is a retired gardener. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on his neck and a 0.6-cm hyperpigmented papule on his lower back, both of which have a greasy and wax-like appearance. A photograph of the neck is shown.
output: Are the bumps flat or raised?

instruction: I'm actually feeling okay; I'm here for a follow-up about something they found on my chest x-ray last week. Can you tell me your age and gender? I am a 56-year-old man.
input: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after a chest x-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule. He has no history of major medical illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.1-cm well-circumscribed, calcified nodule in the periphery of the right lower lung field. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen shows regions of disorganized hyaline cartilage interspersed with myxoid regions and clefts of ciliated epithelium.
output: Have you ever smoked or currently do you smoke?

instruction: I've been having intermittent pain on the sides of my lower back for about 5 months. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 31-year-old woman. Have you noticed any changes in your urination, such as pain or blood? I have had five urinary tract infections over the past 2 years. Have you noticed any blood in your urine? No, I haven't noticed any blood in my urine. Have you experienced any fever or chills? No, I haven't experienced any fever or chills. Do you feel any pain that spreads to your abdomen or groin? No, the pain does not spread to my abdomen or groin. Are you taking any medications? You have not provided me any information about taking medications, so I can't say if I am. Have you experienced any weight loss or fatigue? No, I haven't experienced any weight loss or fatigue. Have you ever had kidney stones? You didn't give me any information about having kidney stones, so I can't say if I have.
input: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of intermittent flank pain. Over the past 2 years, she has had five urinary tract infections. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral, nontender upper abdominal masses. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 29 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.4 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple parenchymal anechoic masses.
output: Do you have any family history of kidney disease?

instruction: I'm experiencing cramping pain in the lower left side of my abdomen, and it gets worse when I go to the bathroom. I've also been having mild constipation for the last few years. What is your age and sex? I am a 68-year-old woman. Have you noticed any blood in your stool? No, I haven't noticed any blood in my stool. Have you experienced any weight loss recently? No, I haven't had any recent weight change. Are you currently taking any medications? The case vignette does not mention any medications that I am taking. Do you have any history of gastrointestinal disorders? The case vignette does not provide any information about a history of gastrointestinal disorders. Have you experienced any fever or chills? Yes, I have a fever with a temperature of 37.8°C (100.0°F).
input:
A 68-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain that worsens with defecation. She describes the pain as 'crampy'. She also says she has suffered from mild constipation for the past few years. The patient denies any recent weight change or urinary symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 16 years ago. Her body temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 133/87 mm Hg. On physical examination, tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant is present. The laboratory studies are presented as follows:
Hemoglobin 13.2 mg/dL
Hematocrit 48%
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm³
Neutrophils 89%
Bands 5%
Eosinophils 0%
Basophils 0%
Lymphocytes 11%
Monocytes 0%
Platelet count 380,000/mm³
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Diverticulitis

instruction: I've been experiencing increasing shortness of breath for the last 8 months and a dry cough for the last 6 months.
input: A 75-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for increasing shortness of breath for the last 8 months. He also complains of a dry cough for the last 6 months. Initially, his shortness of breath occurs with exertion, but now he feels it at rest as well. He has no other complaints. He has a sedentary lifestyle and had a hip replacement surgery recently. The past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is taking lisinopril. The patient is a lifetime non-smoker. The blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, pulse rate is 85/min, and the temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F). Physical examination reveals fine inspiratory crackles and digital clubbing. A chest X-ray reveals peripheral reticular opacities associated with traction bronchiectasis predominantly at the lung bases. The pulmonary function test results reveal a decreased FEV1, a decreased FVC, and a preserved FEV1/FVC ratio. High-resolution CT scan of the chest is shown.
output: How old are you?

instruction: I've been feeling really tired for the past 5 months and I also have this numbness with a tingling sensation in my fingers and feet, sometimes I can't feel them at all. How old are you? I am 46 years old. What is your sex? I am a woman.
input:
A 46-year-old woman arrives at your clinic complaining of a 5-month history of fatigue and “numbness.” She describes a “tingling” sensation in her fingers and feet, and says sometimes she cannot feel them at all. She admits to being an IV heroin user with her last use being yesterday evening. The patient has also been homeless for three years. She reports that she was sexually assaulted at a shelter, so she is afraid to go back. Instead, she buys her own meals, when she can, with donations. The patient is currently sexually active with two male partners. She has never had testing for sexually transmitted diseases. The patient reports blurry vision, but admits she has not been to an eye doctor for over five years. She denies fever, headache, palpitations, night sweats, abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, or rashes. On exam, the patient appears emaciated. Neurologic examination shows a decreased vibratory sense and proprioception in the fingers and toes. Pupils are equally reactive to light and accommodation. The patient has mild difficulty rising from a chair without using her upper extremities to assist. A CBC is drawn, and results include:

Leukocyte count and differential:
Leukocyte count: 4,400/mm^3
Segmented neutrophils: 60%
Bands: 3%
Eosinophils: 2%
Basophils: < 1%
Lymphocytes: 26%
Monocytes: 7%
Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
Platelet count: 250,000/mm^3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration: 32%
Mean corpuscular volume: 123 µm^3
Reticulocyte count: .8%

A peripheral blood smear is drawn and shown in Figure A.
output: Do you have any past medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been having a recurring itchy rash on my face and scalp for the past three months. Can you please tell me your age and gender? I am a 28-year-old man. Do you have any history of eczema or allergies? I've never mentioned having eczema or allergies before. Are you currently using any new skincare products? Yes, I've been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. Have you noticed the rash worsening after using the shaving cream? I haven't explicitly stated that the rash gets worse after using the shaving cream. Have you noticed any scaling or redness in the rash? The rash has greasy yellow scales at the margins of my eyelids.
input: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Seborrheic dermatitis

instruction: I've been having muscle pains, not sleeping well, and feeling tired during the day. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 45-year-old woman. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I've had these symptoms since I last saw you one year ago. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? As a patient with the information provided, I haven't mentioned any other medical conditions or medications. Have you experienced any weight changes recently? No, I haven't mentioned any changes in my weight. Have you experienced any changes in your mood or mental health? Yes, I have been panicking about my job, marriage, children, and finances, and I worry severely.
input: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of muscle pains, poor sleep, and daytime fatigue. When asked about stressors she states that she "panics" about her job, marriage, children, and finances. When asked to clarify what the "panics" entail, she states that it involves severe worrying. She has had these symptoms since she last saw you one year ago.
output: Have you any family history of mental health conditions?

instruction: I've got a rash in the diaper area that's been there for about a month, and the skin around my mouth is peeling. My tongue also looks shiny. What is your age and gender? I am a 2-month-old male infant. Is the baby currently taking any medications? I was given some cream and a zinc oxide paste, but they didn't help.
input: A 2-month-old male infant presents with a rash in the diaper area. It has been present for the last month. He was seen by his pediatrician and was given topical triamcinolone as well as zinc oxide paste which did not help. His mom says that she was unable to make enough breastmilk and so has recently been feeding him from a new formula. Physical exam reveals erythematous erosions in the diaper area, as well as peri-oral scaling and a shiny tongue. There is no rash on the scalp.
output: Is the baby exclusively breastfed or formula-fed?

instruction: I have blisters on my forearm that popped up 3 days ago, and I've been feeling pain in my left cheek when I eat and discomfort during sexual intercourse for the past week. What's your age and sex? I'm a 50-year-old woman. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have high blood pressure and osteoarthritis, and I recently started taking captopril while I stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. Have you noticed any new exposures or products applied to your skin recently? I haven't been exposed to anything new, but I did start hiking in the woods with my son a few months ago, being careful to avoid poison ivy. Is the blisters on your forearm itchy or painful? The blisters on my forearm aren't itchy, but they do feel painful. Have you noticed any rash or lesions on your face? Yes, I have ulcers inside my mouth on my cheek and gums.
input: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blisters on her forearm that appeared 3 days ago. She also reports pain in her left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. She has not been sick for the past 6 months. She has started hiking in the woods on the weekends with her son a couple months ago but has been careful to avoid poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She recently started taking captopril and stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. She has a family history of pernicious anemia and Graves' disease. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. The total body surface area involvement of the blisters is estimated to be 10%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Have you noticed any sores or lesions in your genital area?

instruction: I've been having severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting for the last 5 days, and it hurts when I pee. What is your age and gender? I'm a 17-year-old girl. Are you experiencing increased frequency or urgency when urinating? It hurts when I pee, but I didn't say anything about going more often or feeling like I need to go in a hurry.
input: A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting. She also has pain with urination. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She experienced a burning pain when she last had sexual intercourse 3 days ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/h.
output: Have you had any fever or chills?

instruction: I've been increasingly confused, and I get headaches and feel sick to my stomach sometimes; I've also thrown up a few times.
input: A 72-year-old man is brought into clinic by his daughter for increasing confusion. The daughter states that over the past 2 weeks, she has noticed that the patient “seems to stare off into space.” She reports he has multiple episodes a day during which he will walk into a room and forget why. She is also worried about his balance. She endorses that he has had several falls, the worst being 3 weeks ago when he tripped on the sidewalk getting the mail. The patient denies loss of consciousness, pre-syncope, chest pain, palpitations, urinary incontinence, or bowel incontinence. He complains of headache but denies dizziness. He reports nausea and a few episodes of non-bloody emesis but denies abdominal pain, constipation, or diarrhea. The patient’s medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. He takes aspirin, warfarin, insulin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and ibuprofen. He drinks a half glass of whisky after dinner every night and smokes a cigar on the weekends. On physical examination, he is oriented to name and place but not to date. He is unable to spell "world" backward. When asked to remember 3 words, he recalls only 2. There are no motor or sensory deficits.
output: What is your age and gender?

instruction: I've been having this dull, aching pain in my right leg for two months, and it's gotten worse recently. What is your age and sex? I am a 14-year-old male. Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your leg? No, I can't think of any particular injury that might have caused the pain. Do you have any swelling or lumps in your leg? There's some mild swelling below my knee. Have you experienced any fever or weight loss? No, I have not had any fever or weight loss.
input: A 14-year-old previously healthy male presents to your office with complaints of two months of dull, aching pain in his right leg that has recently become worse. While he experiences the pain constantly, he notes that it is sometimes so bad at night that it awakes him from his sleep. Though an avid soccer player, he has been unable to participate this season due to the pain and difficulty running. He cannot think of any particular trauma that might have precipitated this pain. Vitals are all within normal range. Physical examination reveals localized tenderness below the knee with mild swelling and reduced range of motion. You order an X-ray of the painful limb, which is shown in Figure A.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Osteosarcoma

instruction: I have a cut on my scalp that isn't healing. What is your age and sex? I am a 69-year-old male. How long has the cut been present without healing? It has been present for at least three months.
input:
A 69-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for a general checkup. The patient works as a farmer and gardens in his spare time. The patient has a past medical history of poorly managed diabetes mellitus type II, and irritable bowel syndrome. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, insulin, fiber supplements, and a multivitamin. On physical exam you note an obese gentleman. Inspection of the patient's scalp reveals the finding in Figure A. The patient is sent home and instructed to keep a blood glucose journal and to return with it in three months.

Three months later, the patient returns with his glucose journal. In addition, he complains of a cut on his scalp that is not seeming to heal. The patient's glucose journal reveals an average blood glucose of 175 mg/dL. On inspection of the patient's scalp, you note the finding in Figure B.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I have a large sore on my right lower leg that hasn't healed for 6 months, and my legs have been swollen for over 10 years. What is your age and sex? I am a 57-year-old man. Do you have any chronic medical conditions? No, I don't have any chronic medical conditions besides the swelling in my legs. Is the sore painful? The vignette doesn't specify if the sore is painful, so I can’t say for sure.
input: A 57-year-old man presents with a large wound on his right lower leg that has been present for 6 months as shown in the picture. He has had chronically swollen legs for over 10 years. His mother and brother had similar problems with their legs. He had a documented deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the affected leg 5 years earlier, but has no other past medical history. He has a blood pressure of 126/84 and heart rate of 62/min.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Venous ulcer secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.

instruction: I've been experiencing shortness of breath, especially when I do any physical activity. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 60-year-old man. Do you have any history of heart or lung disease? No, I don't have any history of heart or lung disease. Do you smoke or have you ever smoked? The case vignette does not provide information about my smoking history. Are you taking any medications currently? The case vignette does not mention any medications that I'm taking. Have any of your family members had heart or lung diseases? The case vignette does not provide information about my family's medical history. I'm unable to make a diagnosis without further information. Could you please provide more details? I have been working in the glass manufacturing industry for 20 years, and during my recent doctor's visit, it was noted that my breathing sounds are quite reduced. Also, my chest x-ray showed some scarring and unusual patterns in my lungs and some calcium deposits in multiple areas of my lymph nodes.
input: A 60-year-old man presents to the office for shortness of breath. The shortness of breath started a year ago and is exacerbated by physical activity. He has been working in the glass manufacturing industry for 20 years. His vital signs include: heart rate 72/min, respiratory rate 30/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. On physical exam, there are diminished respiratory sounds on both sides. On the chest radiograph, interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate is found on both sides, and there is also an eggshell calcification of multiple adenopathies.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Silicosis

instruction: I've been looking pale and feeling really tired lately. How old are you? I am 5 years old. Are you male or female? I am a girl.
input: A 5-year-old girl presents for a routine checkup. The patient’s parents say she has been looking pale and tired lately. Her family history is unremarkable. Upon physical examination, several bruises are seen, as well as petechial bleeding on her limbs. A complete blood count shows leukocytosis with severe anemia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows 35% blasts. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows hepatosplenomegaly and a chest radiograph reveals a mediastinal mass.
output: Have you had any fever or infections recently?

instruction: I have a rash that started on my face a few weeks ago and spread to my whole body, including my palms and soles. What is your age and sex? I am a 2-month-old male. Does your baby have a fever? No, I haven't mentioned having a fever. Is the rash itchy? I haven't said if the rash is itchy or not.
input: A 2-month-old male with past medical history of delayed neurological development, deafness presents for evaluation of rash and history of suspected multiple fractures evaluated in the emergency room. Mother notes the rash started a few weeks ago on the face and then spread throughout the body onto the palms and soles. Physical examination reveals multiple thin scaly dark pink macules coalescing into patches on the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles. The patient does not move the right hand during the encounter.
output: Has anyone in the family have a history of skin conditions?

instruction: I've been experiencing intermittent pain and swelling in both my knees and my right ankle and wrist for 3 months. What is your age and sex? I'm a 4-year-old girl. Do you have any morning stiffness in your joints? Yes, my joints feel "stuck" and hard to move when I wake up, but they start to move after a few minutes. Have you had any fever or rash recently? No, I haven't had any fever or rash. Do you have any eye redness or pain? I have occasional mild eye pain, but it goes away by itself.
input:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel ""stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago she was diagnosed with upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.6 g/dl
Leukocyte count 8,000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 76%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 360,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 36 mm/hr
Serum
Antinuclear antibodies 1:320
Rheumatoid factor negative
output: Have any of your family members have arthritis or similar conditions?

instruction: I've been experiencing increasing smooth, round spots where I'm losing hair on my scalp, and these spots are itchy and sometimes feel like they're burning.
input: A 28-year-old man is referred to the dermatologist for 2 months of increasing appearance of multiple smooth, circular patches of complete hair loss on his scalp. He says that the patches have associated pruritus and a burning sensation, and are not improving with the over-the-counter products recommended by his hair stylist. He denies pulling his hair intentionally. Physical examination reveals no epidermal inflammation or erythema, and no fluorescence is detected under Wood’s lamp. A punch biopsy shows a peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles, resembling a swarm of bees.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I've noticed some changes in my vision, like it's not as sharp as it used to be. How old are you? I'm 59 years old.
input: A 59-year-old man presents to his ophthalmologist for an annual eye exam. The patient reports feeling well and has noticed some changes in his visual acuity. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis. He is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen. Family history is significant for glaucoma in his mother and father. His intraocular pressure is 17 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. The patient undergoes a slit-lamp examination and the findings are shown in Figure A.
output: Do you identify as male or female?

instruction: I've been having this tender spot on my left ear that comes and goes, and it's been like that for about six months now. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 60-year-old female. Has the spot changed in size or color? No, it hasn't changed in size or color. Have you had any recent injury or trauma to your ear? No, I haven't had any injury or trauma to my ear. Do you notice any itching or discharge from the spot? No, there's no itching or discharge. Do you have any chronic medical conditions or take any regular medications? I haven't mentioned any chronic medical conditions or regular medications. Is the tender spot located on the outer part of your ear or the earlobe? It's on the outer part, along the top edge of my ear.
input: A 60-year-old female presents with an intermittently tender spot on the left ear present for six months. She denies any trauma to the area but notes she often lays on the left side when sleeping at night. She denies any history of skin cancer. Examination reveals a crusted light pink papule along the left superior helix along the cartilaginous component. A biopsy is performed and reveals an ulcer with underlying dermal fibrosis with adjacent granulation tissue.
output: Does the spot feel raised or is it flat?

instruction: My skin is really saggy, especially on my cheeks, neck, underarms, and thighs. What is your age and gender? I'm a 6-year-old boy. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? I have a medical condition where my aortic root is dilated.
input: A 6-year-old male with past medical history of aortic root dilation presents for evaluation of loose skin that was noticed at birth but has progressively worsened. Family members have noticed the patient's skin is saggy but thought it may be related to overeating. The patient's mother reports other family members may have similar skin. Physical examination reveals loose, sagging skin of the cheeks, neck, axilla, thighs. A punch biopsy demonstrates loss of elastic fibers. Arm span width to body height ratio is within normal limits.
output: Do any family members have similar skin or heart conditions?

instruction: I've got a painful, scaly skin rash that's itchy and burns, and also I've been experiencing some intermittent vomiting and diarrhea.
input: A man, aged 42 years, presents with a 6-month history of a painful, scaly skin rash. The eruption is symmetrically distributed over photosensitive areas, affecting his face, neck, upper back, forearms, and hands. The dorsal surfaces of his hands and forearms exhibit a dusky brown coloration over rough and cracked skin. He complains of itching and burning and reports intermittent vomiting and diarrhea. He admits to heavy alcohol intake for the last 2 decades and denies taking any medications. Neuropsychiatric evaluation reveals short-term memory loss, speech problems, and poor concentration.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I'm actually feeling okay; I'm here for a follow-up about something they found on my chest x-ray last week. Can you tell me your age and gender? I am a 56-year-old man. Have you ever smoked or currently do you smoke? Yes, I have smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Do you have any cough, weight loss, or shortness of breath? No, I don't have any of those symptoms. Are you taking any medications or have any other medical conditions? No, I don't have a history of major medical illness and I'm not on any medications. Do you have any family history of cancer or other major illnesses? I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history. Do you know what was found on your chest x-ray? They told me it showed a solitary nodule in my lung. How large is the nodule? The nodule is 2.1 centimeters. Has a biopsy been performed on the nodule? Yes, a biopsy of the nodule was performed.
input: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after a chest x-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule. He has no history of major medical illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.1-cm well-circumscribed, calcified nodule in the periphery of the right lower lung field. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen shows regions of disorganized hyaline cartilage interspersed with myxoid regions and clefts of ciliated epithelium.
output: What did the biopsy show?

instruction: I've been experiencing tender bumps on my shins for the last three months. Are you male or female, and how old are you? I'm a 45-year-old woman.
input: A 45-year-old woman presents with 3 months of tender bumps on the shins. She says that 4 months ago, she was hospitalized for abdominal pain and was found to be positive for hepatitis B. She denies ever having tuberculosis. She denies itching or scratching at the bumps. She denies any rash on the trunk or extremities.
output: Have you started any new medications or have any existing medical conditions?

instruction: I've been feeling dizzy and like the floor is moving under me for the past 2 days. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 33-year-old man. Have you noticed any hearing loss or ringing in your ears? No, I haven't noticed any hearing loss or ringing in my ears. Did the dizziness start suddenly or gradually? The dizziness has been sustained for the past 2 days. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? I'm otherwise healthy and the only thing I'm taking is vitamin C. Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting? No, I haven't experienced any nausea or vomiting.
input: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness. He states he has experienced a sustained sense of disequilibrium for the past 2 days. He feels that the floor is unstable/moving. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not have any other medical diagnoses. The patient is currently taking vitamin C as multiple family members are currently ill and he does not want to get sick. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a horizontal nystagmus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver does not provoke symptoms and examination of the patient’s cranial nerves is unremarkable.
output: Have you experienced any headaches or other neurological symptoms?

instruction: I've been feeling more short of breath when I exert myself and dizzy for the past 8 weeks. What is your age? I am 81 years old. What is your sex? I am a man. Do you have any history of heart disease or high blood pressure? I have high blood pressure and I take medication for it. Have you noticed any swelling in your legs? The information about swelling in my legs was not mentioned; I only know about my shortness of breath and dizziness. Are you experiencing any chest pain? No, I haven't mentioned any chest pain.
input: An 81-year-old man comes to the physician because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown.
output: Are you experiencing any palpitations?

instruction: I have a painful lump on my neck and the skin over it is red. What is your age and sex? I'm a 15-year-old girl. Have you noticed any fever or other symptoms? No, I haven't noticed having a fever. How long have you had the lump? I've had the neck mass for many years.
input: A 15-year-old female presents to your office for evaluation of a painful neck mass. The family reports the patient has had a midline neck mass for many years, but had become painful over the past week with erythema at the overlying skin. The patient denies subjective fevers at home. The patient has an otherwise unremarkable past medical history. Her temperature is 100.1 deg F (37.8 deg C), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 15/min. Clinical exam is seen in Figure A. The mass is noted to rise with deglutition and tongue protrusion.
output: Has the lump changed in size recently?

instruction: I've been experiencing discharge from my left nipple for the past 3 months, and the amount seems to be increasing. What is your age? I am 52 years old. What is your sex? I am a woman. Is the nipple discharge bloody? No, the discharge looks gray-greenish.
input: A 52-year-old woman visits your office complaining about discharge from her left nipple for the past 3 months. The discharge looks like gray greenish and its amount is progressively increasing. She appears to be anxious and extremely uncomfortable with this situation as it is embarrassing for her when it occurs outdoors. Past medical history is insignificant. Her family history is negative for breast and ovarian disorders. She tries to stay active by running for 30 minutes every day on a treadmill, staying away from smoking, and by eating a balanced diet. She drinks alcohol occasionally. During physical examination you find a firm, stable mass under an inverted nipple in her left breast; while on the right breast, dilated subareolar ducts can be noted. There is no lymphadenopathy and remaining of the physical exam is normal. A mammogram is performed which reveals tubular calcifications.
output: Do you have any pain or tenderness in your breasts?

instruction: I have a painful skin sore on my right leg that's been growing for a month. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 54-year-old woman. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have Crohn's disease, type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and I'm taking insulin, mesalamine, enalapril, and aspirin.
input: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a painful skin lesion on her right leg for 1 month. It initially started out as a small red spot but has rapidly increased in size during this period. She remembers an ant bite on her leg prior to the lesion occurring. She was treated for anterior uveitis 8 months ago with corticosteroids. She has Crohn's disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension.
