Current medications include insulin, mesalamine, enalapril, and aspirin. She returned from Wisconsin after visiting her son 2 months ago. Her temperature is 37.6°C (98°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 126/88 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting pedal edema of the lower extremities. There is a 4-cm tender ulcerative lesion on the anterior right leg with a central necrotic base and purplish irregular borders. There are dilated tortuous veins in both lower legs. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpated bilaterally.
output: Is there any discharge or drainage from the sore?

instruction: I feel extremely sleepy and I can't respond to people talking to me. What is your age? I am 22 years old. Are you male or female? I am male. Have your symptoms been sudden or gradual? My symptoms have been sudden. Have you experienced any seizures or headaches? I haven't mentioned having any seizures or headaches. Are you taking any medications? I was given diphenhydramine and haloperidol at the hospital. Do you have any past medical history? I was treated once before for using multiple substances.
input: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, he is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry.
output: Have you used any substances recently?

instruction: I've been having abdominal discomfort and pain on my right side for several months, and lately, I've noticed blood in my urine.
input: A 53-year-old male presents to your office for abdominal discomfort. The patient states he first noticed pain on his right flank several months ago, and it has been gradually getting worse. For the past week, he has also noticed blood in his urine. Prior to this episode, he has been healthy and does not take any medications. The patient denies fever, chills, and dysuria. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are T 37 C, HR 140/90 mmHg, HR 84/min, RR 14/min, O2 98%. Physical exam is unremarkable. CBC reveals a hemoglobin of 17 and hematocrit of 51%, and urinalysis is positive for red blood cells, negative for leukocytes.
output: Can you please tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I have a spot on my left upper back that has been getting larger over the years, and sometimes it gets itchy, especially when it rubs against my bra.
input: A 68-year-old female presents to dermatology for a slowly enlargening lesion on the left uppper back. She denies any personal or family history of skin cancer. She lesion has been present for several years and slowly enlargening. Sometimes it gets irritated and itchy against her bra. She denies any pain or spontaneous bleeding. On examination of the left upper back is a flat topped stuck on appearing thin browh hyperkeratotic papule with milial-like cysts on dermoscopy.
output: Can you tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I had a seizure that lasted for 2 minutes and I felt really tired and out of it for about 10 minutes afterward.
input: A 16-year-old boy presents after suffering a tonic-clonic seizure. He says it had a duration of 2 minutes and a postictal period of 10 minutes. Patient denies any similar episodes in the past. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for his mother and older brother who died of colorectal cancer at ages 40 and 20, respectively. On physical examination, the patient is drowsy but arousable and responsive to commands. Both pupils are symmetrical and responsive to light. An MRI of the brain reveals an infratentorial hypointense cerebellar mass with a small cystic area.
output: What is your age and gender?

instruction: I've been having watery diarrhea for the last 3 weeks, with over 10 bowel movements per day.
input: A 54-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician complaining of watery diarrhea for the last 3 weeks. She reports now having over 10 bowel movements per day. She denies abdominal pain or rash. A basic metabolic profile is notable for the following: Na: 127 mEq/L; K 2.1 mEq/L; Glucose 98 mg/dL. Following additional work-up, octreotide was started with significant improvement in symptoms and laboratory values.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I have pain in my right hip that started this afternoon and I've been limping since the pain began. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 6-year-old boy. Do you have a fever? My temperature is a little high at 37.5°C (99.6°F).
input: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8,500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasound of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities.
output: Have you had any recent injuries or falls?

instruction: I have a rash and swelling of the hands and feet.
input: A 7-month-old female presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a rash and swelling of the hands and feet. Patient's mother reports the patient developed high fevers up to 103 Farenheit over the past six days, rough skin on the chest, back, arms and swelling in the hands and feet. Mother denies any recent travel or any medication exposures. Review of systems is positive for conjunctival injection. Physical examination is remarkable for palpable cervical lymph nodes, multiple prominent tongue papillae, diffuse background erythematous patches across the chest, back, and arms. Swelling of the hands and feet is appreciated.
output: What is your age?

instruction: I've been dealing with a facial rash on both cheeks and across my nose for about 10 years, and it gets worse when I'm out in the sun. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 58-year-old man. Have you experienced any eye irritation or dryness along with the rash? No, I haven't had any eye irritation or dryness. Do you have any pimples or visible blood vessels with the rash? Yes, I have some visible blood vessels on my eyelids. Have you noticed any scaling or dryness with the rash? No, I haven't noticed any scaling or dryness.
input: A 58-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of a facial rash. He states that he has had the rash for at least 10 years. The rash is on both cheeks and spreads across his nose. It normally comes and goes, but is exacerbated by sun exposure. The patient was recently fired, and is embarrassed of his rash, which has prevented him from accepting job interviews. He has tried various over the counter lotions and soaps with little improvement. He has no other complaints. His medical history is significant for mild osteoarthritis and coronary artery disease. He takes aspirin, simvastatin, and ibuprofen. On physical examination, you note telangiectasias on his bilateral eyelids. The rash is shown in Figure A.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Rosacea

instruction: I used to be able to ride a tricycle, stack blocks, and talk in short sentences, but now I can't feed myself and I point to things instead of asking for them. What is the patient's age? I am 4 years old.
input: A 4-year-old girl is seen by her pediatrician for developmental delay. One year prior, the patient was able to ride a tricycle, stack 3 blocks, and speak in short sentences. Now, she is unable to feed herself and has recently started to point to objects she wants rather than asking. Physical exam reveals a well nourished child sitting in a stroller wringing her hands. Vital signs are normal. The patient's mother reports that her 7-year-old son is doing well, and that they have no family history of mental retardation or other cognitive disorders.
output: Has the child had any recent illnesses or infections?

instruction: I've been noticing red urine three times in the past week and I've been experiencing recurrent headaches and sometimes my vision gets blurry for the past month. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 63-year-old man. Do you have a history of high blood pressure? My blood pressure was high at 152/95 mm Hg when it was last checked. Are you taking any medications, such as blood thinners? I'm currently taking tamsulosin for my prostate. Have you ever smoked or currently smoke? Yes, I have smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. Have you experienced any pain during urination? No, I haven't experienced any pain during urination. Have you experienced any weight loss or night sweats recently? No, I haven't experienced any weight loss or night sweats. Do you have any family history of kidney or bladder cancer? I'm sorry, but the provided information does not include any details about my family history.
input:
An obese 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of 3 episodes of red urine over the past week. He has also had recurrent headaches and intermittent blurry vision during the past month. He has benign prostatic hyperplasia. He works as an attendant at a gas station. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include tamsulosin. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 152/95 mm Hg. Examination shows a flushed face. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Digital rectal examination shows an enlarged prostate with no nodules. Urinalysis shows:
Blood 3+
Glucose negative
Protein negative
WBC 1-2/hpf
RBC 40-45/hpf
RBC casts none
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Renal cell carcinoma

instruction: I've been having severe lower abdominal pain for several hours, fevers, feeling generally unwell, and nausea for the last 2 days. What is your age and sex? I am 23 years old and female.
input: A 23-year-old gravida 1-para-1 (G1P1) presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started several hours ago. She has had fevers, malaise, and nausea for the last 2 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her past medical history is insignificant. She has had 3 sexual partners in the past 1 month and uses oral contraception. The vital signs include temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Uterine and adnexal tenderness is also elicited. A urine test is negative for pregnancy. On speculum examination, the cervix is inflamed with motion tenderness and a yellow-white purulent discharge.
output: Have you missed a period or think you might be pregnant?

instruction: I've been having mild pelvic discomfort and a yellowish, kind of foamy discharge from down there for the past two weeks. How old are you? I am 24 years old. Have you been sexually active recently? Yes, I have been sexually active.
input: A 24-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist complaining of mild pelvic discomfort and a frothy, yellowish discharge from her vagina for the past 2 weeks. She also complains of pain during sexual intercourse and sometimes after urination. Her past medical history is noncontributory. She takes oral contraceptives and a multivitamin daily. She has had two male sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Today, her vitals are normal. On pelvic exam, she has vulvovaginal erythema and a 'strawberry cervix' that is tender to motion, with minimal green-yellow malodorous discharge. A swab of the vaginal wall is analyzed for pH at bedside. Vaginal pH is 5.8.
output: Do you have any itching or burning sensation?

instruction: I have these light-colored spots on my face and arms that my parents noticed recently. How old are you and what is your gender? I am a 5-year-old boy. Are the spots itchy or scaly? No, they're not itchy or scaly.
input: A 5-year-old male with a past medical history of well-controlled eczema presents with light colored patches on the face and forearms noticed by the patient's parents a few days ago. Parents deny any trauma to the sites or any new topical products. Patient denies any pruritus or pain at the affected areas. Examination of the face reveals poorly demarcated ovoid hypopigmented patches on the cheeks and forearms.
output: Do you have a history of eczema or dry skin?

instruction: I was feeling very agitated and I had trouble organizing my thoughts when speaking. Can you tell me your age and gender? I am a 55-year-old male. Are you currently taking any medications? They gave me diazepam and chlorpromazine. Do you have any past medical conditions? No, my medical history is normal.
input: A 55-year-old male was picked up by police in the public library for harassing the patrons and for public nudity. He displayed disorganized speech and believed that the books were the only way to his salvation. Identification was found on the man and his sister was called to provide more information. She described that he recently lost his house and got divorced within the same week although he seemed fine three days ago. The man was sedated with diazepam and chlorpromazine because he was very agitated. His labs returned normal and within three days, he appeared normal, had no recollection of the past several days, and discussed in detail how stressful the past two weeks of his life were. He was discharged the next day.
output: Have your symptoms been getting better or worse?

instruction: I've been having left shoulder pain for the last two months, especially when I move my arm to its limits, and it's hard to sleep on that side. What is your age and sex? I am a 55-year-old woman. Have you experienced any injuries or trauma to your shoulder recently? No, I haven't had any shoulder injuries or trauma. Do you experience morning stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes? The vignette doesn't mention anything about morning stiffness, so I can't say if I experience that. Have you noticed any swelling or redness around the shoulder? No, I haven't noticed any swelling or redness around my shoulder. Do you have difficulty moving your shoulder even when someone else moves it for you? Yes, I have a hard time moving my shoulder even when someone else tries to move it for me. Do you have any other medical conditions, such as diabetes? Yes, I have type 2 diabetes.
input: A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with a 2-month history of insidious onset of left shoulder pain. It only occurs at the extremes of her range of motion and has made it difficult to sleep on the affected side. She has noticed increasing difficulty with activities of daily living, including brushing her hair and putting on or taking off her blouse and bra. She denies a history of shoulder trauma, neck pain, arm/hand weakness, numbness, or paresthesias. Her medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin and glipizide. Her physical examination reveals a marked decrease in both active and passive range of motion of the left shoulder, with forwarding flexion to 75°, abduction to 75°, external rotation to 45°, and internal rotation to 15° with significant pain. Rotator cuff strength is normal. AP, scapular Y, and axillary plain film radiographs are reported as normal.
output: Do you have a gradual loss of both active and passive range of motion in your shoulder?

instruction: I woke up yesterday with a painful, warm, soft lump on my left eyelid, and it's all swollen now.
input: A 7-year-old girl comes in to the emergency department with her mother for swelling of her left periorbital region. Yesterday morning she woke up with a painful, warm, soft lump on her left eyelid. Eye movement does not worsen the pain. Physical examination shows redness and swelling of the upper left eyelid, involving the hair follicles. Upon palpation, the swelling drains purulent fluid.
output: How old are you?

instruction: I've been getting short of breath with moderate exertion and I have a slight cough that sometimes brings up a little bit of phlegm. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 79-year-old man.
input: A 79-year-old man presents to the office due to shortness of breath with moderate exertion and a slightly productive cough. He has a medical history of 25 years of heavy smoking. His vitals include: heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 27/min, and blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg. The physical exam shows increased resonance to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and crackles at the lung base. Chest radiography shows signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. Spirometry shows a forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%, a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%.
output: Do you have any history of heart disease or high blood pressure?

instruction: I'm experiencing painful skin lesions. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 55-year-old man. Where on your body are the lesions located? The case vignette does not specify the exact location of the lesions on my body. How long have you had the lesions? I've had similar lesions for the past several months. Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions? Yes, I have diabetes, and I've had a middle ear infection and urinary tract infection in the past. Are you currently taking any medications? The case vignette does not provide information about my current medications. Do you have any family history of skin conditions? The case vignette doesn't mention any family history of skin conditions. Have you noticed any changes in the size or appearance of the lesions? They have worsened recently. Are the lesions ulcerated or blistering? Yes, they separate and break open with minimal pressure.
input: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with painful skin lesions. The patient has had similar lesions for the past several months but states they have worsened recently. He has a past medical history of diabetes, a middle ear infection, and urinary tract infection, which were treated with antibiotics. The patient has allergies to latex and sulfa drugs. He works as a mountain ranger and regularly hikes through forestry. His temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 167/108 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates the lesions seen in Figure A which separate and break open when minimal pressure is applied. Oral mucosal erosions are also seen upon inspection of the oropharynx.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Pemphigus vulgaris

instruction: I've been having a hard time focusing and paying attention, and I get angry really easily, especially at school. How old are you? I am 15 years old. What is your sex? I'm a boy. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications. Have you experienced any significant changes or stressful events recently? Yes, I've gotten into trouble for setting a fire at my school and for stealing a car. Have you experienced any problems at home or with your family? Well, my parents are upset with me because I killed our cat. Have any family members been diagnosed with mental health conditions? My mother has been diagnosed with schizophrenia for the past 10 years. Are you experiencing any hallucinations or delusions? No, I'm not experiencing hallucinations or delusions.
input: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of his “weird” behavior. The parents report that their son tortured their cat to death two weeks ago. Over the past year, he has been accused of stealing a car and setting a fire at his school. He has no history of serious illness. He attends a local high school, and his performance at school is very poor compared to his classmates. He often loses his temper and argues with his teachers. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years. He does not drink alcohol. His mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia controlled with medication. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm, and his thought process is organized. Short- and long-term memory are intact. Attention and concentration are poor.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Conduct Disorder

instruction: I've been having episodes of shortness of breath and a cough that doesn't bring anything up for 3 months. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 4-year-old boy. Does he wheeze or have noisy breathing during his episodes? Yes, my breathing is noisy with a whistling sound during my episodes. Does he have any family history of asthma or allergies? I don’t know, nobody told me about that. Does he take any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications.
input: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician in December for episodic shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for 3 months. These episodes frequently occur before sleeping, and he occasionally wakes up because of difficulty breathing. His mother also reports that he became short of breath while playing with his friends at daycare on several occasions. He is allergic to peanuts. He is at the 55th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild scattered wheezing in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Asthma

instruction: I have a rash, my belly hurts sometimes, and my legs and arms are swollen. I also have pain in my knees and hands but I didn't get hurt. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 6-year-old girl.
input: A 6-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician with a rash and intermittent abdominal pain and swelling of her legs and arms. She has also begun to complain of pain in her knees and hands with no history of trauma. Her temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 100/80 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A as well as symmetric swelling in the joints of the upper extremities. Her abdomen is currently nontender and not painful. Laboratory studies are pending, and the results of a urinalysis are notable only for positive blood and protein in the urine.
output: Do you have a fever?

instruction: I have a dark spot on my lower lip and on my hands that appears when I take certain medications. What is your age? I am 45 years old.
input: A 45-year-old-man with a past medical history of knee pain and hypertension complains of dark spot on the lower lip and hands that develop whenever he takes certain oral medications. He states the rash has been ongoing for several years, and usually begins as a pink spot with a darker brown-black center. He denies any bleeding or ulceration at the site.  Current medications includes naproxen, multivitamins, and metoprolol.   Physical examination reveals a well demarcated red-purple patch with a darker red-violaceous center on the dorsal hands and lower lip. The patch is non-painful.
output: Are you male or female?

instruction: I have itchy blisters in my armpit area. How old are you? I am 81 years old.
input: An 81-year-old man patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in his axilla. He attributes these to a poor diet. He also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to his existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane.
output: Are you male or female?

instruction: I had a high fever, and I've been really fussy and crying a lot. What is the patient's age and sex? I'm an 11-month-old baby girl. How long have you had the fever? I don't have the fever anymore; it went away, but now I have a rash. Is the rash raised or flat? The rash is both raised and flat. Does the rash appear on your trunk or elsewhere? You didn't ask me about the location of my rash when it appeared, only about whether it was raised or flat. Would you like to know where it is now? Would you like to know where the rash is currently located? Yes, I would. The rash appeared after my fever went away. Where is the rash currently located? The rash is on my skin. How long has the rash been present? The rash showed up five days after my fever went away.
input: Parents bring an 11-month-old baby to the clinic because the baby has a fever of 39.0°C (102.2°F). The baby is irritated and crying constantly. She is up to date on immunizations. A complete physical examination reveals no significant findings, and all laboratory tests are negative. Five days after resolution of her fever, she develops a transient maculopapular rash.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Roseola

instruction: I've been having muscle pains, not sleeping well, and feeling tired during the day. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 45-year-old woman. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I've had these symptoms since I last saw you one year ago. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? As a patient with the information provided, I haven't mentioned any other medical conditions or medications.
input: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of muscle pains, poor sleep, and daytime fatigue. When asked about stressors she states that she "panics" about her job, marriage, children, and finances. When asked to clarify what the "panics" entail, she states that it involves severe worrying. She has had these symptoms since she last saw you one year ago.
output: Have you experienced any weight changes recently?

instruction: I've been feeling very tired and I have a fever. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 33-year-old man. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I haven't felt well since I returned from a hiking trip in Alabama. Do you have a rash? No, there is no rash; the physical exam didn't show anything unusual on my skin. Have you been bitten by any ticks? I'm not sure; nothing about a tick bite was mentioned during my exam. Have you experienced any muscle or joint pain? I haven't mentioned any muscle or joint pain. Have you experienced any chills or night sweats? I haven't mentioned experiencing chills or night sweats. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? No, I'm generally healthy and have no other medical conditions. Do you have any headaches? I haven't mentioned having headaches. Do you have a cough? I haven't mentioned having a cough. Do you have any nausea or vomiting? I haven't mentioned any nausea or vomiting. Have you noticed any swollen lymph nodes? I haven't mentioned noticing any swollen lymph nodes. Have you been exposed to freshwater or participated in swimming during your trip? I didn't mention any activities involving freshwater or swimming during my trip.
input:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever and fatigue. He states that he has not felt well since he returned from a hiking trip in Alabama. He is generally healthy and has no other medical conditions. His temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 127/85 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam including a full dermatologic inspection is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL
Hematocrit: 39%
Leukocyte count: 2,200/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 77,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 19 mg/dL
Glucose: 98 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
AST: 92 U/L
ALT: 100 U/L
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Ehrlichiosis

instruction: My child has a rash that started behind his ears and has spread to his torso and arms and legs, a sore throat, red and itchy eyes, and a headache.
input: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started behind the ears and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis and occasional asthma attacks. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He immigrated with his family from Brazil 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. The patient appears weak and lethargic. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a non-confluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities.
output: How old is your child?

instruction: I've been having progressively worsening pain in my knees and fingers for the past two years, and when I walk for more than 30 minutes, my knee pain gets worse. Can you tell me your age and sex? I am a 58-year-old woman. Do you have morning stiffness in your joints? Yes, my fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes when I wake up in the morning. Do you experience swelling or warmth in your joints? The case vignette does not mention swelling or warmth in my joints.
input: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressively worsening pain in her knees and fingers. The knee pain is worse when she walks for longer than 30 minutes. When she wakes up in the morning, her fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes. She cannot recall any trauma to the joints. She was treated with amoxicillin following a tick bite 2 years ago. She is otherwise healthy and only takes a multivitamin and occasionally acetaminophen for the pain. She drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 133/78 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities reveals mild genu varum. Range of motion of both knees is limited; there is palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicit pain. Tender nodules are present on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers bilaterally.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions?

instruction: I have a rash that started on my knees and has spread to my elbows, it's a bit itchy, and when I scratch it, it tends to bleed. Can you tell me your age and sex? I am a 41-year-old woman. Are you currently taking any medications or have any other medical conditions? I have seasonal allergies and take loratadine daily.
input: A 41-year-old woman comes to the office for an evaluation of a rash. She reports the rash started 2 months ago on her knees and the rash has now appeared on her elbows. She denies pain or burning, but says the areas are mildly itchy and when she scratches them, they bleed. The patient is embarrassed because she works as a massage therapist. She reports some fatigue, but attributes it to stress. She denies headache, weight loss, or joint pains. She has seasonal allergies and takes daily loratadine. She had a tonsillectomy as a child. Her sister has alopecia and her son has vitiligo. She smokes 1 pack a day and denies alcohol or other recreational drug use. She is sexually active with her husband of 15 years. On physical examination, there are symmetric erythematous plaques with overlying scales on the extensor surfaces of bilateral knees and elbows. One of the plaques is shown in Figure A.
output: Have you noticed any patterns or triggers that worsen the rash?

instruction: I've been having severe, sharp, piercing pain in the upper middle part of my stomach that started about 3 hours ago and it's so bad, I'd say it's a 10 out of 10. It also feels like it's moving towards my back. What is your age and sex? I'm a 43-year-old man.
input: A 43-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency room for severe abdominal pain. He is known to the emergency department for repeated visits for alcohol intoxication. He reports that the pain started about 3 hours ago and describes it as sharp, piercing, 10/10, and concentrated at the epigastric region with radiation to the back. His past medical history is unclear given his homeless status. His temperature is 100.4°F (38°C), blood pressure is 104/80 mmHg, the pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 16/min. A physical examination demonstrates epigastric tenderness and the finding shown in Figure A.
output: Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting?

instruction: I've been feeling dizzy and like the floor is moving under me for the past 2 days. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 33-year-old man. Have you noticed any hearing loss or ringing in your ears? No, I haven't noticed any hearing loss or ringing in my ears. Did the dizziness start suddenly or gradually? The dizziness has been sustained for the past 2 days. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? I'm otherwise healthy and the only thing I'm taking is vitamin C. Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting? No, I haven't experienced any nausea or vomiting. Have you experienced any headaches or other neurological symptoms? Nope, no headaches or other neurological symptoms.
input: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness. He states he has experienced a sustained sense of disequilibrium for the past 2 days. He feels that the floor is unstable/moving. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not have any other medical diagnoses. The patient is currently taking vitamin C as multiple family members are currently ill and he does not want to get sick. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a horizontal nystagmus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver does not provoke symptoms and examination of the patient’s cranial nerves is unremarkable.
output: Have you had any recent infections, such as a cold or flu?

instruction: I've been feeling very tired and noticeably pale for the past two days. What is your age and sex? I'm a 2-year-old boy. Have you experienced any bruising or bleeding? No, I haven't noticed any bruising or bleeding lately. Have you had any recent illnesses or infections? Yes, about a week ago, I had belly pain, throwing up, and bloody poop, but that has gotten better.
input:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of pallor and increasing lethargy for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a 6-week roadtrip in Mexico because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him oral rehydration solution. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 45,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec
Serum
Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 2.5 mg/dL
Direct 0.1 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L
A blood smear shows schistocytes.
output: Have you noticed any swelling or changes in your urine?

instruction: I've been having severe lower back pain and feeling really tired for the past 3 months. What is your age and gender? I'm a 72-year-old man. Are you currently taking any medications or have any past medical conditions? I take ibuprofen for pain relief and I have no history of a serious illness. Have you experienced any weight loss or night sweats? No, I haven't experienced weight loss or night sweats. Have you noticed any changes in your urination? No, I haven't noticed any changes in my urination.
input:
A 72-year-old man presents to the physician with severe lower back pain and fatigue for 3 months. The pain increases with activity. He has no history of a serious illness. He takes ibuprofen for pain relief. He does not smoke. The blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg, the pulse is 86/min, the respirations are 16/min, and the temperature is 36.7℃ (98.1℉). The conjunctivae are pale. Palpation over the 1st lumbar vertebra shows tenderness. The heart, lung, and abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. No lymphadenopathy is palpated. The results of the laboratory studies show:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 5,500/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 350,000/mm3
Serum
Calcium 11.5 mg/dL
Albumin 3.8 g/dL
Urea nitrogen 54 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL
Lumbosacral computed tomography (CT) scan shows a low-density lesion in the 1st lumbar vertebra and several similar lesions in the pelvic bones.
output: Have you had any bone fractures or additional bone pain?

instruction: I've been having left knee pain for the past 6 weeks and it gets really bad when I run up and down the stairs. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 12-year-old girl.
input: A 12-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with left knee pain for the past 6 weeks. She recently joined the field hockey team at her school. The pain is the most severe when she is running up and down the stairs at the school stadium. The pain decreases when she goes home and rests after practice. She additionally admits to tripping and landing on her left knee 5 days ago. Physical exam shows a knee with a healing abrasion over the left patella. The tibial tuberosity is tender to palpation. A radiograph of the knee is presented in figure A.
output: Have you experienced any injuries or swelling in your knee?

instruction: I have loose and stretchy skin, and I bruise easily. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 16-year-old male. Have you noticed any joint hypermobility or frequent joint dislocations? I didn't mention anything about joint problems or dislocations.
input: A 16-year-old male with past medical history of mitral valve prolapse presents for evaluation of loose skin. Patient's parents report a several year history of stretchy skin, poor wound healing with some scars healing with thin overlying skin, and easy bruising. There is a family history of similar symptoms amongst other family members. Physical examination reveals soft, significantly extensible skin diffusely, multiple linear scars with atrophic overlying pink patches, and white-yellow papules along the bilateral inner and outer calcaneus upon standing. The patient is able to touch the tip of his nose with his tongue.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been experiencing lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 34-year-old man.
input: A 34-year-old man presents to his physician with a complaint of lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. He describes the pain as being worse in the morning and then gradually improving with activity throughout the day. On physical exam, he has decreased anterior flexion of the lumbar spine. A radiograph of his lumbar spine is obtained and is shown in Figure A.
output: Do you experience morning stiffness that lasts longer than 30 minutes?

instruction: I've been feeling extremely irritable, really tired, and I've lost my appetite for the past 3 weeks. What is your age? I'm 16 years old. Are you male or female? I'm a boy. Have you been feeling sad or down? I've been feeling irritable. Are you taking any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications. Have you been having trouble sleeping? No, I go to bed when I get home from school and sleep for 11–12 hours each night.
input: A previously healthy 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation because of extreme irritability, fatigue, and loss of appetite for 3 weeks. Five months ago, his grandfather, whom he was very close to, passed away from chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He used to enjoy playing soccer but quit his soccer team last week. When he comes home from school he goes straight to bed and sleeps for 11–12 hours each night. He previously had good grades, but his teachers report that he has been disrespectful and distracted in class and failed an exam last week. He tried alcohol twice at a party last year and he has never smoked cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he avoids making eye contact but cooperates with the exam. His affect is limited and he describes an irritable mood. He is easily distracted and has a difficult time focusing for an extended conversation.
output: Have you had any changes in your weight?

instruction: I've been having severe, sharp, piercing pain in the upper middle part of my stomach that started about 3 hours ago and it's so bad, I'd say it's a 10 out of 10. It also feels like it's moving towards my back. What is your age and sex? I'm a 43-year-old man. Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting? I haven't mentioned feeling nauseous or throwing up.
input: A 43-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency room for severe abdominal pain. He is known to the emergency department for repeated visits for alcohol intoxication. He reports that the pain started about 3 hours ago and describes it as sharp, piercing, 10/10, and concentrated at the epigastric region with radiation to the back. His past medical history is unclear given his homeless status. His temperature is 100.4°F (38°C), blood pressure is 104/80 mmHg, the pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 16/min. A physical examination demonstrates epigastric tenderness and the finding shown in Figure A.
output: Do you have any history of stomach or digestive problems?

instruction: I've been experiencing all-over muscle pain, feeling generally unwell, pain in both of my knees, and I keep having episodes of stomach and chest pain. What is your age and sex? I'm a 58-year-old man. Are you currently taking any medications? Yes, I've been taking tenofovir for my chronic hepatitis B infection. Have your symptoms been continuous or do they come and go? They come and go.
input: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, pain in both knees, recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. He has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows a transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.
output: Do you have any morning stiffness?

instruction: I've been having progressive pain in the front part of my left knee for about a week now. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 22-year-old woman. Have you had any recent injuries or increased physical activities? I first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. Do you experience any swelling, locking, or clicking in your knee? No, there's no swelling, and it doesn't lock or click.
input: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 1 week of progressive left anterior knee pain. The pain is worse after sitting for a prolonged period of time and while ascending stairs. She first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. She has often taken painful blows to the side of the knees while playing basketball but does not recall this having happened in the last game. Four weeks ago, she was diagnosed with a chlamydial urinary tract infection and treated with azithromycin. She is sexually active with one male partner; they use condoms inconsistently. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 19.6 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left anterior knee that is exacerbated with anterior pressure to the patella when the knee is fully extended; there is no erythema or swelling.
output: Does the pain worsen when climbing stairs or sitting with bent knees?

instruction: I've been having a hard time focusing and paying attention, and I get angry really easily, especially at school. How old are you? I am 15 years old. What is your sex? I'm a boy. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I'm not taking any medications. Have you experienced any significant changes or stressful events recently? Yes, I've gotten into trouble for setting a fire at my school and for stealing a car.
input: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of his “weird” behavior. The parents report that their son tortured their cat to death two weeks ago. Over the past year, he has been accused of stealing a car and setting a fire at his school. He has no history of serious illness. He attends a local high school, and his performance at school is very poor compared to his classmates. He often loses his temper and argues with his teachers. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years. He does not drink alcohol. His mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia controlled with medication. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm, and his thought process is organized. Short- and long-term memory are intact. Attention and concentration are poor.
output: Have you experienced any problems at home or with your family?

instruction: I feel well generally, but I get occasional abdominal pain about 1–2 times a month.
input:
A 70-year-old man presents for his annual check-up. He says he feels well except for occasional abdominal pain. He describes the pain as 4/10–5/10 in intensity, diffusely localized to the periumbilical and epigastric regions, radiating to the groin. The pain occurs 1–2 times a month and always subsides on its own. The patient denies any recent history of fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, change in body weight, or change in bowel and/or bladder habits. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral vascular disease, managed with lisinopril and simvastatin. The patient reports a 40-pack-year smoking history and 1–2 alcoholic drinks a day. The blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg and the pulse is 80/min. Peripheral pulses are 2+ bilaterally in all extremities. Abdominal exam reveals a bruit in the epigastric region along with mild tenderness to palpation with no rebound or guarding. There is also a pulsatile abdominal mass felt on deep palpation at the junction of the periumbilical and the suprapubic regions. The remainder of the physical exam is normal. Laboratory studies show:
Serum total cholesterol 175 mg/dL
Serum total bilirubin 1 mg/dL
Serum amylase 25 U/L
Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 20 U/L
Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 16 U/L
output: How old are you and what is your gender?

instruction: I have rough, hard spots on both of my earlobes where I got my ears pierced three months ago.
input: A 21-year-old woman presents to clinic with rough, firm spots on both earlobes that developed three months ago when she underwent ear piercings. She has tried over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement.   She notes that she has a history of multiple similar spots that developed after she injured herself, and multiple family members have similar spots.   On physical exam, thick pink firm plaques are noted at the sites of ear piercings that extend beyond margin of the scar.
output: How old are you and what is your gender?

instruction: I've been making uncontrollable face movements and smacking my lips for the past 2 months, and it's getting worse. How old are you and what is your gender? I am a 43-year-old woman. Are you currently taking any medications? Yes, I'm taking medication for schizophrenia, it's called clozapine. Have you noticed any other involuntary movements or symptoms? No, just the uncontrollable grimacing and lip smacking. Have you been taking clozapine for more than six months? I’m sorry, I don't have that information.
input: A 43-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She says she has been uncontrollably grimacing and smacking her lips for the past 2 months, and these symptoms have been getting progressively worse. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia, managed medically with clozapine.
output: Do you have any other medical conditions?

instruction: I am not experiencing any symptoms today; I feel healthy. What is your age? I am an 18-month-old toddler. Are you male or female? I am a boy. Have you had any previous illnesses or taken any medications? No, I have not had any previous illnesses or taken any medications. Do any family members have a history of cancer or blood disorders? The case vignette doesn't provide any information on my family's medical history. Have any recent blood tests been performed? Yes, I've had several blood tests which showed a low count of a specific type of white blood cells.
input:
An 18-month-old toddler is brought to a pediatric hematologist by his father. The boy was referred to this office for prolonged neutropenia. He has had several blood tests with an isolated low neutrophil count while hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet count is normal. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. Today his complete blood count (CBC) with differential shows:
Hemoglobin: 15.5 g/dL
Platelets: 300,000 mm3
Neutrophils: 20%
Bands: 2%
Lymphocytes: 40%
Monocytes: 15%
Today, he has a heart rate of 90/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, blood pressure of 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the child appears healthy and is within expected growth parameters for his age and sex. A bone marrow biopsy shows normal bone marrow with 95% cellularity and trilineage maturation. Flow cytometry is normal with no abnormal markers noted.
output: Which specific type of white blood cells is low?

instruction: I've been having to go to the bathroom a lot at night, and it keeps waking me up. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 75-year-old woman. Do you have any pain or discomfort while urinating? No, I don't have any pain or discomfort while urinating. Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions or are you taking any medications? The case vignette does not mention any other medical conditions or medications that I'm taking. Do you feel a sudden urge to urinate? Yes, I often feel a sudden urge to urinate.
input: A 75-year-old woman presents to the physician with a complaint of a frequent need to void at nighttime, which has been disrupting her sleep. She notes embarrassingly that she is often unable to reach the bathroom in time, and experiences urinary leakage throughout the night as well as during the day. The patient undergoes urodynamic testing and a urinalysis is obtained which is normal. She is instructed by the physician to perform behavioral training to improve her bladder control.
output: How often do you need to urinate during the day?

instruction: I've been feeling hopeless, have a poor appetite, am having difficulty concentrating, and trouble with sleep. What is your age and sex? I am a 24-year-old woman. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I've been experiencing these symptoms for the past 3 years.
input: A 24-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a wellness exam. She currently has no acute concerns but has been feeling hopeless, has a poor appetite, difficulty with concentration, and trouble with sleep. She says that she has poor self-esteem and that her symptoms have been occurring for the past 3 years. She has had moments where she felt better, but it lasted a few weeks out of the year. She currently lives alone and does not pursue romantic relationships because she feels she is not attractive. She has a past medical history of asthma. Her mother is alive and healthy. Her father committed suicide and suffered from major depressive disorder. On physical exam, the patient has a gloomy demeanor and appears restless and anxious.
output: Do you experience a loss of interest or pleasure in activities?

instruction: I've been having pain and stiffness in my fingers and knees for the past year. What is your age and sex? I'm a 59-year-old woman.
input: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of pain and stiffness in her fingers and knees. The stiffness lasts for about 10 minutes after she wakes up in the morning. She also reports that her knee pain is worse in the evening. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her only medication is acetaminophen. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers of both hands.
output: Do you experience morning stiffness? If yes, how long does it last?

instruction: I've had a painful, itchy rash for the past 3 days that started on my arms and legs and has moved to my trunk. What is your age and sex? I am a 32-year-old woman. Have you started using any new soaps, detergents, or cosmetics recently? No, I haven't started using any new soaps, detergents, or cosmetics recently. Have you experienced any allergies before? I haven't mentioned any allergies. Have you been taking any medications recently? Yes, I'm taking acyclovir. When did you start taking acyclovir? I can't provide those details; I only mentioned that acyclovir is my only medication. Have you experienced any fever or other systemic symptoms? Yes, I have a fever with a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F).
input: A 32-year-old woman with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them.
output: Have you noticed any blisters or peeling of your skin?

instruction: I passed out during a soccer game, and I've been feeling short of breath for the last 3 months and chest pain when I do strenuous activities for the past week. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 26-year-old male. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? No, I haven't mentioned any medical conditions or medications. Do you have a family history of heart disease? Yes, my brother had a sudden death a couple of years ago. Do you experience any palpitations? No, I haven't mentioned experiencing palpitations. Do you have any chest tightness at rest? No, I only feel chest pain when I exert myself, not at rest. Have you been diagnosed with any heart murmurs? Yes, the doctors found a harsh sound in my heart when they listened with a stethoscope.
input: A 26-year-old male professional soccer player is brought to the emergency department due to an episode of syncope during a game. He has felt increasing shortness of breath during the past 3 months. During the past week, he has been feeling chest pain upon exertion. He also tells the doctor that his brother had a sudden death a couple of years ago. His heart rate is 98/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur immediately after S1; it is best heard on the apex, and it radiates to the axilla. There is also an early diastolic murmur heard in early diastole, which is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope. When the Valsalva maneuver is performed, the murmur becomes louder. An ECG and an echocardiogram are performed, which confirm the diagnosis.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

instruction: I have a rash all over my body for 1 day, but it's not on my palms or soles. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 4-day-old newborn, and my sex is not specified. Does the rash have any pustules or blisters? Yes, the rash has pustules with a red base. Does your baby have a fever? No, my baby does not have a fever.
input: A 4-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 1 day. He was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 152/min, and respirations are 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Erythema toxicum neonatorum

instruction: I've been experiencing bleeding in between my periods for the past six months, but without any other problems like pain during sex, pelvic pain, or unusual discharge. How old are you? I am 38 years old.
input: A 38-year-old woman undergoes a diagnostic hysteroscopy for a 6-month history of small volume intermenstrual bleeding with no other complaints. There is no history of pelvic pain, painful intercourse, or vaginal discharge other than blood. During the procedure, a red beefy pedunculated mass is seen arising from the endometrium of the anterior wall of the uterus that has well-demarcated borders. This mass is resected and sent for histopathological examination.
output: Have you taken any medications or hormonal treatments recently?

instruction: I've been more irritable than usual and sometimes I turn pale and blue. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 2-year-old girl. Are you experiencing any difficulty breathing or rapid breathing? Yes, I seem to be in distress. Have you been diagnosed with any heart conditions before? Yes, I was diagnosed with a heart murmur.
input: A 2-year-old girl is brought in to the office by her parents. They state that their daughter has recently been more irritable than usual, and she occasionally becomes pale and blue. Her parents note that she was diagnosed with a heart murmur, but it was never treated. Physical examination reveals a small child in distress. She is laying on the examination table with her knees drawn to her chest. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh, systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper left sternal border.
output: Does anyone in your family have heart disease?

instruction: I've been having these moments where I just stare and make faces for a few minutes without responding to anyone, and afterwards, I can't remember anything that happened. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 7-year-old boy. How often do these episodes occur? They've been happening for the past month. Do you have any family history of seizures or epilepsy? I don't know about that. Have you had any recent illnesses or injuries? No, I haven't had any illnesses or injuries recently. How long does each episode last? Each episode lasts about 3 to 4 minutes.
input: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for recurrent 3–4 minutes episodes of facial grimacing and staring over the past month. He is nonresponsive during these episodes and does not remember them afterward. He recalls a muddy taste in his mouth before the onset of symptoms. One week ago, his brother witnessed an episode where he woke up, stared, and made hand gestures. After the incident, he felt lethargic and confused. Examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Have you been taking any medications?

instruction: I've been having progressive pain in the front part of my left knee for about a week now. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 22-year-old woman. Have you had any recent injuries or increased physical activities? I first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. Do you experience any swelling, locking, or clicking in your knee? No, there's no swelling, and it doesn't lock or click. Does the pain worsen when climbing stairs or sitting with bent knees? Yes, the pain gets worse when I climb stairs or after I've been sitting for a long time. Are you experiencing any tenderness around your kneecap? Yes, there's tenderness over the front part of my left knee.
input: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 1 week of progressive left anterior knee pain. The pain is worse after sitting for a prolonged period of time and while ascending stairs. She first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. She has often taken painful blows to the side of the knees while playing basketball but does not recall this having happened in the last game. Four weeks ago, she was diagnosed with a chlamydial urinary tract infection and treated with azithromycin. She is sexually active with one male partner; they use condoms inconsistently. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 19.6 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left anterior knee that is exacerbated with anterior pressure to the patella when the knee is fully extended; there is no erythema or swelling.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome

instruction: I've been hitting my head on the wall a lot, I'm not talking as much as I used to, and I don't answer when people call my name.
input: A mother brings her 3-year-old son to the doctor because she is worried that he might be harming himself by constantly banging his head on the wall. He has been exhibiting this behavior for a few months. She is also worried because he has started to speak less than he used to and does not respond when his name is called. He seems aloof during playtime with other children and seems to have lost interest in most of his toys.
output: How old is the patient and what is their sex?

instruction: I've noticed some changes in my vision, like it's not as sharp as it used to be. How old are you? I'm 59 years old. Do you identify as male or female? I am a male. Is your vision impairment in one eye or both eyes? It's in both eyes. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have high blood pressure, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis, and I'm taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen for my conditions. When did you first notice the changes in your vision? I didn't specify when I first noticed the changes in my vision. Do you experience any pain in your eyes? No, I don't feel any pain in my eyes.
input: A 59-year-old man presents to his ophthalmologist for an annual eye exam. The patient reports feeling well and has noticed some changes in his visual acuity. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes, and ankylosing spondylitis. He is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, and naproxen. Family history is significant for glaucoma in his mother and father. His intraocular pressure is 17 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. The patient undergoes a slit-lamp examination and the findings are shown in Figure A.
output: Is your vision loss gradual or did it occur suddenly?

instruction: I'm having trouble paying attention at home and school, I don't finish my assignments, and I don't listen to what my teachers or parents say to me. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 5-year-old girl.
input: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother has found her to be inattentive at home and has received multiple complaints from her teachers at school. She does not complete her assignments and does not listen to her teachers' instructions. She refuses to talk to her parents or peers. Her mother says, “She ignores everything I say to her!” She prefers playing alone, and her mother reports that she likes playing with 5 red toy cars, repeatedly arranging them in a straight line. She avoids eye contact with her mother and the physician throughout the visit. Physical and neurological examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Have these behaviors been present for at least six months?

instruction: I'm experiencing pain in both my knees and severe pain over my right groin. My right leg also feels a bit shorter, is bent, turned inward, and I can't open it outward. What is your age? I'm 25 years old.
input: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Are you male or female?

instruction: I've been having severe pain in the middle of my upper belly that spreads to my back for the past 3 days. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 47-year-old. Are you male or female? The case vignette does not specify my gender. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any medications? I have high blood pressure, diabetes, and high blood fat levels, and I take enalapril, metformin, sitagliptin, glargine, lispro, and fenofibrate for them. Have you consumed alcohol recently? I only have 1 or 2 drinks during special occasions, like weddings and family reunions. Do you have any nausea or vomiting? The case vignette doesn’t mention nausea or vomiting. Do you have any yellowing of your skin or eyes? No, there's no yellowing of my skin or eyes.
input:
A 47-year-old presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of severe mid-epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back. The patient has hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypertriglyceridemia. Prescription medications include enalapril, metformin, sitagliptin, glargine, lispro, and fenofibrate. The patient has not had a cigarette in more than 35 years, and reports only having 1 or 2 drinks during special occasions such as weddings and family reunions. The blood pressure is 146/90 mm Hg, the heart rate is 88/min, the respiratory rate is 10/min, and the temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F). On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable but alert. The visualization of the sclera is negative for jaundice. The neck is supple and non-tender without nodules. There are no heart murmurs. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The palpation of the abdomen elicits pain in the epigastric region. The liver is palpable along the costal margin, and the Murphy’s sign is negative. The laboratory results are as follows:
Na+ 138 mEq/L
K+ 4.2 mEq/L
Cl- 108 mmol/L
HCO-3 20 mmol/L
BUN 178 mg/dL
Cr 1.0 mg/dL
Glucose  154 mg/dL
LDL 117 mg/dL
HDL 48 mg/dL
TG 942 mg/dL
AST 45 IU/L
ALT 48 IU/L
GGT 27 IU/L
Amylase  110 U/L
Lipase 250 U/L
output: Have you had any history of gallstones or similar abdominal pain before?

instruction: I had a high fever, and I've been really fussy and crying a lot. What is the patient's age and sex? I'm an 11-month-old baby girl. How long have you had the fever? I don't have the fever anymore; it went away, but now I have a rash. Is the rash raised or flat? The rash is both raised and flat. Does the rash appear on your trunk or elsewhere? You didn't ask me about the location of my rash when it appeared, only about whether it was raised or flat. Would you like to know where it is now? Would you like to know where the rash is currently located? Yes, I would. The rash appeared after my fever went away.
input: Parents bring an 11-month-old baby to the clinic because the baby has a fever of 39.0°C (102.2°F). The baby is irritated and crying constantly. She is up to date on immunizations. A complete physical examination reveals no significant findings, and all laboratory tests are negative. Five days after resolution of her fever, she develops a transient maculopapular rash.
output: Where is the rash currently located?

instruction: I've been having trouble staying awake past 6 pm in the evening, even though I feel rested when I wake up. How old are you? I am 69 years old. Are you male or female? I am a male. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions? Yes, I have irritable bowel syndrome. Are you currently taking any medications? I'm taking fiber supplements for my irritable bowel syndrome. Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns recently? Yes, I've been having trouble sleeping and can't stay awake past 6 pm.
input: A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble sleeping. The patient states that he recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery. When the patient retired, his goal was to finally be able to go out with his wife; however, he finds that he is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. His inability to stay awake has been straining his marriage as his wife is disappointed that they cannot do any activities in the evening together. The patient has tried drinking caffeine but finds that it does not help. The patient’s wife claims that the patient seems to sleep peacefully, and the patient states he feels rested when he awakes. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome which is managed with fiber supplements. The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits.
output: Are you experiencing loud snoring or gasping for air during sleep?

instruction: I've been feeling uncomfortable in my own body, especially in situations like swim class where I have to wear swim trunks, and I would rather be a girl. How old are you and what is your current gender? I'm 13 years old and my current gender is male. How long have you been feeling this way? I've felt this way since I started puberty about a year ago. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? No, I don't have any other medical conditions or take any medications.
input: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because she is concerned about her son's behavior. She reports that he has been wearing her dresses at home and asks to be called Lilly. He also stopped going to swim class because he “doesn't feel comfortable in swim trunks.” Since starting puberty about a year ago, he has not had any friends and the teachers report he is consistently being bullied at school. His academic performance has been poor for the last year even though he had maintained an A average the year before. The mother further reports that her son has had mainly female friends since preschool. She also mentions that as a child her son never enjoyed playing with typical boy toys like cars and instead preferred dressing up dolls. The patient was raised by his single mother from the age of 8 because his father left the family due to financial issues. He appears shy. Physical examination shows normal male external genitalia. There is scarce coarse, dark axillary and pubic hair. Upon questioning, the patient reports that he would rather be a girl.
output: Have you discussed these feelings with anyone in your family?

instruction: I tend to eat a lot all at once when I'm feeling stressed, especially around exam times, and afterwards, I feel really guilty about it. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm an 18-year-old male. How long have you been experiencing these eating behaviors? I didn't mention exactly how long I've been experiencing these eating behaviors. Have you engaged in any behaviors to compensate after eating, like vomiting or excessive exercise? I sometimes go to the gym for more than 4 hours a day to make up for it, but I have never vomited to lose weight. Do these binge eating episodes occur regularly each week? You didn't ask me about how often the binge eating happens, so I haven't provided that information. How many times per week do you experience binge eating episodes? I didn't specify how many times per week the binge eating happens. Have you experienced any significant weight changes recently? I haven't mentioned any changes in my weight recently. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? I haven't mentioned having any other medical conditions or taking any medications.
input: An 18-year-old male is seen for a routine physical prior to starting college. He will be moving from Ohio to California, away from his family for the first time. His temperature is 36.8 deg C (98.2 deg F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg. BMI is 24. On questioning, he reveals that he has a habit of binge eating during times of stress, particularly during exams. He then feels guilty about his behavior and attempts to compensate by going to the gym, sometimes for 4+ hours per day. He is disturbed by this behavior and feels out of control. He denies ever vomiting as a means of loosing weight.
output: Have you any family history of eating disorders or mental health conditions?

instruction: I've got growing red spots and bumps on my tongue, inside my mouth, on my nose, lower lip, and fingertips. How old are you? I am 45 years old. Are you male or female? I am a woman. Have you started any new medications recently? No, I haven't started any new medications recently. Have you experienced any allergies? No, I haven't mentioned any allergies.
input: A 45-year-old woman presents with enlarging blood vessels on her tongue that recently have increased in size and number. Numerous 1- to 2-mm discrete red macules and papules are seen on her tongue, oral mucosa, nose, lower lip, and fingertips. She has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood as well as iron-deficiency anemia that has not responded to iron supplementation. Her father, who died at the age of 50, had similar symptoms.
output: Have you had any other medical conditions?

instruction: I have painful urination, fever, and pain on the right side of my lower back. What is your age and sex? I am a 33-year-old female. Have you noticed any blood in your urine? No, I haven't noticed any blood in my urine. Do you have any history of urinary tract infections? You didn't specify that I have a history of urinary tract infections in the information provided to me, so I can't say if I do.
input: A 33-year-old female presents with recent onset of painful urination, fever, and right flank pain. Urinary sediment analysis is positive for the presence of white blood cell casts and Gram-negative bacteria. She has not recently started any new medications.
output: Apologies for the confusion. Have you ever had a urinary tract infection before?

instruction: I've been having some strange, jittery movements in my arms and hands that I can't control and I've been forgetting things I just learned or did recently. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 31-year-old man.
input: A 31-year-old man is referred to a neurologist due to his gradually increasing eccentric behavior and involuntary movements, especially the movements of his arms and hands. He also has difficulty with his short-term memory. Past medical history is otherwise noncontributory. His father had similar symptoms before he died but those symptoms started at the age of 33. His blood pressure is 125/92 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F). Physical exam reveals involuntary writhing movements of hands, slow eye movements, and sporadic rigidity. The physician explains that this is an inherited disorder where the symptoms occur progressively at an earlier age than the parent and often with increased severity in the future generations.
output: Are you taking any medications?

instruction: I have a rash that started on my face a few weeks ago and spread to my whole body, including my palms and soles. What is your age and sex? I am a 2-month-old male. Does your baby have a fever? No, I haven't mentioned having a fever.
input: A 2-month-old male with past medical history of delayed neurological development, deafness presents for evaluation of rash and history of suspected multiple fractures evaluated in the emergency room. Mother notes the rash started a few weeks ago on the face and then spread throughout the body onto the palms and soles. Physical examination reveals multiple thin scaly dark pink macules coalescing into patches on the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles. The patient does not move the right hand during the encounter.
output: Is the rash itchy?

instruction: I had a high fever, and I've been really fussy and crying a lot.
input: Parents bring an 11-month-old baby to the clinic because the baby has a fever of 39.0°C (102.2°F). The baby is irritated and crying constantly. She is up to date on immunizations. A complete physical examination reveals no significant findings, and all laboratory tests are negative. Five days after resolution of her fever, she develops a transient maculopapular rash.
output: What is the patient's age and sex?

instruction: I've been having progressive pain in the front part of my left knee for about a week now. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 22-year-old woman. Have you had any recent injuries or increased physical activities? I first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game.
input: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 1 week of progressive left anterior knee pain. The pain is worse after sitting for a prolonged period of time and while ascending stairs. She first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game.
