Yes, I have ulceration on my tongue and the roof of my mouth, and my eyes are red.
input: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. The rash began on her chest and face and spread to her limbs, palms, and soles. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked.
output: Have you noticed any blisters or peeling on your rash?

instruction: I've been feeling really agitated and I think someone is spying on me and trying to control my mind. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 26-year-old man. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? I've been experiencing these symptoms for the last 6 weeks. Do you currently take any medications? The vignette does not mention me taking any medications.
input: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of bizarre and agitated behavior for the last 6 weeks. He thinks that the NSA is spying on him and controlling his mind. His wife reports that the patient has become withdrawn and at times depressed for the past 3 months. He lost his job because he stopped going to work 4 weeks ago. Since then, he has been working on an invention that will block people from being able to control his mind. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. His speech is disorganized and his affect is labile.
output: Do you have any family history of mental illness?

instruction: I have a cut on my scalp that isn't healing. What is your age and sex? I am a 69-year-old male. How long has the cut been present without healing? It has been present for at least three months. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have diabetes that isn't well-controlled and irritable bowel syndrome, and I take blood pressure medication, diabetes medications, fiber supplements, and a multivitamin. Does the cut show any redness, swelling, or discharge? The vignette does not provide this information.
input:
A 69-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for a general checkup. The patient works as a farmer and gardens in his spare time. The patient has a past medical history of poorly managed diabetes mellitus type II, and irritable bowel syndrome. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, insulin, fiber supplements, and a multivitamin. On physical exam you note an obese gentleman. Inspection of the patient's scalp reveals the finding in Figure A. The patient is sent home and instructed to keep a blood glucose journal and to return with it in three months.

Three months later, the patient returns with his glucose journal. In addition, he complains of a cut on his scalp that is not seeming to heal. The patient's glucose journal reveals an average blood glucose of 175 mg/dL. On inspection of the patient's scalp, you note the finding in Figure B.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Squamous Cell Carcinoma

instruction: I keep getting skin bumps that are red and some have pus, and I also have swollen glands in my neck and under my arms. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 3-year-old boy. Have you had a fever recently? Yes, I've had recurrent fevers since I was born. Have you had any other recurrent infections? I've had several episodes of respiratory tract infections. Have any family members had similar symptoms? No, but my older brother has asthma.
input: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Has your child experienced any delays in growth or development?

instruction: I've been experiencing severe pain around the left side of my eye and my vision is blurry in that same eye.
input: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 25 minutes after the onset of severe left periorbital pain and blurred vision in the same eye. The pain began soon after she entered a theater to watch a movie. She has a headache and vomited twice on the way to the hospital. Two weeks ago, she had acute sinusitis that resolved spontaneously. She has atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Current medications include metoprolol and warfarin. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Visual acuity is counting fingers at 3 feet in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. The left eye shows conjunctival injection and edematous cornea. The left pupil is mid-dilated and irregular; it is not reactive to light. Extraocular movements are normal. Fundoscopic examination is inconclusive because of severe corneal edema.
output: How old are you and what is your gender?

instruction: I have painful urination, fever, and pain on the right side of my lower back. What is your age and sex? I am a 33-year-old female. Have you noticed any blood in your urine? No, I haven't noticed any blood in my urine. Do you have any history of urinary tract infections? You didn't specify that I have a history of urinary tract infections in the information provided to me, so I can't say if I do. Apologies for the confusion. Have you ever had a urinary tract infection before? The information you've given me doesn't include my history of urinary tract infections, so I don't know. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I have not recently started any new medications.
input: A 33-year-old female presents with recent onset of painful urination, fever, and right flank pain. Urinary sediment analysis is positive for the presence of white blood cell casts and Gram-negative bacteria. She has not recently started any new medications.
output: Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting?

instruction: I used to be able to ride a tricycle, stack blocks, and talk in short sentences, but now I can't feed myself and I point to things instead of asking for them. What is the patient's age? I am 4 years old. Has the child had any recent illnesses or infections? No recent illnesses or infections have been mentioned. What is the patient's sex? I am a girl.
input: A 4-year-old girl is seen by her pediatrician for developmental delay. One year prior, the patient was able to ride a tricycle, stack 3 blocks, and speak in short sentences. Now, she is unable to feed herself and has recently started to point to objects she wants rather than asking. Physical exam reveals a well nourished child sitting in a stroller wringing her hands. Vital signs are normal. The patient's mother reports that her 7-year-old son is doing well, and that they have no family history of mental retardation or other cognitive disorders.
output: Does any family member have similar symptoms?

instruction: I've been feeling itchy all over my body for the last 8 days. What is your age and gender? I'm a 25-year-old woman. Have you noticed any rashes or bumps on your skin? No, I haven't had any rashes. Have you started any new medications recently? I haven't started any new medications.
input:
A 25-year-old primigravid woman at 34-weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of an 8-day history of generalized pruritus. She has no history of rash. She has had standard prenatal care. Three weeks ago she was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. She traveled to Mexico for a vacation 3 months ago. She takes her multivitamin supplements inconsistently. Her blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and mild scleral icterus. The uterus is soft, nontender, and consistent in size with a 34-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8,000/mm3
Platelet 250,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 11 seconds
Serum
Total bilirubin 4 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 3.2 mg/dL
Bile acid 15 μmol/L (N = 0.3–10)
AST 45 U/L
ALT 50 U/L
A peripheral blood smear is normal. There are no abnormalities on abdominopelvic ultrasonography.
output: Have you experienced any fatigue or weight changes?

instruction: I've been feeling weak, and it's been getting worse for the past two weeks. I'm having a hard time lifting my arms, although they seem to work fine otherwise. What is your age and sex? I am a 45-year-old woman. Do you have any chronic illnesses or take any medications? No, I don't have any history of chronic illnesses or take any medications. Have you noticed any skin rashes or changes? Yes, I have a rash around my eyes and on my lower face, which extends down to my neck and chest. Have you noticed any rash on your knuckles? No, I haven't mentioned anything about having a rash on my knuckles.
input: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of weakness that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. She states that she has a hard time lifting both her arms but that they function normally. She notes no history of trauma or other deficits. On examination, that patient has 2/5 muscle strength on shoulder shrug and arm abduction bilaterally, but all other neurological exam findings are normal. You notice some skin changes and ask the patient about them. She states that she has had a rash around her eyes as well as on her lower face, going down to her neck and chest. She notes that the rashes started around the same time as the weakness began. Labs are drawn and a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal.
output: Do you experience any muscle pain or tenderness?

instruction: I have itchy blisters in my armpit area.
input: An 81-year-old man patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in his axilla. He attributes these to a poor diet. He also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to his existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane.
output: How old are you?

instruction: I've been experiencing lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 34-year-old man. Do you experience morning stiffness that lasts longer than 30 minutes? Yes, the pain and stiffness are worse in the morning.
input: A 34-year-old man presents to his physician with a complaint of lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. He describes the pain as being worse in the morning and then gradually improving with activity throughout the day. On physical exam, he has decreased anterior flexion of the lumbar spine. A radiograph of his lumbar spine is obtained and is shown in Figure A.
output: Have you had any eye problems, such as redness or pain?

instruction: I'm unable to use my left hand at all.
input: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly several hours ago and has steadily worsened. The patient has a past medical history of anxiety and depression. Her current medications include sertraline, sodium docusate, a multivitamin, and fish oil. The patient is currently sexually active with her boyfriend and uses the "pull-out" method for contraception. A pelvic ultrasound in the emergency room reveals an ectopic pregnancy. The patient is scheduled for surgery and is promptly treated. She is recovering on the surgical floor. The procedure was complicated by a large amount of blood loss. The patient is recovering on IV fluids when her family comes to visit. When her parents find out the diagnosis, yelling ensues and they leave angrily. The patient is scheduled to go home today. Prior to discharge, the patient reports she is unable to use her left hand. Upon examination, she is teary-eyed and she claims that she has “the worst family in the world,” and she does not want to go home. Physical exam reveals no skin or bony abnormalities of the left arm. Strength is 0/5 in the left upper extremity. She does not recoil her left arm to pain. A MRI is obtained and is unremarkable. The rest of the patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I currently have no complaints. How old are you? I am 55 years old. Do you have any family history of cancer? There is no mention of a family history of cancer in my case. Are you male or female? I am a male.
input:
A 55-year-old man presents for a routine check-up. He currently has no complaints, and his last physical and laboratory studies were unremarkable. His past medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia, well managed with rosuvastatin, and hypertension, well managed with hydrochlorothiazide. His current medications also include aspirin. The patient is afebrile and his vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals some generalized lymphadenopathy. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
WBC 38,000/mm3
RBC 4.20 x 106/mm3
Hematocrit 27.3%
Hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL
Platelet count 355,000/mm3
A peripheral blood smear and differential shows 92% small normocytic lymphocytes.
output: Have you had any previous illnesses?

instruction: I'm having chest pain and shortness of breath. Can you tell me your age and gender? I'm a 33-year-old woman. How long have you been experiencing these symptoms? My symptoms started when I returned from my trip to Africa. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions or are you taking any medications? I have asthma and I'm currently using albuterol and taking oral contraceptive pills. Have you experienced any swelling or pain in your legs? No, I have not experienced any swelling or pain in my legs.
input: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for chest pain and shortness of breath. She states that her symptoms started when she returned from her trip to Africa. She states that the pain is worsened with deep breaths and she has experienced hemoptysis during this time. The patient has a past medical history of asthma and is currently taking albuterol and oral contraceptive pills. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 125/64 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam is within normal limits, and a chest radiograph is obtained as seen in Figure A.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Pulmonary embolism

instruction: I've been experiencing gradual hair thinning for the past 2 years. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 54-year-old woman.
input: A 54-year-old woman presents with 2 years of gradual hair thinning. She says that her mother also experienced hair thinning starting in her 50s. She denies scalp itch. She denies clumps of hair coming out in the shower or on her pillow. She denies any preceding stressful life events. She denies wearing her hair in tight braids. She denies loss of eyebrows or eyelashes.
output: Do you have any underlying medical conditions or are you taking any medications?

instruction: I suddenly lost my vision in my right eye about 50 minutes ago. What is your age and sex? I am a 62-year-old woman.
input: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 50 minutes ago. She does not have eye pain. She had several episodes of loss of vision in the past, but her vision improved following treatment with glucocorticoids. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and multiple sclerosis. She underwent a left carotid endarterectomy 3 years ago. She had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metformin, glipizide, and weekly intramuscular beta-interferon injections. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/88 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye and absent in the right eye. The indirect pupillary reflex is brisk in the right eye but absent in the left eye. Intraocular pressure is 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye. A white, 1-mm ring is seen around the circumference of the cornea in both eyes. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows a few soft and hard exudates in the superior and nasal retinal quadrants. The optic disc and macula appear normal.
output: Do you have any history of hypertension, diabetes, or other medical conditions?

instruction: I've been having to go to the bathroom a lot at night, and it keeps waking me up. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 75-year-old woman. Do you have any pain or discomfort while urinating? No, I don't have any pain or discomfort while urinating. Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions or are you taking any medications? The case vignette does not mention any other medical conditions or medications that I'm taking.
input: A 75-year-old woman presents to the physician with a complaint of a frequent need to void at nighttime, which has been disrupting her sleep. She notes embarrassingly that she is often unable to reach the bathroom in time, and experiences urinary leakage throughout the night as well as during the day. The patient undergoes urodynamic testing and a urinalysis is obtained which is normal. She is instructed by the physician to perform behavioral training to improve her bladder control.
output: Do you feel a sudden urge to urinate?

instruction: I've been having a fever, headache, and a rash that has been getting worse over the past 6 days. How old are you? I am 29 years old. What is your gender? I am a woman. Have you taken any new medications recently? No, I have not taken any new medications recently. Have you traveled anywhere recently? I haven't mentioned any recent travel.
input: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician with complaints of fever, headache, and rash, which have gradually worsened over the past 6 days. The patient informs the physician that the rash appeared after 2 days of fever. The rash started at the wrists and ankles and then gradually spread to the trunk, palms, and soles. On examination, the physician notes a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below. Vital signs show a temperature of 39.4°C (103.0°F), a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, and a pulse rate of 86/min.
output: Do you have any chronic medical conditions?

instruction: My baby girl is having trouble eating and keeps getting sick frequently. How old is your baby girl? She is 4 months old. Is she frequently vomiting or spitting up after feeding? She's having feeding problems, but nothing was mentioned about vomiting or spitting up specifically. Is she gaining weight normally? There's no mention of her weight gain in the information provided. Is she breastfed or formula-fed? It wasn't specified if she is breastfed or formula-fed. Does she have a fever or any signs of infection? She keeps getting sick frequently, which could imply signs of infection. Does she have any known medical conditions or take any medications? She has a cleft palate, malformed jaw, structural heart problems, and weak immunity, but there's no mention of medications.
input: A 4-month-old neonate girl is brought to the pediatrician because of feeding problems and recurrent infections. She has a blood pressure of 104/65 mm Hg and heart rate of 91/min. On physical examination, she has a cleft palate, malformed jaw, structural cardiac abnormalities, and diminished cell-mediated responses. Laboratory investigations reveal hypocalcemia.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** DiGeorge Syndrome

instruction: I've got an itchy rash that started about 3 months ago.
input: A 32-year-old woman presents with an itchy rash that began 3 months ago. She has a history of anxiety but otherwise no known medical conditions. She has tried over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream to treat the rash, finding some relief from the itchiness, but the rash continues to spread. She has no known allergies and has not changed her skin care products or medications. On examination, the patient has dark purple and gray flat-topped papules with fine gray-white streaks on her flexural wrists, dorsal hands, elbows, ankles, and dorsal feet.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I've got a red rash with small raised spots and some pus-filled bumps on my skin, mostly on my trunk and arms and legs, but not on the palms of my hands or the bottoms of my feet. How old are you? I'm just 4 days old. Does your baby have a fever? No, my baby doesn't have a fever. Is your baby full-term? Yes, my baby was born full-term.
input: A 4-day-old newborn is presented to the physician because of a generalized rash for the past day. He was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. The vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 152/min, and respirations 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: Does the rash cover the face or head?

instruction: I've been having moments where I just stare into space, smack my lips, and clasp my hands together without responding to anything around me.
input: A 5-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department by his parents for concerning behavior. His parents relate that over the past 3 weeks, he has had multiple episodes of staring into space, lip smacking, and clasping his hands together. The patient has his eyes open during these episode but does not respond to his parents’ voice or his name. These episodes last between 1-2 minutes after which the patient appears to return back to awareness. The patient is confused after these episodes and appears not to know where he is for about 15 minutes. These episodes occur once every few days and the most recent one happened about 10 minutes before the patient arrived to the emergency department. On arrival, the patient is mildly confused and does not know where he is or what recently happened. He is slow to respond to questions and appears tired.
output: How old are you and what is your gender?

instruction: I've been making uncontrollable face movements and smacking my lips for the past 2 months, and it's getting worse. How old are you and what is your gender? I am a 43-year-old woman.
input: A 43-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She says she has been uncontrollably grimacing and smacking her lips for the past 2 months, and these symptoms have been getting progressively worse. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia, managed medically with clozapine.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I've been acting inappropriately, like making wrong comments and jokes, and I even tried to kiss strangers on the street recently. Can you tell me your age and gender? I'm a 55-year-old man. Have you noticed any changes in your memory or thinking? No, my memory and thinking seem to be fine. Do you have any history of head injury or neurological conditions? No, I don't have any history of head injury or neurological conditions. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I am not taking any medications.
input: A 55-year-old man is brought to the physician because of inappropriate behavior for the past 6 months. He has been making inappropriate comments and jokes while talking to friends and family members. He was arrested 3 weeks ago while trying to kiss strangers on the street. He has no interest in talking to his daughter or playing with his grandchildren. During this period, he has developed a strong desire for chocolate pudding and potato chips and has gained 10 kg (22 lb). He appears unkempt. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Mental status examination shows apathy and a blunt affect. He avoids answering questions and instead comments on the individuals he saw in the waiting room. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 28/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatine, and electrolytes are within the reference range.
output: When did these behavioral changes begin?

instruction: I've been experiencing weakness in my right leg, unsteadiness when walking, and I've had multiple falls in the past week. How old are you? I'm 44 years old. What is your sex? I am a man. Do you have any other medical conditions? Yes, I have HIV, high blood pressure, and type 2 diabetes. When did your symptoms begin? The weakness in my leg, unsteady walking, and falls started about a week ago, but I've been more forgetful and getting lost on familiar routes for the past 6 months. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I haven't been taking my medications. Do you have any family history of neurological conditions? I'm sorry, but I don't have information about my family's medical history to share.
input:
A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for a 1-week history of right leg weakness, unsteady gait, and multiple falls. During the past 6 months, he has become more forgetful and has sometimes lost his way along familiar routes. He has been having difficulties operating simple kitchen appliances such as the dishwasher and coffee maker. He has recently become increasingly paranoid, agitated, and restless. He has HIV, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His last visit to a physician was more than 2 years ago, and he has been noncompliant with his medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 152/68 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. He is somnolent and slightly confused. He is oriented to person, but not place or time. There is mild lymphadenopathy in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Neurological examination shows right lower extremity weakness with normal tone and no other focal deficits. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 3,600/mm3
Platelet count 140,000/mm3
CD4+ count 56/µL
HIV viral load > 100,000 copies/mL
Serum
Cryptococcal antigen Negative
Toxplasma gondii IgG Positive
An MRI of the brain is shown below.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

instruction: I've been having diarrhea, I'm not gaining weight as I should, I'm losing hair, and I've developed a rash around my mouth, bottom, and on my hands and feet.
input: A 7-month-old male who had been born prematurely presents with a 2-month history of diarrhea, failure to thrive, alopecia, and rash involving the perioral, perianal, and acral areas. He had been treated unsuccessfully for presumed atopic dermatitis with topical corticosteroids. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months ago, when he was transitioned to formula. Examination reveals an irritable, thin infant with sharply demarcated red, inflamed, scaly plaques and erosions around his mouth, anus, eyes, hands, and feet. Diffuse hair loss is noted on the scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes. Paronychia and nail dystrophy are noted on his upper and lower extremities.
output: Can you tell me your age and gender?

instruction: I've been having abdominal pain for a while, and today it's become unbearable, plus I've lost 20 pounds this past month and my stools are bulky and foul-smelling. How old are you? I'm 55 years old. What is your sex? I am a man. Have you been diagnosed with any chronic illnesses? Yes, I have a history of alcohol abuse, malnutrition, Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis, and IV drug use.
input:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for abdominal pain. The patient states that he has had abdominal pain for a while, but it became unbearable today and he is concerned. He also endorses a weight loss of 20 pounds this past month and complains of bulky and foul-smelling stools. The patient is homeless and is currently living by a local wash where he obtains his drinking water and cleans his clothes. He admits to recently eating raw meat that he found. The patient has a past medical history of alcohol abuse, malnutrition, Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis, IV drug use, and a recent hospitalization for intoxication of unknown etiology. The patient is not taking any medications currently. His temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 100/67 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 11/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the patient complains of epigastric tenderness. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is started on IV fluids, thiamine, folate, magnesium, and dextrose. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below:

Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 25%
Leukocyte count: 5,500 cells/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 222,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
K+: 4.1 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 24 mg/dL
Glucose: 68 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
Ca2+: 9.8 mg/dL
Amylase: 22 U/L
Lipase: 22 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 58 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 18 U/L

A computed tomography (CT) scan is obtained as seen in Figure A.
output: Have you noticed any yellowing of your skin or eyes?

instruction: I've been feeling dizzy and like the floor is moving under me for the past 2 days. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 33-year-old man. Have you noticed any hearing loss or ringing in your ears? No, I haven't noticed any hearing loss or ringing in my ears. Did the dizziness start suddenly or gradually? The dizziness has been sustained for the past 2 days. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? I'm otherwise healthy and the only thing I'm taking is vitamin C.
input: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness. He states he has experienced a sustained sense of disequilibrium for the past 2 days. He feels that the floor is unstable/moving. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not have any other medical diagnoses. The patient is currently taking vitamin C as multiple family members are currently ill and he does not want to get sick. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a horizontal nystagmus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver does not provoke symptoms and examination of the patient’s cranial nerves is unremarkable.
output: Have you experienced any nausea or vomiting?

instruction: I'm breathing really fast, and my heart is beating quickly too.
input: A newborn born at 33 weeks of gestation has a respiratory rate of 70/min and a heart rate of 148/min 2 hours after birth. He is grunting and has intercostal and subcostal retractions. He has peripheral cyanosis as well. An immediate chest radiograph is taken which shows a fine reticular granulation with ground glass appearance on both lungs.
output: What is the patient's age?

instruction: I'm actually feeling okay; I'm here for a follow-up about something they found on my chest x-ray last week. Can you tell me your age and gender? I am a 56-year-old man. Have you ever smoked or currently do you smoke? Yes, I have smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Do you have any cough, weight loss, or shortness of breath? No, I don't have any of those symptoms. Are you taking any medications or have any other medical conditions? No, I don't have a history of major medical illness and I'm not on any medications. Do you have any family history of cancer or other major illnesses? I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history.
input: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after a chest x-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule. He has no history of major medical illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.1-cm well-circumscribed, calcified nodule in the periphery of the right lower lung field. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen shows regions of disorganized hyaline cartilage interspersed with myxoid regions and clefts of ciliated epithelium.
output: Do you know what was found on your chest x-ray?

instruction: I'm experiencing severe abdominal and lower back pain that feels like intense cramping. How old are you? I'm 24 years old. Are you currently pregnant? I'm sexually active and not using contraception, so I guess there is a possibility, but I haven't said I'm pregnant. Have you missed your period? No, my periods are happening, but they're very heavy—I soak through a pad in a day. Do you pass blood clots during your periods? I haven't mentioned anything about passing blood clots during my periods. Have you taken any medications for your symptoms? No, I haven't mentioned taking any medications for my symptoms. Have you experienced similar symptoms in previous cycles? Yes, I had a similar severe pain about a month ago.
input: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal and lower back pain. She describes it as intense cramping and states that she experienced severe pain roughly 1 month ago that was similar. The patient's past medical history is non-contributory, and she states that her menses cause her to soak through 1 pad in a day. She is currently sexually active and does not use any contraception. Her vitals are within normal limits. The patient's abdominal exam is non-focal, and her pelvic exam reveals no adnexal masses or tenderness and no cervical motion tenderness.
output: Do you experience pain during or after sexual intercourse?

instruction: I've been having progressive difficulty reading over the past year. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 75-year-old man. Have you noticed any other changes in your vision? Yes, I've been avoiding driving because I have trouble reading road signs. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? No, I have no history of a serious illness and take no medications.
input: A 75-year-old man presents to the physician with progressive difficulty reading over the past year. Currently, he avoids driving as he has trouble reading road signs. He has no history of a serious illness and takes no medications. The fundoscopic examination shows localized retinal elevation and drusen. A description of the patient’s visual on the Amsler grid is shown. Fluorescein angiography shows early hyperfluorescence.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Age-related macular degeneration

instruction: I've been having recurrent ear infections since I was born. How old are you and what is your sex? I am an 11-month-old boy. Do you have any other recurrent infections? No, just the recurrent ear infections. Do you have any family history of immune disorders? I don't know. Has your child had multiple ear infections within the last year? Yes, he has had multiple ear infections since birth. Does your child currently take any medications? No, he is not taking any medications right now.
input: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent otitis media since birth. The patient’s immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows multiple petechiae and several eczematous lesions over the scalp and extremities. The remainder of the examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,600/mm3 (61% neutrophils and 24% lymphocytes), a platelet count of 29,000/mm3, and an increased serum IgE concentration.
output: Has your child undergone any immune system tests?

instruction: I've been yelling and screaming outside, and I have this feeling that I've got technology implanted in me and I'm going to die soon. Can you please tell me your age and gender? I'm a 24-year-old woman.
input: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department when she was found yelling and screaming outside a bowling alley. The patient was found smoking marijuana and eating pizza while stating “if I'm going to die I'm going to die happy.” She was brought in by police and has been compliant since her arrival. Upon questioning, the patient states that she has had technology implanted in her for quite a while now, and she knows she will die soon. Any attempts to obtain further history are not helpful. The patient’s parents are contacted who provide additional history. They state that the patient recently started college 3 months ago. Two months ago, the patient began complaining about “technology” and seemed at times to converse with inanimate objects. On physical exam, you note a healthy young woman whose neurological exam is within normal limits. The patient is fixated on her original story and does not offer any information about her past medical history or current medications.
output: Have you been taking any medications or drugs recently?

instruction: I've been having hip pain that my usual painkillers don't help with anymore. What is your age and sex? I am a 60-year-old man. Do you have any existing medical conditions or take any regular medications? Yes, I have osteoarthritis in my hip and I've been taking high doses of painkillers for the pain. Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or changes in your urine? No, I haven't noticed any swelling or changes in my urine. Do you have any family history of kidney or urinary diseases? I'm sorry, but I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history. Do you have a history of high blood pressure? No, my blood pressure today was 110/70 mm Hg, which is within normal limits. Have you been experiencing this hip pain for a long time? Yes, I've been diagnosed with hip problems due to osteoarthritis for the past 5 years. Are you currently taking any over-the-counter pain medications? Yes, I have been taking high doses of painkillers for my hip pain.
input:
А 60-уеаr-old Ніѕраnіс mаn рrеѕеntѕ to thе offісе for а rеgulаr hеаlth сhесkuр. Не hаѕ bееn wаіtіng for his hір rерlасеmеnt ѕurgеrу for osteoarthritis, whісh he was diagnosed for the past 5 уеаrѕ. Не admits to having taken high doses of painkillers for hip pain management, but now they don’t provide any pain relief. Ніѕ vіtаl ѕigns include: blood рrеѕѕurе 110/70 mm Нg, рulѕе 78/mіn, tеmреrаturе 36.7°C (98.1°F), and rеѕріrаtorу rаtе 10/mіn. Оn physical ехаmіnаtіon, thеrе іѕ а lіmіtеd rаngе of motіon of hіѕ rіght hір.
The laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 12 g/dL
Red blood cell 5.1 million cells/µL
Hematocrit 45%
Total leukocyte count 6,500 cells/µL
Neutrophils 71%
Lymphocyte 14%
Monocytes 4%
Eosinophil 11%
Basophils 0%
Platelets 240,000 cells/µL
Urinalysis shows:
pH 6.2
Color light yellow
RBC 7–8/ HPF
WBC 10-12 /HPF
Protein 1+
Cast none
Glucose absent
Crystal none
Ketone absent
Nitrite negative
24-hr urine protein excretion 0.9 g
Urine for culture No growth noted after 48 hours of inoculation at 37.0°C (98.6°F)
output: What type of painkillers are you taking?

instruction: I've been feeling more tired than usual over the last year and my friends told me I look paler. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 67-year-old male. Do you have any medical history or take any medications? I have had arthritis for 10 years. Have you experienced any unintentional weight loss? No, I haven't mentioned any unintentional weight loss. Have you noticed any dizziness or shortness of breath? No, I didn't mention experiencing dizziness or shortness of breath. Have you noticed any blood in your stool? No, I didn't mention seeing any blood in my stool. Have you any family history of blood disorders or cancers? I haven't mentioned anything about a family history of blood disorders or cancers.
input: A 67-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of increased fatigue over the last year. He also says that his friends say he appears to be more pale. His past medical history is significant for 10 years of arthritis. Physical exam reveals spoon shaped nails as well as conjunctival pallor. Based on clinical suspicion RBC tests are ordered showing an mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 75 fl (normal 80-100 fl) and a peripheral blood smear is obtained and found to be normal. Iron studies shows a serum iron of 30 micromolar (normal range 50-170) and a serum ferritin of 300 micrograms/liter (normal range 15-200).
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Anemia of Chronic Disease

instruction: I've been experiencing increasing smooth, round spots where I'm losing hair on my scalp, and these spots are itchy and sometimes feel like they're burning. What is your age and sex? I am a 28-year-old man.
input: A 28-year-old man is referred to the dermatologist for 2 months of increasing appearance of multiple smooth, circular patches of complete hair loss on his scalp. He says that the patches have associated pruritus and a burning sensation, and are not improving with the over-the-counter products recommended by his hair stylist. He denies pulling his hair intentionally. Physical examination reveals no epidermal inflammation or erythema, and no fluorescence is detected under Wood’s lamp. A punch biopsy shows a peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles, resembling a swarm of bees.
output: Have you noticed any scaling or redness around the hair loss spots?

instruction: I suddenly passed out while playing baseball and needed CPR to wake up again. What is your age and sex? I'm a 23-year-old man. Have you experienced chest pain or palpitations before? No, I haven't had any chest pain or palpitations before. Do you have any family history of heart disease or sudden death? My case doesn't mention any family history of heart disease or sudden death. Are you currently taking any medications? No, I'm not on any medications. Have you had any previous episodes of fainting or dizziness? I haven't had any previous episodes of fainting or dizziness. Have you used any recreational drugs? My case doesn't mention the use of any recreational drugs.
input: A 23-year-old man presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury. Consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs. An S4 is present.
output: Have you had any heart tests done after the collapse?

instruction: I've been having chronic pelvic pain, particularly during sex, and I recently started having yellowish vaginal discharge. How old are you? I am 21 years old. Have you noticed any unusual odor with the discharge? No, there hasn't been any unusual odor with the discharge. Are you sexually active? Yes, I am sexually active. Have you experienced any pain or burning when you urinate? No, I haven't had any pain or burning when I urinate. Have you had any new sexual partners recently? Yes, I have had new sexual partners recently.
input: A 21-year-old woman presents to the women’s clinic with chronic pelvic pain, especially during sexual intercourse. She also reports new onset yellowish vaginal discharge. She has no significant past medical history. She does not take contraceptive pills as she has had a copper intrauterine device placed. She smokes 2–3 cigarettes every day. She drinks beer on weekends. She admits to being sexually active with over 10 partners since the age of 14. Her blood pressure is 118/66 mm Hg, the heart rate is 68/min, the respiratory rate is 12/min and the temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). On physical examination she appears uncomfortable but alert and oriented. Her heart and lung examinations are within normal limits. Bimanual exam reveals a tender adnexa and uterus with cervical motion tenderness. Whiff test is negative and vaginal pH is greater than 4.5.
output: Have you experienced any itching or irritation in your genital area?

instruction: I've been having episodes of shortness of breath and a cough that doesn't bring anything up for 3 months. How old are you and what is your gender? I'm a 4-year-old boy. Does he wheeze or have noisy breathing during his episodes? Yes, my breathing is noisy with a whistling sound during my episodes. Does he have any family history of asthma or allergies? I don’t know, nobody told me about that.
input: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician in December for episodic shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for 3 months. These episodes frequently occur before sleeping, and he occasionally wakes up because of difficulty breathing. His mother also reports that he became short of breath while playing with his friends at daycare on several occasions. He is allergic to peanuts. He is at the 55th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild scattered wheezing in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities.
output: Does he take any medications?

instruction: I've been experiencing hair loss, and I'm even pulling out clumps of hair when I shampoo in the morning. What is your age and sex? I am a 40-year-old woman. How long have you been experiencing hair loss? I started noticing more hair loss earlier this month. Have you recently experienced any significant stress or illness? No, I haven't had any significant stress or illness recently. Have you started any new medications or supplements? No, I haven't started any new medications or supplements. Have you noticed if the hair loss is patchy or uniform? The hair loss is patchy; there are smooth, circular, hairless patches across my scalp. Do you have any family history of hair loss or autoimmune diseases? My past medical history is unremarkable, so no, I don't have any family history of hair loss or autoimmune diseases.
input: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic for hair loss. She was in her usual state of health until earlier this month when she started noticing more and more hair on her pillow in the morning. The problem has only been getting worse since then; she's even started pulling out clumps of hair when she shampoos in the morning. She has no other symptoms, and her past medical history is unremarkable. The physical exam is notable for smooth, circular, non-scarring, hairless patches across her scalp. A firm tug on a bundle of hair causes almost all of the hair to be removed.
output: Have you noticed any changes in your nails?

instruction: I have blisters on my forearm that popped up 3 days ago, and I've been feeling pain in my left cheek when I eat and discomfort during sexual intercourse for the past week. What's your age and sex? I'm a 50-year-old woman. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have high blood pressure and osteoarthritis, and I recently started taking captopril while I stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. Have you noticed any new exposures or products applied to your skin recently? I haven't been exposed to anything new, but I did start hiking in the woods with my son a few months ago, being careful to avoid poison ivy. Is the blisters on your forearm itchy or painful? The blisters on my forearm aren't itchy, but they do feel painful. Have you noticed any rash or lesions on your face? Yes, I have ulcers inside my mouth on my cheek and gums. Have you noticed any sores or lesions in your genital area? Yes, I have ulcers in my genital area too. Do you have any eye symptoms, such as redness or pain? No, I don't have any eye symptoms.
input: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blisters on her forearm that appeared 3 days ago. She also reports pain in her left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. She has not been sick for the past 6 months. She has started hiking in the woods on the weekends with her son a couple months ago but has been careful to avoid poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She recently started taking captopril and stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. She has a family history of pernicious anemia and Graves' disease. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. The total body surface area involvement of the blisters is estimated to be 10%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Pemphigus vulgaris

instruction: I'm feeling confused, and I have a fever.
input: A 68-year-old woman presents to the hospital for an elective right hemicolectomy. She is independently mobile and does her own shopping. She has had type 2 diabetes mellitus for 20 years, essential hypertension for 15 years, and angina on exertion for 6 years. She has a 30-pack-year history of smoking. The operation was uncomplicated. On post-op day 5, she becomes confused. She has a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), respiratory rate of 28/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on 2 L of oxygen. She is tachycardic at 118/min and her blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. On chest auscultation, she has coarse crackles in the right lung base. Her surgical wound appears to be healing well, and her abdomen is soft and nontender.
output: How old are you?

instruction: I have itchy blisters in my armpit area. How old are you? I am 81 years old. Are you male or female? I am a male.
input: An 81-year-old man patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in his axilla. He attributes these to a poor diet. He also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to his existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane.
output: Have the blisters appeared suddenly or gradually?

instruction: I've been feeling really tired and generally unwell. What is your age and sex? I am a 71-year-old man. Have you experienced any weight loss, fever, or night sweats? Yes, I've lost 40 pounds in the past 6 months without trying. Have you any other medical conditions or take any medications? I have type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, a history of testicular cancer, and high cholesterol. Do you have any bone pain or swollen lymph nodes? I haven't mentioned any bone pain, but I do have swollen lymph nodes in my neck and groin. Do your swollen lymph nodes hurt? No, they don't hurt. Do you have any fevers or night sweats? No, I haven't mentioned having fevers or night sweats.
input: A 71-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with non-specific complaints of fatigue and malaise. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, non-seminomatous testicular cancer, and hypercholesterolemia. He currently smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day, drinks a glass of wine per day, and he currently denies any illicit drug use. His vital signs include: temperature, 36.7°C (98.0°F); blood pressure, 126/74 mm Hg; heart rate, 87/min; and respiratory rate, 17/min. On examination, his physician notices cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally, as well as splenomegaly. The patient comments that he has lost 18.1 kg (40 lb) over the past 6 months without a change in diet or exercise, which he was initially not concerned about. The physician orders a complete blood count and adds on flow cytometry.
output: Do any of your family members have cancer?

instruction: I've been noticing red urine three times in the past week and I've been experiencing recurrent headaches and sometimes my vision gets blurry for the past month. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I'm a 63-year-old man. Do you have a history of high blood pressure? My blood pressure was high at 152/95 mm Hg when it was last checked.
input:
An obese 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of 3 episodes of red urine over the past week. He has also had recurrent headaches and intermittent blurry vision during the past month. He has benign prostatic hyperplasia. He works as an attendant at a gas station. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include tamsulosin. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 152/95 mm Hg. Examination shows a flushed face. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Digital rectal examination shows an enlarged prostate with no nodules. Urinalysis shows:
Blood 3+
Glucose negative
Protein negative
WBC 1-2/hpf
RBC 40-45/hpf
RBC casts none
output: Are you taking any medications, such as blood thinners?

instruction: I've been experiencing right flank pain and vomiting for the past 5 hours.
input:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right flank pain and vomiting for 5 hours. She has had fever and chills for the past 2 days. She attended a barbecue 3 days ago, where she ate egg salad. She underwent surgery for left ovarian torsion a year ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 72.5 kg (160 lb); BMI is 27.5 kg/m2. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The right lower quadrant and right flank show severe tenderness to palpation. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,200/mm3
Platelet count 230,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
K+ 3.8 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 23 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Urine
Blood 1+
Protein 1+
Glucose negative
Leukocyte esterase positive
Nitrites negative
RBC 6–8/hpf
WBC 80–85/hpf
output: What is your age and gender?

instruction: I've been keeping to myself a lot and I don't really show much emotion, even for big events like my mother's funeral. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 31-year-old man. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions or are you taking any medications? No, I haven't been diagnosed with any medical conditions and I'm not taking any medications. Have you experienced any changes in your sleep or appetite recently? No, there haven't been any changes in my sleep or appetite. Are you experiencing feelings of sadness or hopelessness? No, I don't really feel sad or hopeless.
input: A 31-year-old man is brought in to the clinic by his sister because she is concerned about his behavior since the death of their mother 2 months ago. The patient’s sister states that he has always been a ‘loner’ and preferred being by himself than socializing with others. His social isolation resulted in him being ‘socially awkward’, as described by his family. However, 2 months ago, when he found out about the death of their mother, he showed little emotion and attended her funeral in jeans and a dirty T-shirt which upset the rest of their family. When asked about it, he shrugged and said he was in a hurry to get to the funeral and “just left the house with what I had on.” He does not speak much during the interview, allowing his sister to speak on his behalf. His sister insists that he has ‘always been like this’, quiet and a complacent child who had no interest in playing with other children. The patient currently lives alone and spends his time repairing and building electrical appliances, and his sister is worried that his self-imposed isolation is making it ‘impossible for him to interact with other people normally’. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
output: Do you enjoy spending time alone and prefer solitary activities?

instruction: I've been having fever, pain, and a rash on my belly for three days. What is your age? I'm 8 years old. Are you male or female? I am a boy. Is the rash itchy? No, it's not itchy, but it's painful.
input: An 8-year-old African-American boy presents with a 3-day history of fever, pain, and a rash on his trunk. On examination, the patient has several fragile, bullous lesions on his trunk, many of which have eroded, exposing erythematous, annular lesions. The patient is febrile and shaking in the office, and he appears to be in pain. He has no other relevant social or family history and does not take any medications. His mother is very concerned about her son.
output: Do you have any blisters on the rash?

instruction: I've been having trouble staying awake past 6 pm in the evening, even though I feel rested when I wake up. How old are you? I am 69 years old. Are you male or female? I am a male. Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions? Yes, I have irritable bowel syndrome.
input: A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble sleeping. The patient states that he recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery. When the patient retired, his goal was to finally be able to go out with his wife; however, he finds that he is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. His inability to stay awake has been straining his marriage as his wife is disappointed that they cannot do any activities in the evening together. The patient has tried drinking caffeine but finds that it does not help. The patient’s wife claims that the patient seems to sleep peacefully, and the patient states he feels rested when he awakes. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome which is managed with fiber supplements. The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits.
output: Are you currently taking any medications?

instruction: I'm not really facing any physical symptoms today; I just feel really upset and my emotions keep flipping between crying and feeling angry. How old are you? I am 28 years old.
input: A 28-year-old woman presents following a suicide attempt 2 days ago. She says that her attempt was a result of a fight with her boyfriend and that she slit her wrists in an attempt to keep him from breaking up with her. In the past, she has had many turbulent relationships, both romantic and in her family life. Her family members describe her as being very impulsive and frequently acting to manipulate people’s feelings. Since she was admitted to the hospital, she has spit at several staff members and alternated between sobbing and anger. She has no significant past medical history. The patient denies any history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use.
output: Do you identify as male or female?

instruction: I've been having this dull, aching pain in my right leg for two months, and it's gotten worse recently.
input: A 14-year-old previously healthy male presents to your office with complaints of two months of dull, aching pain in his right leg that has recently become worse. While he experiences the pain constantly, he notes that it is sometimes so bad at night that it awakes him from his sleep. Though an avid soccer player, he has been unable to participate this season due to the pain and difficulty running. He cannot think of any particular trauma that might have precipitated this pain. Vitals are all within normal range. Physical examination reveals localized tenderness below the knee with mild swelling and reduced range of motion. You order an X-ray of the painful limb, which is shown in Figure A.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I've become really suspicious that my doorman is stealing my packages and entering my apartment when I'm not around, and I've noticed that my belongings don't seem to be where I left them.
input: A 46-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist for evaluation. Three months prior, the patient moved to a new apartment building, and since then, she has become increasingly convinced that her doorman has been stealing her packages and going into her apartment while she is not home. She states that objects do not stay where she leaves them, and sometimes she expects mail but never receives it. She has filed numerous complaints with her leasing company. The building has 24-hour security footage, however, which has never shown any other person entering her apartment. On further questioning, the patient denies audiovisual hallucinations or changes in sleep, mood, energy levels, or eating. The family reports that her behavior and affect have not changed. The patient works as a pharmacist. She has no psychiatric history, although her father had a history major depressive disorder.
output: How old are you and what is your sex?

instruction: I get out of breath and tired easily when I'm walking or playing.
input: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the office due to exertional dyspnea and fatigability. He tires easily when walking or playing. His parents say that he was diagnosed with a congenital heart disease during his infancy, but they refused any treatment. They do not remember much about his diagnosis. The patient also had occasional respiratory infections throughout childhood that did not require hospitalization. He takes no medications. The patient has no family history of heart disease. His vital signs iclude: heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.2°C (98.9°F), and blood pressure of 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows toe cyanosis and clubbing but no finger abnormalities. Cardiac auscultation reveals a continuous machine-like murmur. All extremity pulses are full and equal.
output: What is your age and gender?

instruction: I passed out during a soccer game, and I've been feeling short of breath for the last 3 months and chest pain when I do strenuous activities for the past week. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 26-year-old male. Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications? No, I haven't mentioned any medical conditions or medications. Do you have a family history of heart disease? Yes, my brother had a sudden death a couple of years ago. Do you experience any palpitations? No, I haven't mentioned experiencing palpitations. Do you have any chest tightness at rest? No, I only feel chest pain when I exert myself, not at rest.
input: A 26-year-old male professional soccer player is brought to the emergency department due to an episode of syncope during a game. He has felt increasing shortness of breath during the past 3 months. During the past week, he has been feeling chest pain upon exertion. He also tells the doctor that his brother had a sudden death a couple of years ago. His heart rate is 98/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur immediately after S1; it is best heard on the apex, and it radiates to the axilla. There is also an early diastolic murmur heard in early diastole, which is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope. When the Valsalva maneuver is performed, the murmur becomes louder. An ECG and an echocardiogram are performed, which confirm the diagnosis.
output: Have you been diagnosed with any heart murmurs?

instruction: I have a rash and swelling of the hands and feet. What is your age? I am 7 months old. Are you male or female? I am female. Do you have a fever? Yes, I had high fevers up to 103 degrees Fahrenheit over the past six days.
input: A 7-month-old female presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a rash and swelling of the hands and feet. Patient's mother reports the patient developed high fevers up to 103 Farenheit over the past six days, rough skin on the chest, back, arms and swelling in the hands and feet. Mother denies any recent travel or any medication exposures. Review of systems is positive for conjunctival injection. Physical examination is remarkable for palpable cervical lymph nodes, multiple prominent tongue papillae, diffuse background erythematous patches across the chest, back, and arms. Swelling of the hands and feet is appreciated.
output: Do you have red eyes?

instruction: I've been feeling numbness and weakness in my right arm. What is your age and sex? I'm a 27-year-old woman. When did your symptoms begin? My symptoms started last week. Do you have any existing medical conditions? No, my past medical history is unremarkable.
input: A 27-year-old woman presents to your office complaining of right arm numbness and weakness. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Her family history, however, is significant for the unexpected death of both her parents at age 59 in a motor vehicle accident last week. On physical exam, her bicep, brachioradialis, and patellar reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. CNS imaging shows no abnormalities.
output: Have you experienced any other symptoms?

instruction: I've been experiencing lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months.
input: A 34-year-old man presents to his physician with a complaint of lower back pain and stiffness for the past few months. He describes the pain as being worse in the morning and then gradually improving with activity throughout the day. On physical exam, he has decreased anterior flexion of the lumbar spine. A radiograph of his lumbar spine is obtained and is shown in Figure A.
output: How old are you and what is your sex?

instruction: I've been having persistent bleeding from the gums where my wisdom teeth were removed, and I also tend to bruise easily. What is your age and sex? I'm a 17-year-old boy. Have you had any previous medical conditions or surgeries? No, I've been previously healthy. Do you have any family history of bleeding disorders? Yes, my uncle had similar problems with bleeding and also has a history of easy bruising and joint swelling.
input:
A previously healthy 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother for further evaluation after elective removal of his wisdom teeth. During the procedure, the patient had persistent bleeding from the teeth's surrounding gums. Multiple gauze packs were applied with minimal effect. The patient has a history of easy bruising. The mother says her brother had similar problems when his wisdom teeth were removed, and that he also has a history of easy bruising and joint swelling. The patient takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 108/74 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 35%
Leukocyte count 8,500/mm3
Platelet count 160,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 15 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 60 sec
Bleeding time 6 min
Fibrin split products negative
Serum
Urea nitrogen 20 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 1.0 mg/dL
Direct 0.5 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 90 U/L
Peripheral blood smear shows normal-sized platelets.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Hemophilia A

instruction: I have this skin rash on my nose and cheeks that comes back every summer after I've been in the sun too much, and it goes away without leaving any scars. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 40-year-old female. Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications? I have arthritis and chronic fatigue, but I didn't mention any medications. Are you currently taking any medications for your arthritis? I didn't say if I'm taking any medications for it.
input: A 40-year-old female presents with a recurrent skin eruption on her nose and cheeks for 2 years. These lesions appears usually in the summer following excessive sun exposure, and disappears without scarring. She has complains about arthritis and chronic fatigue. She denies muscle weakness. Physical exam reveals eroded butterfly-shaped erythematous plaques over the malar area, non-scarring alopecia and oral ulcers.
output: Are there any other symptoms you’re experiencing?

instruction: I have some painful bumps that look like boils on my skin and now there are open sores that are draining clear fluid. What is your age and sex? I am a 54-year-old male. Do you have any underlying medical conditions or take any medications? Yes, I have diabetes mellitus. Are the bumps located in a specific area of your body? The bumps started at the scratch on my skin and then additional bumps appeared in a line from that spot.
input: A 54-year-old gardener with diabetes mellitus from the Northeast Jillin Province in China acquired a small scratch from a thorn while working in his flower garden. After 3 weeks, he noticed a small pink, painless bump at the site of a scratch. He was not concerned by the bump; however, additional linearly-distributed bumps that resembled boils began to appear 1 week later that were quite painful. When the changes took on the appearance of open sores that drained clear fluid without any evidence of healing (as shown on the image), he finally visited his physician. The physician referred to the gardener for a skin biopsy to confirm his working diagnosis and to start treatment as soon as possible.
output: Have you been exposed to plants or soil recently?

instruction: I have loose and stretchy skin, and I bruise easily.
input: A 16-year-old male with past medical history of mitral valve prolapse presents for evaluation of loose skin. Patient's parents report a several year history of stretchy skin, poor wound healing with some scars healing with thin overlying skin, and easy bruising. There is a family history of similar symptoms amongst other family members. Physical examination reveals soft, significantly extensible skin diffusely, multiple linear scars with atrophic overlying pink patches, and white-yellow papules along the bilateral inner and outer calcaneus upon standing. The patient is able to touch the tip of his nose with his tongue.
output: Can you tell me your age and sex?

instruction: I've been having headaches, feeling generally unwell, and a sharp pain on the right side of my head for four days. Can you tell me your age and sex? I'm a 42-year-old man. Do you have any skin rashes or changes? Yes, I developed a rash over the area where I have the pain, on my right forehead.
input: A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history.
output: Do you have any blisters or vesicles on the rash?

instruction: I've been feeling really sad most days, I'm having a hard time sleeping, and it's hard to concentrate on my tasks. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 27-year-old woman. How long have you been feeling this way? I've been feeling this way for about 2 to 3 years.
input: A 27-year-old woman visits a psychiatrist expressing her feelings of sadness which are present on most days of the week. She says that she has been feeling this way for about 2 to 3 years. During her first pregnancy 3 years ago, the fetus died in utero, and the pregnancy was terminated at 21 weeks. Ever since then, she hasn’t been able to sleep well at night and has difficulty concentrating on her tasks most of the time. However, for the past month, she has found it more difficult to cope. She says she has no will to have another child as she still feels guilty and responsible for the previous pregnancy. Over the past few days, she has completely lost her appetite and only eats once or twice a day. She doesn’t recall a single day in the last 3 years where she has not felt this way. The patient denies any past or current smoking, alcohol, or recreational drug use.
output: Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?

instruction: I've been experiencing a loss of control over my urine and bowel movements for the past 6 hours. Can you please tell me your age and sex? I am a 47-year-old man. Are you experiencing any back pain or leg weakness? Yes, I have lower back pain and weakness in both of my legs. Have you noticed any numbness in your groin or saddle area? The vignette didn't mention any numbness in my groin or saddle area.
input: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he suffered a fall at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine, bilateral lower extremity weakness, absent ankle jerk reflexes, and preserved patellar reflexes. There is decreased rectal tone. An ultrasound of the bladder shows a full bladder.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Conus medullaris syndrome

instruction: I have sores in my mouth that have been there for a while and are really painful, and a few days ago I started getting these fragile blisters on my skin that quickly turned into similar sores.
input: A 52-year-old woman presents with erosions in her mouth that are persistent and painful. She says that symptoms appeared gradually 1 week ago and have progressively worsened. She also notes that, several days ago, flaccid blisters appeared on her skin, which almost immediately transformed to erosions as well.
output: What is your age?

instruction: I have multiple spots on my abdomen that have spread to my arms and legs.
input: A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician office with complaints of multiple spots that began on the abdomen and spread to the arms and legs. The spots are not itchy or painful, unless he scratches them. Sometimes the skin surronding the lesion will become very red and painful, but then the lesion and redness fade. The parents report they have tried topical corticosteroids but the lesions do not go away. Mom endorses a history of atopic dermatitis in her sister and herself. Physical exam reveals multiple dome shaped skin colored to light pink papules with central umbilication and yellow core across the chest, abdomen, and back.
output: What is your age and sex?

instruction: I hit my head and was out for a bit, then I started having a really bad headache with feeling sick to my stomach and throwing up. What is your age and sex? I'm 35 years old and male. Did you lose consciousness when you hit your head? Yes, I was unconscious after hitting my head but then I woke up. Are your headaches getting progressively worse? Yes, the headache got severe. Are you experiencing any weakness or numbness in your limbs? I can't tell, I'm confused and can't provide details.
input: A 35-year-old is brought into the emergency room after a bicycle vs motored vehicle accident. He was unconscious after hitting the side of his head on the road, but recovered consciousness after a few minutes. He started to ride his bicycle again, but then developed a severe headache with nausea and vomiting, at which time he called EMS. While in the hospital, the patient is confused and cannot provide a history. He quickly loses consciousness and his CT scan is displayed in Figure 1.
output: **Final Diagnosis:** Epidural Hematoma

instruction: I noticed a big lump on my elbow this morning that I've never seen before. How old are you and what is your sex? I'm a 55-year-old man. Is the lump painful? No, the lump is not painful.
input: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an enlarged mass on his elbow he noticed this morning. He states that he has never seen it before. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and a 35 pack-year smoking history. He recently started boxing to get into shape. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for a mass seen in Figure A, which is rubbery and non-tender.
output: Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to the elbow?

instruction: I've been having this tender spot on my left ear that comes and goes, and it's been like that for about six months now. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 60-year-old female. Has the spot changed in size or color? No, it hasn't changed in size or color. Have you had any recent injury or trauma to your ear? No, I haven't had any injury or trauma to my ear. Do you notice any itching or discharge from the spot? No, there's no itching or discharge.
input: A 60-year-old female presents with an intermittently tender spot on the left ear present for six months. She denies any trauma to the area but notes she often lays on the left side when sleeping at night. She denies any history of skin cancer. Examination reveals a crusted light pink papule along the left superior helix along the cartilaginous component. A biopsy is performed and reveals an ulcer with underlying dermal fibrosis with adjacent granulation tissue.
output: Do you have any chronic medical conditions or take any regular medications?

instruction: My fingernails are inflamed, and the skin around my nails is red and swollen. How old are you and what is your sex? I am a 35-year-old woman.
input: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with inflammation of her fingernails that first appeared 5 months ago and recently worsened. She reports wearing acrylic nails for the last year, removing them just before the clinic visit. On examination, the patient has erythema and swelling of the lateral nail folds and hyperpigmentation of the proximal nail folds of all fingers on her right hand. Examination also reveals nail dystrophy, onycholysis, and an absence of cuticles. She has not tried any treatments for this condition.
output: How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?

instruction: I've been feeling weakness in my legs and having trouble breathing. What is your age and sex? I am a 35-year-old woman.
